Working Paper

SWP Working Papers are online publications within the purview of the respective Research Division. Unlike SWP Research Papers and SWP Comments they are not reviewed by the Institute.


RESEARCH DIVISION INTERNATIONAL SECURITY

|

WP NR.

2,

AUGUST 2023


Nuclear rhetoric and escalation management in

Russia’s war against Ukraine: A chronology


Liviu Horovitz and Martha Stolze

Contents


Introduction 3

Key statements & developments 6

Graphic representation 15

Autumn & Winter 2021 – 2022: First nuclear signals 18

February 2022: The high-time of nuclear threat-making 22

March 2022: Drawing red lines 29

April 2022: Fading momentum 48

May 2022: Backpedalling to the official doctrine 66

June 2022: Bringing Belarus into the nuclear fold? 79

July 2022: Nuclear narratives loose steam 92

August 2022: Everything was misunderstood? 100

September 2022: Placing annexed provinces under a nuclear umbrella? 112

October 2022: Threats and warnings everyday 130

November 2022: The sudden demise of nuclear rhetoric 147

December 2022: Nuclear diversion from conventional destruction 160

January 2023: Leopards freed; Moscow’s nuclear rhetoric silent 170

February 2023: Of Western figherjets and Ukrainian incursions 180

March 2023: Russian nuclear rhetoric returns in full force 190

April 2023: A quiet spring on the nuclear rhetoric front 208

May 2023: Western debates on arming Ukraine – but few nuclear statements 221

June 2023: Some Russian nuclear rhetoric returns with Ukraine’s offensive 237

Introduction


During the night of February 23, 2022, Russian forces crossed into Ukraine, seeking to capture Kyiv within days. A few hours later, Russian President Vladimir Putin announced the beginning of a “special military operation.” In his speech, the Kremlin leader warned those who tried to stand in Russia’s way that they would face “never seen” consequences – a statement many interpreted as a thinly veiled threat to employ nuclear weapons. Nuclear allusions piled up in the subsequent weeks and months. Moscow’s nuclear in- sinuations were accompanied by Western comments, condemnations, and a few counter-threats. Most importantly, the Russian allusions triggered a public debate in several Western countries about how such narratives should be interpreted and what responses they required. This working paper attempts to col- lect Russia’s nuclear narratives and the reactions of the West.


As a starting point, we decided to go back to autumn 2021 to offer readers a before-after comparison. Nonetheless, given available resources, with regard to the time period until February 2022, this chronol- ogy only includes (a) ex post revelations of Washington’s assessments of Moscow’s intentions; (b) Russia’s public statements on a potential conflict with NATO; and (c) the Kremlin’s nuclear-related statements. We purposefully exclude numerous other contentious issues, like for instance Russia’s demands that NATO rule out Ukraine’s membership;1 insistence upon Western restrictions on weapons deployments;2 threats to deploy intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe in response to a similar NATO decision;3 or re- fusal to rule out a military deployment to Cuba or Venezuela.4


From February 24, 2022 onwards, we mainly focus on tracing nuclear signaling between Russia and the West, but we also include the two sides’ attempts at managing and controlling escalation dynamics; at exercising deterrence, dissuasion, and compellence; and at dealing with the domestic and international political implications of these nuclear-related processes. Within the West, we focus primarily on state- ments by officials from nuclear-weapon states or from NATO: We suspected that the statements of these individuals were more likely to lead to potential nuclear escalation.


Therefore, we identified, evaluated, and coded more than 200 statements and actions with a nuclear di- mension, but also included hundreds of other potentially relevant exchanges. Below, we start by listing the most important developments. Subsequently, we present them graphically. The bulk of this paper, however, contains our summaries of all statements and actions we deemed relevant. We sought to provide enough context to enable the reader to trace back the unfolding discussions, and (where reasonably easy to access) include references to primary sources. Nonetheless, this chronology does not claim to be ex- haustive.


1 Andrea Shalal, Steve Holland and Andrew Osborn, “Biden warns Putin of sanctions, aid for Ukraine military if Russia invades,” Reuters, December 8, 2021 [https://www.reuters.com/markets/currencies/biden-putin-set-crucial-call-over-ukraine-2021-12- 07/], and Vladimir Soldatkin and Dmitry Antonov, “Kremlin says presidents agree to further US-Russian talks on Ukraine,” Reu- ters, December 8, 2021 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/putin-demands-security-guarantees-biden-curb-nato-expan- sion-2021-12-07/].


2 “Foreign Ministry statement on dialogue with the United States and other Western countries regarding security guarantees,” Website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation, December 10, 2021 [https://archive.mid.ru/en/foreign_pol- icy/news/-/asset_publisher/cKNonkJE02Bw/content/id/4991520].


3 Alexander Marrow and Mark Trevelyan, “Russia says it may be forced to deploy mid-range nuclear missiles in Europe,” Reuters, December 13, 2021 [https://www.reuters.com/world/russia-says-lack-nato-security-guarantees-would-lead-confrontation-ria- 2021-12-13/].


4 Vladimir Isachenkov and Matthew Lee, “Russia’s talk of troops in Latin America called ‘bluster’,” AP News, January 14, 2022 [https://apnews.com/article/europe-russia-ukraine-vladimir-putin-moscow-473d4b2eebff4dc59d8e7dff9e8653ba].

This is the fourth and last update of this chronology. The first version of this working paper appeared in German in May 2022. The second iteration went online in September 2022. The third version was pub- lished in February 2023.


This fourth update contains two innovations.


Firstly, as journalists have managed to gain and publish new insights into events from 2021 on- wards, we have tried to include this newly available information. To make it easier for readers to follow these updates, we have highlighted these changes in blue. This approach allowed us to include two additional nuclear signals, #111 and #150 below.


Secondly, we have colour-coded the various nuclear signals of escalation, warning and de-escala- tion throughout the document for an easier identification.


Escalatory


Warning


De-escalatory


Our analytical bottom line is that, compared to 2022, Russia’s nuclear rhetoric has toned down. In this fourth issue of the chronology we analysed all statements of the past five months, from Febraury 2023 until June 2023. Both escalatory statements we identified in this time period concerned the Russian sta- tioning of nuclear weapons in Belarus. Otherwise, the tensions remained at the level of warnings, spotted with a few de-escalatory statements. Overall, with only two escalatory statements from Moscow, Russia’s nuclear rhetoric was less threatening compared to the five months prior which saw eight Russian and one Western escalatory statements.


Taken together, three peaks of escalatory nuclear rhetoric can be identified between February 2022 and June 2023.

  • 24-28 February 2022 saw Russian escalatory threats at the beginning of the war. Putin claimed that Western actions were a “very real threat” to “the very existence” of the Russian state and to its “sovereignty.” Whoever tried to hinder Russia in Ukraine would face consequences “never seen,” he argued. He also put Russia’s “deterrence forces” on “high combat alert” (see below, statements no. 5 and 11). Western reactions comprised escalatory statements by British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss, voicing that Russia must be stopped in Ukraine, and the US warning Russia against using tactical nuclear weapons (no. 10 and 15).

  • 25-29 April 2022 was marked by two Western escalatory statements, as US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin declared the United States now wanted “to see Russia weakened to the degree that it can’t do the kinds of things it has done in invading Ukraine,” a statement Pentagon spokesperson John Kirby confirmed (no. 49, 52). In response, Putin warned that Russia’s response to strategic threats would be “swift, lighting fast,” and that Russia had “all the tools for this” and would “use them if needed” (no. 53).

  • 20-30 September 2022 was a period of numerous Russian nuclear threats. Prior to Putin announc- ing the annexation of four Ukrainian provinces on September 30, Dmitry Medvedev, the Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council and a former president and prime minister, noted that Russia could defend itself with “all the forces of self-defense” in case of an encroachment of its ter- ritory (no. 96). Putin also vowed to “make use of all weapon systems available” in case of “a threat

to the territorial integrity” of Russia (no. 97). Medvedev reiterated that “any Russian weapons, in- cluding strategic weapons” could be used to protect “all the territories that have joined [Russia]” (no. 101). Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov then underlined that all doctrines would apply to the entire Russian territory, including the nuclear security doctrine (no. 103); and Medvedev high- lighted that Russia had “the right to use nuclear weapons if necessary” (no. 106). Washington re- acted with National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan stressing that “the possible use of nuclear weap- ons for the first time since the Second World War” was “a matter that we have to take deadly seriously” and which would trigger “catastrophic consequences” (no. 104).


Notably, these peaks of escalatory rhetoric did not only provoke (limited) counter-threats, but were es- pecially countered by a similar amount of de-escalatory statements. Accordingly, the two Russian escala- tory threats during 24-28 February were met with two Western counter-threats and a series of four West- ern de-escalatory statements. Likewise, the three escalatory threats of 25-29 April (two Western, one Russian) seem to also have been balanced out by a Western and a Russian de-escalatory statement. The same can be said about 20-30 September, when six Russian escalatory statements were met with one Western counter-threat and four Western de-escalatory statements.


The bulk of statements, however, fell in the category of warnings and counter-warnings. In total, we counted 66 Russian and 50 Western warnings; compared to 29 Russian vs. 38 Western de-escalatory statements and 15 Russian and 6 Western escalatory threats. Numerically, the Western attempts at de- escalation have thus been higher.


Overall, compiling this chronology has been a time-consuming endeavor, but it has allowed us to place certain Russian statements and actions in a broader context, to offer empirically based policy analysis and advice, and to publish a number of products.


For example, in March 2022, Liviu Horovitz, Claudia Major, and Lydia Wachs advised the West to care-

fully assess these nuclear developments, but to avoid Putin’s escalation game. As early as April 2022, Liviu Horovitz and Lydia Wachs published an initial analysis of Russia’s nuclear threats. They argued that Moscow’s threats had to be taken seriously, but that there was no reason to panic – an analysis that seems prescient in retrospect. The SWP podcast has made their assessments available to a wider audi- ence.


Based on this chronology, team members were able to provide well-informed analysis to various media outlets. An examples of Liviu Horovitz's work can be found here. A few of the many contributions of Lydia Wachs can be accessed here, here, or here.


In September 2022, Liviu Horovitz and Anna Clara Arndt published a second analysis of Russia’s rheto- ric. They argued that, below the threshold of direct intervention, Western governments had more lee- way to aid Ukraine’s war effort than many pundits and policymakers presumed.


This chronology also allowed team members to author controversial opinion pieces. For instance, in No- vember 2022, Liviu Horovitz, Anna Clara Arndt, and Lydia Wachs wrote that the constraints imposed by nuclear weapons would likely force both beligerents and their supporters into a protracted conflict.


Last but not least, Liviu Horovitz and Anna Clara Arndt published a third analysis of Russia’s nuclear sig- nalling. They concluded that, faced with concerted opposition, Russia had abandoned its nuclear coer- cion attempts and its nuclear rhetoric had since largely subsided.

Key statements & developments


Below we include a selection of the most important nuclear interactions in this conflict. We coded the Russian steps and Western reactions. For the sake of simplicity, we distinguished between two actors only: Russia (RU) and the West (W). We classified the most important statements or actions as escala- tory, warning or de-escalatory. “Escalatory” is anything that can be considered at least an implicit threat of nuclear use. “Warning” is anything that can at least be interpreted as an allusion to nuclear capabili- ties or a possible conventional escalation, but without the threat of nuclear use being directly derived from it. “De-escalatory” is everything that questions or even retracts previous statements or actions that were somehow linked to possible nuclear use, or includes steps through which actors (probably inten- tionally) forego an escalatory action.


1. 27 January 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Russia has “the right” to use nuclear weapons

in response to an existential threat, a right that makes it “possible to achieve various goals.”

2. 7 February 2022: RU [escalatory]: Putin: If Ukraine attempts to take back Crimea, Euro- pean countries will be in conflict with Russia, which is a “leading” nuclear power superior to

“many” NATO countries in terms of “nuclear force.”

3. 19 February 2022: RU [warning]: Yearly nuclear exercise, normally held in autumn.

4. 21-22 February 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: Ukraine is seeking to acquire tactical nuclear

weapons, which would pose a “strategic threat” to Russia.

5. 24 February 2022: RU [escalatory]: Putin: Whoever tries to hinder Russia will face conse- quences “never seen” in history.

6. 24 February 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: Russia is “one of the most powerful nuclear states” and “there should be no doubt for anyone” that a direct attack on Russia would lead to defeat.

7. 24 February 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Biden: No US troops involved in the conflict, only to defend NATO.

8. 24 February 2022: W [warning]: Le Drian: NATO also has nuclear weapons.

9. 26 February 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Western states decide to only impose economic sanctions upon Russia and deliver military support for Ukraine.

10. 27 February 2022: W [escalatory]: Truss: Russia must be stopped in Ukraine.

11. 27 February 2022: RU [escalatory]: Putin: Russian deterrence forces will be placed on

“high combat alert.”

12. 27 February 2022: W [warning]: Borrell: Financial aid to Ukraine, but also military jets (MiGs).

13. 28 February 2022: RU [warning]: Shoigu: High combat alert = more personnel.

14. 28 February 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Psaki: Announces additional support for Ukraine, but the United States can defend itself.

15. 28 February 2022: W [escalatory]: US warning Russia against using tactical nuclear weap-

ons.

16. 28 February 2022: RU [warning]: Zakharova: United States dreams of deploying nuclear

weapons to Ukraine.

17. 1 March 2022: RU [warning]: Russian military exercises with nuclear submarines in the Barents Sea and with mobile ICBMs in Siberia.

18. 28 February & 1 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Biden: US citizens have no reason to be afraid of nuclear war. US forces will not fight in Ukraine, only defend NATO.

19. 2 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Poland, Slovakia, Bulgaria, NATO will not send MiGs to Ukraine.

20. 2 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: United States reschedules Minuteman III test.

21. 2 & 3 March 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Lavrov: Thought of nuclear war is on Western, not

Russian minds. Zakharova: Russia will not use nuclear weapons first.

22. 4 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: NATO foreign ministers reject the no fly zone requested by Ukraine.

23. 5 March 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: A no fly zone would have “disastrous consequences.” And: The decision to put Russia’s deterrence forces on high alert had been necessary because UK Foreign Minister Truss had announced a NATO intervention in Ukraine.

24. 8 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Haines: No changes of the Russian nuclear posture, Putin wants to deter Western support for Ukraine.

25. 9 March 2022: RU [warning]: Peskov: MiGs that take off from “any other airfields” on NATO territory would be “an extremely undesirable and potentially dangerous scenario.”

26. 10 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Wolters: MiGs could be “mistaken as escalatory and

could result in Russian escalation with NATO.”

27. 11 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Biden: NATO will be defended, but a direct confronta- tion with Russia – a third world war – has to be avoided.

28. 15 March 2022: W [warning]: Poland demands a NATO peacekeeping mission for Ukraine.

29. 16 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: NATO decides not to send peacekeeping troops to Ukraine but to expand economic and military assistance.

30. 16 March 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: The West wants to “finish off” Russia, but it will fail.

31. 18-20 March 2022: RU [warning]: Use of a conventional Kinzhal missile in Ukraine.

32. 20 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Austin: Putin trying to “reestablish some momentum” and the United States can defend itself.

33. 22 March 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Peskov: Nuclear weapons would only be used in “exis-

tential threat.” Ryabkov: Russia would “never escalate anything.”

34. 23 March 2022: RU [warning]: Peskov: A NATO mission in Ukraine would be “very reckless

and extremely dangerous” and could have “consequences that would be hard to repair.”

Lavrov: Everyone should try to avoid a “direct clash between the Russian and NATO armed

forces.” Medvedev: Russia’s destruction could lead to nuclear war. Rogozin: Russia could de- stroy “any aggressor.”

35. 23 March 2022: W [escalatory]: Anonymous Biden administration official: Use of a tactical nuclear weapon in Ukraine would mean “all bets are off” regarding direct US intervention in the war. But nuclear use remains unlikely. Sullivan: There have been no Russian prepara-

tions.

36. 23 March 2022: W [warning]: France conducts test of nuclear-armed missile and deploys three of its four nuclear submarines.

37. 23 March 2022: W [warning]: Stoltenberg: „Any use of nuclear weapons will fundamentally

change the nature of the conflict.”

38. 26 March 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Russia could use nuclear weapons if its existence is threatened, even by conventional weapons.

39. 28 March 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Peskov: Any outcome of the operation in Ukraine is “of course” not a reason to use nuclear weapons, only an existential threat would be. But: Every- one understands what Putin meant with his warning “not to interfere.” And: He does “not think” Putin would use nuclear weapons if a third country intervened in Ukraine. But: Russia has “all the possibilities” to punish such states. But: “No one is thinking about using, even

about the idea of using a nuclear weapon.”

40. 31 March 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Senior Pentagon official: “No indication” Russia is pre-

paring to use tactical nuclear weapons.

41. 1 April 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Pentagon cancels Minuteman III test.

42. 7 April 2022: W [warning]: G7 and Borrell: Any threat or use of nuclear weapons would be

“unacceptable and result in severe consequences.”

43. 14 April 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: If Sweden and Finland join NATO, “no non-nuclear status of the Baltics will be possible.”

44. 14 April 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Burns: Putin’s threats must be taken seriously, but so far

there are no alarming indications.

45. 19 April 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Kirby: Washington is monitoring Russian rhetoric, but confident its strategic deterrent posture remains sufficient.

46. 19 April 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Lavrov: Russia initiated Putin-Biden and P5 statements that nuclear war cannot be won and must not be fought.

47. 20 April 2022: RU [warning]: Russia tests nuclear-capable Sarmat intercontinental missile. Putin: Sarmat will “safeguard Russia’s security from external threats.”

48. 20 April 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Kirby: Sarmat test was “routine” and Russia “properly

notified” the United States.

49. 25 April 2022: W [escalatory]: Austin: United States wants “to see Russia weakened to the

degree that it can’t do the kinds of things that it has done in invading Ukraine.”

50. 25 April 2022: RU [warning]: Lavrov: The risks of nuclear war are “very significant,” “seri- ous” and “real.” But: He does not want to “artificially inflate these risks.” And: It is Russia’s “principled position” that nuclear war is inadmissible. Western arms deliveries to Ukraine are

“pouring oil on the fire.”

51. 26 April 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Johnson: No risk of Moscow using nuclear weapons.

52. 27 April 2022: W [escalatory]: Kirby: United States do not want “to see Russia in a position

to be able to do this again” and Russia should not be “in a position going forward, where they haven't suffered consequences for this unprovoked invasion.”

53. 27 April 2022: RU [escalatory]: Putin: “If someone intends to intervene on what is happen- ing from the outside and creates unacceptable strategic threats for us, then they should know that our response to oncoming strikes will be swift, lightning fast.” And: “We have all the tools

for this, ones that no one can brag about.”

54. 28 April 2022: W [warning]: Sullivan: “We won’t succumb to nuclear blackmail,” nor “toler-

ate nuclear saber rattling and nuclear brinksmanship.”

55. 28 April 2022: W [warning]: Biden: United States is prepared for “whatever” Russia might

do, but would send only military assistance, not troops, to Ukraine.

56. 29 April 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Lavrov: Russian policymakers are “champions of mak-

ing pledges by all nuclear countries never to start a nuclear war.”

57. 4 May 2022: RU [warning]: Russia simulates electronic launches of nuclear-capable missiles in Kaliningrad – unclear whether training routine or political signaling.

58. 5 May 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Antonov: Russia would only use nuclear weapons defen- sively, in response to WMD use or when state existence is endangered.

59. 6 May 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Zaitsev: Nuclear contingencies spelled out in Russia’s nu-

clear doctrine do not apply to the conflict in Ukraine.

60. 6 May 2022: W [warning]: Tomero: Nuclear use would have “devastating consequences” for

Russia.

61. 7 May 2022: W [warning]: Macron inauguration ceremony with a nuclear component.

62. 7 May 2022: W [warning]: Burns: No evidence that Russia is planning for nuclear use, but its saber-rattling cannot be taken “lightly.”

63. 9 May 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: The nuclear-capable component of the Victory Day parade is cancelled and Putin makes no nuclear references.

64. 10 May 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Grushko: Official nuclear doctrine drives policy.

65. 10 May 2022: W [warning]: Haines: Russia is using nuclear threats to deter Western supply of military aid – Putin would only use nuclear weapons in case of an existential threat. But:

losing the war and/or a NATO intervention could qualify as such.

66. 12 May 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: NATO aid to Ukraine could lead to an open conflict with Russia, which would risk “full-fledged nuclear war.”

67. 28 May 2022: RU [warning]: Russia tests a hypersonic Zircon cruise missile.

68. 29 May 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Kelin: Russia will use nuclear weapons when state exist- ence is threatened. This has “nothing to do” with a “limited conventional operation.”

69. 31 May 2022: W [warning]: Biden: “Any” nuclear use “in this conflict” would be “completely unacceptable” and “entail severe consequences.”

70. 2 June 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Biden: Signals US readiness to engage Russia on strategic

stability to reduce risks of arms race or nuclear escalation.

71. 3 June 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Foreign-supplied weapons use against Russia could lead to strike on suppliers, which could lead to nuclear apocalypse.

72. 15 June 2022: RU [warning]: Ryabkov: US planners have an “ideology” of “limited nuclear war,” and a US nuclear use would be an “irreversible event.”

73. 17 June 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Putin: “We are not threatening anyone” but would use “resources” to “defend our sovereignty.”

74. 17 June 2022: W [warning]: US tests Trident II missile.

75. 25 June 2022: RU [escalatory]: Putin: Announces the transfer of nuclear-capable missiles to Belarus and the re-equipment of its bombers to carry nuclear weapons.

76. 27 June 2022: W [warning]: G7 agrees that “any” nuclear use would be “unacceptable and met with severe consequences” – concern after Belarus announcement.

77. 28 June 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Peskov: Russia is not planning to deploy nuclear weap- ons to Belarus, just nuclear-capable delivery vehicles.

78. 28 June 2022: W [warning]: US military unsuccessfully tests a hypersonic missile.

79. 6 July 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Trying to punish a country with a large nuclear arse- nal is “absurd,” could pose a “threat to the existence of humanity.”

80. 7 July 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Matvienko: Russia sees nuclear weapons only as a deter-

rent, “exceptional cases” are “clearly and strictly prescribed.”

81. 12 July 2022: RU [warning]: Zakharova: Washington is “dangerously teetering on the brink of an open military confrontation” with Moscow – such “direct armed conflict between nu- clear powers” would be “fraught with nuclear escalation.”

82. 12 July 2022: RU [warning]: Rogozin: Russia is preparing tests of Sarmat missiles.

83. 12 July 2022: W [warning]: United States conducts two successful hypersonic missile tests.

84. 20 July 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Brown: If Putin uses nuclear weapons in Ukraine, US pol- icy is “all about deterrence” and avoiding a “slippery slope that we can’t recover from.”

85. 2 August 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Restatement of official nuclear doctrine and claim that none of its contingencies is “relevant to the situation in Ukraine.”

86. 5 August 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Russia’s nuclear policy is “aimed exclusively at protect-

ing the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the country.”

87. 5 August 2022: W [warning]: Kahl: It is “not the time” for a sole purpose declaratory policy,

in light of, for instance, Russia’s nuclear rhetoric.

88. 16 August 2022: W [warning]: US test launch of the Minuteman III ICBM.

89. 16 August 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Shoigu: “From a military point of view, there is no need to use nuclear weapons in Ukraine.”

90. 22 August 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Ryabkov: Clash between nuclear powers must be pre-

vented. As per Russian doctrine, nuclear use only in case of aggression and threat to existence of the state.

91. 1 September 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Macron: France’s role is to avoid nuclear escalation and “everything” has to be done for “countries not to get engaged in the conflict carelessly.”

92. 7 September 2022: W [warning]: US conducts an announced Minuteman III test.

93. 14 September 2022: RU [warning]: Zakharova: Sending long-range weapons to Ukraine

would make the United States “a direct party to the conflict.”

94. 16 September 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: Russia could intensify attack on Ukrainian infra- structure. And: Russia’s military conducts nuclear drills in the Arctic to test its ability to “de-

fend the Russian arctic by military means.”

95. 16 September 2022: W [warning]: Biden: Russian nuclear use would “change the face of

war unlike anything since World War II” and a US response would be “consequential.”

96. 20 September 2022: RU [escalatory]: Medvedev: Russia could defend the four Ukrainian

provinces it was annexing with “all the forces of self-defense.”

97. 21 September 2022: RU [escalatory]: Putin: Russia will “make use of all weapon systems

available to us” in case of “a threat to the territorial integrity” of Russia. “This is not a bluff.”

98. 21 September 2022: W [warning]: Stoltenberg: Allies will not engage in similarly “reckless and dangerous nuclear rhetoric,” but “will make sure that there is no misunderstanding in Moscow about the seriousness of using nuclear weapons,” which would cause “unprece-

dented consequences.”

99. 21 September 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Biden: Condemns Russia for “making irresponsible

nuclear threats,” but does not issue any own warnings.

100. 22 September 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Blinken: Urges the UN Security Council to “send a clear message that these reckless nuclear threats must stop immediately,” but refrains from issuing any own warnings.

101. 22 September 2022: RU [escalatory]: Medvedev: Any weapons, “including strategic nuclear weapons and weapons based on new principles, could be used” to protect “all the territories

that have joined [Russia].”

102. 23 September 2022: W [de-escalatory]: US officials: Express concern Putin could use tacti- cal nuclear weapons, but stress that there is “no evidence” Russia was preparing such a

strike.

103. 24 September 2022: RU [escalatory]: Lavrov: Russia’s “entire territory” is “under the state’s full protection” and all Russian “doctrines” apply to Russia’s “entire territory.”

104. 25 September 2022: W [escalatory]: Sullivan: “Any use of nuclear weapons will be met with catastrophic consequences for Russia.” Washington has been “clear and specific” to-

wards the Kremlin regarding the US response.

105. 26 September 2022: RU [warning]: Ryabkov: Accuses Washington of an “irresponsible, ex-

tremely aggressive, extremely pushy course,” which is “bringing everyone closer to a danger- ous line.”

106. 27 September 2022: RU [escalatory]: Medvedev: If the “threat” to Russia from “Nazi

Ukraine” exceeds “the established danger limit,” the Kremlin “will have to respond,” including with “the most formidable weapon,” while the West will still “not directly intervene in the

conflict even in this situation.”

107. 27 September 2022: W [de-escalatory]: US Strategic Command: “We have not seen any reason to adjust our own nuclear posture at this time.”

108. 28 September 2022: RU [warning]: Zakharova: The West talks “with ease” about nuclear

weapons and is “engaged in total destruction” against Russia, whereas Moscow has pursued

“many attempts to dialogue.”

109. 28 September 2022: W [warning]: US government: “There would be catastrophic, severe,

strong, profound implications for Russia” if it used nuclear weapons.

110. 30 September 2022: RU [escalatory]: Putin: Washington “created a precedent” by using

nuclear weapons during World War II.

111. October 2022: W [warning]: US, UK, and France warned Russia that they would retaliate with conventional weapons if Moscow decided to use nuclear weapons in Ukraine.

112. 4 October 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Peskov: Dismisses allegations that Russia would use

nuclear weapons, blaming the West for engaging in “exercises in nuclear rhetoric.”

113. 6 October 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Antonov: NATO has an “ill sense of fear in the context of [Russia’s] possession of nuclear weapons.” Zakharova: A nuclear war “should never be un- leashed” and Russian statements are “turned inside out” by Western “hints” from politicians

and spies.

114. 6 October 2022: W [warning]: Biden: Putin is “not joking” and Washington faces the “pro- spect of Armageddon,” hence needing to find an “off ramp.”

115. 7 October 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Various US institutions underline that there are no signs of an imminent nuclear threat – it is “not probable” that Russia would use nuclear

weapons.

116. 11 October 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Biden: Does not think that Putin would use nuclear weapons, but it is “irresponsible for [Russia’s leader] to talk about it.”

117. 11 October 2022: W [warning]: G7: “Any use of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons by

Russia would be met with severe consequences.”

118. 11 October 2022: W [warning]: Stoltenberg: The Steadfast Noon exercise will go ahead as NATO's military strength “is the best way to prevent escalation.”

119. 12 October 2022: RU [warning]: Peskov: Criticizes Biden for his Armageddon comment – engaging in “nuclear rhetoric” is a “harmful and provocative practice.”

120. 12 October 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Austin: US does not see any indicators that Russia is changing its nuclear posture towards moving ahead with a nuclear strike.

121. 12 October 2022: W [warning]: A NATO official: A Russian nuclear strike would change the

course of the conflict and “almost certainly be drawing a physical response from many allies, and potentially from NATO itself.”

122. 13 October 2022: W [warning]: Stoltenberg: “Any use of a smaller nuclear weapon will be a very serious thing, fundamentally changing the nature of the war in Ukraine, and of course

that would have consequences.”

123. 13 October 2022: W [warning]: Borell: “Any nuclear attack against Ukraine will create an answer, not a nuclear answer but such a powerful answer from the military side that the Rus- sian army will be annihilated.”

124. 14 October 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Neither Americans nor Europeans want to die

for Ukraine in “a nuclear apocalypse;” they would respond to a Russian nuclear use in a “care- ful and balanced” manner.

125. 14 October 2022: RU [warning]: Venediktov: Ukraine joining NATO “would mean a guaran-

teed escalation to World War Three,” which would be “suicidal” for existing NATO members.

126. 14 October 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Macron: France would “evidently” not use nuclear

weapons in response to a Russian nuclear attack on Ukraine.

127. 16 October 2022: W [warning]: Sullivan: The seriousness of nuclear weapons use does not

depend on the size of the weapon, meaning that tactical weapons use in Ukraine would be a serious matter.

128. 17 October 2022: W [warning]: NATO commences its Steadfast Noon nuclear exercise as planned.

129. 18 October 2022: RU [warning]: Peskov: The four annexed provinces “are inalienable parts of the Russian Federation and they are all protected. Their security is provided for at the

same level as [it is for] the rest of Russia’s territory.”

130. 18 October 2022: W [warning]: Stoltenberg: Medvedev “is not right” to claim that there

would be no serious NATO response to nuclear weapons use. “We have stated clearly that there will be severe consequences.”

131. 20 October 2022: W [warning]: Blinken: Washington has been “very clear” with Putin “di- rectly and privately” about the “severe consequences” that would follow any nuclear use.

132. 23 October 2022: RU [escalatory]: Shoigu: Claims that Ukraine could escalate the conflict with a dirty bomb and calls his US, British, and French counterparts to repeat this message.

133. 23-24 October 2022: W [warning]: Austin and Wallace: Warn Shoigu not to use such allega- tions as a pretext for further Russian escalation. And: US, UK, and French foreign ministers

issue a statement, “rejecting Russia’s transparently false allegations.”

134. 24 October 2022: RU [escalatory]: Russia places forces on alert to respond to a WMD at- tack. Kirillov: Claims Kyiv is planning a false-flag dirty bomb operation. Moscow sends a letter

to the UNSC containing allegations against Ukraine.

135. 24 October 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Naryshkin: It is “absolutely not” possible that Russia

would use nuclear weapons in Ukraine.

136. 24 October 2022: W [warning]: Price: Expresses concern over “mirror imaging,” and under-

lines that the Administration has been “very clear” about the “severe consequences” of nu-

clear use.

137. 24 October 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Various US officials: There are no indications Russia is preparing to use WMD.

138. 25 October 2022: W [warning]: Biden: “Russia would be making an incredibly serious mis- take for it to use a tactical nuclear weapon.” Austin rejects “pretexts” for Russian escalation.

139. 26 October 2022: RU [warning]: Russia conducts a planned nuclear exercise. Putin: “We

know about the plans to use the so-called dirty bomb for provocations.”

140. 26 October 2022: W [warning]: Blinken: Washington has “communicated directly and very clearly” the “consequences” of using nuclear weapons.

141. 27 October 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Putin: Ukraine is preparing a false flag attack with a radioactive bomb, but “there is no sense in [using nuclear weapons] for us, neither political, nor military.” Moscow has “never said anything proactively about Russia potentially using

nuclear weapons.”

142. 27 October 2022: W [warning]: Biden: If Putin has “no intention” to use nuclear weapons, “why does he keep talking” about “the ability to use a tactical nuclear weapon.” Putin has

“been very dangerous in how he’s approached” the nuclear question.

143. 30 October 2022: RU [warning]: Lavrov: The current situation bears similarity with the Cu-

ban missile crisis. “This situation is very disturbing.” Russia does not see readiness from

Western leaders to “show responsibility.”

144. 31 October 2022: W [warning]: Cleverly: Nuclear use would “change the nature of the con- flict” and imply “severe consequences for Russia.” The dirty bomb claims are “absurd.”

145. 2 November 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Kirby: Administration has “grown increasingly con-

cerned about the potential” that Putin might use a nuclear weapons, but there are still no con- crete indications.

146. 2 November 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Russian Foreign Ministry: Russia’s doctrine man-

dates only “defensive goals” and does not permit an “expansive interpretation.”

147. 3 November 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Kelin: Russia will not use nuclear weapons in Ukraine, they are designed for other purposes. Peskov: Moscow would abide by its doctrine.

148. 4 November 2022: W [warning]: G7: “Any use of chemical, biological, or nuclear weapons

by Russia would be met with severe consequences.”

149. 4 November 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Russia’s has to stop the devil and is fighting

“Nazis,” but it has various weapons and could “send all enemies” to hell, though this is “not”

its task.

150. 14 November 2022: W [warning]: Bruns warned Naryshkin that there would be “serious consequences” if Russia “ever” chose to use nuclear weapons of “any kind.”

151. 17 November 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Peskov: “No one” in Russia “has ever speculated

on the issue” of using nuclear weapons, as “such matters” were “unacceptable per se.”

152. 30 November 2022: RU [warning]: Shoigu: Russia will invest in nuclear infrastructure.

Lavrov: Even conventional clash between nuclear powers has to be avoided, as “escalation may become uncontrollable.”

153. 1 December 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Blinken: Administration still fears nuclear use, espe- cially in an emergency for Russia, and does not want to expand the conflict, does not want a “war with Russia” or a “third world war.”

154. 3 December 2022: W [warning]: Nuland: “When we explained what the price would be for Russia, Putin decided to do something different,” namely to attack Ukraine’s energy infra-

structure.

155. 3 December 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Zakharova: “Nuclear Armageddon” has not hap-

pened not because of US “tough warnings,” but because “no one on this side of the border was planning it.”

156. 7 December 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: Warns of the “growing” threat of nuclear war, but emphasizes that he has “not gone crazy” and would not “brandish these weapons like a razor, running around the world.”

157. 7 December 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Price: “Any loose talk of nuclear weapons is abso-

lutely irresponsible.”

158. 7 December 2022: W [warning]: Stoltenberg: Moscow’s nuclear rhetoric during the autumn

“increased concerns” among NATO allies, but “Russia must know that any use of nuclear weapons would totally change the character, the nature, of the conflict.”

159. 8 December 2022: RU [de-escalatory]: Antonov: “Russia takes seriously its special respon- sibility as a leading nuclear power,” and its statements are merely “classic deterrence in ex- treme geopolitical circumstances.”

160. 9 December 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: It is worth thinking about developing nuclear dis-

arming first-strike options, as the United States is already doing.

161. 9 December 2022: W [de-escalatory]: Austin: Repeats that Putin’s rhetoric is irresponsible, but does not engage in own warnings.

162. 10 December 2022: RU [warning]: Gavrilov: Washington green lighting Ukrainian strikes against Russian territory is “playing with fire, risking a full-scale war which could easily go

nuclear.”

163. 13 December 2022: W [warning]: Smith: The Administration will “continue to signal to Russia” that any nuclear use in Ukraine would produce “unprecedented consequences.”

164. 18 December 2022: W [warning]: Burns: The Administration has “made very clear […] what the serious risks of [nuclear use against Ukraine] would be.”

165. 19 December 2022: RU [warning]: Putin: The Belarusian air-force will receive training to use nuclear-capable airplanes, a change in Russia’s approach to military cooperation.

166. 25 December 2022: RU [warning]: Medvedev: “The only thing” that stopped the West from

directly engaging in the war against Russia was nuclear deterrence.

167. 27 December 2022: RU [de-escalating]: Lavrov: “We have repeated again and again that

there can be no winners in a nuclear war, and it should never be unleashed.”

168. 19 January 2023: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Russia’s defeat could “trigger a nuclear war.”

169. 2 February 2023: RU [warning]: Putin: Russia has “the means” to respond to Western tanks

deliveries, and its response will not end with the use of armor, all have to understand.

170. 4 February 2023: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Strikes on Crimea could be responded with

“anything” and “all types of weapons” – no “restrictions” in Russia’s nuclear doctrine.

171. 21 February 2023: RU [warning]: Putin: If US transforms the local conflict into a global con-

frontation, Russia would “react accordingly” to defend its “existence.”

172. 22 February 2023: RU [warning]: Medvedev: If US wants to defeat Russia, it should expect

retaliation with “any weapon, including nuclear weapons.”

173. 28 Februa ry 2023: W [warning]: Kahl: Any use in Ukraine, on “any scale” would be consid- ered a world changing event, bringing about “severe consequences far in excess of anything

the Russians have experienced to date.”

174. 2 March 2023: RU [warning]: Ryabkov: US and NATO are “fueling the conflict” and “increas- ing involvement” could lead to “clash of nuclear powers” with “catastrophic consequences.”

175. 21 March 2023: RU [de-escalatory]: Russia and China reaffirm that “a nuclear war cannot

be won and should not be fought.”

176. 21 March 2023: RU [warning]: Shoigu: There are “fewer and fewer steps” before “nuclear collision;” Putin: Russia would “respond accordingly” as the West was “already” using “weap-

ons with a nuclear component.”

177. 22 March 2023: RU [warning]: Ryabkov: Nuclear conflict risk is “higher than anything we have had for the past few decades” as Moscow in a “de-facto” open conflict with Washington.

178. 23 March 2023: RU [escalatory]: Medvedev: “Every day when they provide Ukraine with foreign weapons brings the nuclear apocalypse closer;” if Putin were arrested in Germany, nuclear weapons will “fly to hit the Bundestag, the chancellor’s office and so on.”

179. 24 March 2023: RU [warning]: Medvedev: If Ukraine attempts to retake Crimea, Moscow is

ready to use “absolutely any weapons,” including those mentioned in its nuclear doctrine.

180. 26 March 2023: RU [warning]: Putin: Russia would deploy delivery vehicles, finish con- structing storage sites, and potentially station nuclear weapons in Belarus by summer 2023.

181. 28 March 2023: RU [warning]: Patrushev: US believed it could launch a first strike, but this

was “very dangerous” and a “short-sighted stupidity,” as Russia had “unique modern weap- ons capable of destroying any adversary.”

182. 29 March 2023: RU [warning]: Ryabkov: The West ignored Russia’s “serious signals,” forc-

ing Moscow into “an entire range of measures” – ignored these additional signals was an “ir- responsible attitude.”

183. 31 March 2023: RU [warning]: Lukashenko: “Putin and I will decide and introduce here, if

necessary, strategic weapons, and they must under-stand this, the scoundrels abroad, who

today are trying to blow us up from inside and outside.”

184. 17 April 2023: W [de-escalatory]: Kahl: US would do “anything” it could to support Ukraine, but had no interest in “directly entering the conflict” and seing it escalate to WWIII.

185. 18 April 2023: W [warning]: G7: Irresponsible rhetoric and threat to deploy NW to Belarus

were “unacceptable,” and any WMD use “would be met with severe consequences.”

186. 24 April 2023: RU [warning]: Lavrov: To the UN Security Council: The world may have

reached a more dangerous situation than ever during the Cold War.

187. 25 April 2023: RU [warning]: Medvedev: World was “sick and quite probably on the verge of a new world war” – not inevitable, but growing risks of a nuclear confrontation.

188. 25 April 2023: RU [warning]: Yermakov: Most pressing nuclear threat was not first-strike incentive, curbed by New START, but nuclear escalation as a result of direct military confron-

tation between nuclear powers – a risk that was growing because of US hostile course.

189. 27 April 2023: RU [de-escalatory]: Zakharova: Russia would “do everything” to prevent a

“worst scenario,” but not at the cost of “infringing” on its “vital interests.”

190. 19 May 2023: W [warning]: G7: Russian threat to use nuclear weapon, “let alone any use of nuclear weapons” in the context of its aggression against Ukraine were “inadmissible.”

191. 22 May 2023: RU [warning]: Antonov: West should be aware of Russian response if it

“blessed” Ukrainian attacks against Crimea – strikes would be seen as attacks on Russia.

192. 24 May 2023: RU [warning]: Peskov: Western “direct and indirect” involvement in Ukraine was “no secret” and “growing” – Russia was “drawing the appropriate conclusions.”

193. 25 May 2023: RU [escalatory]: Shoigu and Lukashenko signed an agreement to store Rus- sian nuclear weapons in Belarus; Lukashenko: the relocation of nuclear weapons had begun.

194. 25 May 2023: W [warning]: Miller: The use of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons in

the conflict would be met with “severe consequences.”

195. 26 May 2023: RU [warning]: Medvedev: Russia would launch a pre-emptive strike if Ukraine got nuclear weapons - West was seriously underestimating the risk of nuclear war.

196. 27 May 2023: RU [warning]: Kelin: Russia warned that Western supplies to Ukraine risked escalating the war to a new dimension “which we do not need and we do not want.”

197. 6 June 2023: RU [warning]: Lavrov: Western F-16s can “accommodate” nuclear weapons

and supplying Ukraine with such fighter aircraft would escalate the conflict further.

198. 6 June 2023: W [de-escalatory]: Kirby: Biden had been consistent that he did not want to see the war escalate, certainly not into the nuclear realm.

199. 9 June 2023: R [warning]: Putin: Russia would start to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus after the facilities were ready on 7-8 July; with everything “going according to plan.”

200. 13 June 2023: RU [warning]: Lukashenko: the nuclear warheads Belarus received were 3 times more powerful than those dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and there would be “no hesitation” to use them “in the event of an aggression against us.”

201. 16 June 2023: RU [warning]: Putin: use of nuclear weapons was possible if Russia's territo-

rial integrity, independence and sovereignty was threatened; Russia had more nw than NATO

202. 20 June 2023: RU [warning]: Shoigu: an attack on Russian territory, incl. Crimea, with mis-

siles would mean the full involvement of the US and UK in the conflict; Russia would respond with immediate strikes on decision-making centers in Ukraine.

203. 20 June 2023: RU [de-escalatory]: Lavrov: said Biden’s statement that the threat of Russia

using tactical nuclear weapons was “real” were “verbal escapades” that had “no foundation”.

204. 25 June 2023: W [de-escalatory]: US officials: the US was not involved in the Wagner mu- tiny, Moscow should abstain from nuclear escalation; Blinken: Russian instability was of con-

cern, but US saw “no change” in Russia’s nuclear posture.

Graphic representation

Autumn & Winter 2021 – 2022: First nuclear signals


By October 2021, the US government had concluded that Moscow was planning a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and Washington was assessing how to help Kyiv organize its defense while also reducing the dangers of nuclear escalation. In an October meeting at the White House, Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, presented intelligence revealing that Russia’s government envisioned a takeo- ver of most of Ukraine. US officials thought the plan to be of “staggering audacity,” and that it could pose a direct threat to NATO’s eastern flank, or even destroy the post-World War II security architecture of Europe. Thus, US President Joe Biden determined that Putin had to be either deterred or confronted, anonymous sources told journalists in August 2022.


American policymakers saw Ukraine as a “troubled former Soviet republic with a history of corruption,” and assessed how to best organize its resistance. Washington would need to deliver “significant new weaponry” to enable the Ukrainians to defend themselves, US policymakers concluded. “Too little could guarantee a Russian victory. But too much might provoke a direct NATO conflict with nuclear-armed Russia,” reporters summarized the Administration’s quagmire. Revealingly, the article mentions no dis- cussion of a possible direct intervention. Rather, US officials saw even “significant” military deliveries as prone to lead to nuclear escalation. Milley’s notes for the October meeting at the White House encapsu- lated the US goals and dilemmas: How to “underwrite and enforce the rules-based international order” against a nuclear-armed state “without going to World War III?” To achieve this end, Washington would have to avoid a “kinetic conflict between the US military and NATO with Russia.” Also, it would have to “contain war inside the geographical boundaries of Ukraine.” And finally, the United States and its allies would have to “empower Ukraine” and give it the “means to fight.”


Throughout the winter, the US government deployed additional forces to Europe and sent arms to

Ukraine. And yet, the “overriding White House concern about provocation influenced each decision about how much assistance and what kind of weapons to give the Ukrainians to defend themselves,” Washington Post journalists were later told. “I make no apologies for the fact that one of our objectives here is to avoid direct conflict with Russia,” Jake Sullivan, the US National Security Advisor, said of the prewar period. However, determining what Russia would interpret as provocative had been “more art

than science,” a US official later explained to journalists. “There has always been a balance between what is required to effectively defend, and what is going to be seen by Russia as the United States essentially underwriting the killing of huge numbers of Russians.”5


By mid-October 2021, the preponderance of intelligence persuaded most within the US government that Russia was going to invade Ukraine. American military analysts had acquired sufficient intelligence to show that Russia’s actions were incompatible with any other course of action – a conclusion that emerged clearly from the many interviews published on February 24, 2023 with respect to US intelli- gence assessments prior to Russia’s invasion.6


It later emerged that Burns was sent to Moscow in early November 2021 to “lay out in an unusual amount of detail exactly why we were concerned that Putin was preparing for a major new invasion, and then to be very clear about what the consequences would be should Putin choose to execute that plan,” the CIA director told reporters for a February 24, 2023 article. Burns noticed Putin’s “cockiness about


5 Shane Harris et al., “Road to war: As Putin prepared his invasion, the U.S. struggled to convince allies — and Zelensky — of the

danger,” The Washington Post, August 16, 2022 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/interactive/2022/ukraine- road-to-war/].


6 Erin Banco et al, “‘Something Was Badly Wrong’: When Washington Realized Russia Was Actually Invading Ukraine,” Politico, February 24, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2023/02/24/russia-ukraine-war-oral-history-00083757].

Russia’s ability to enforce its will on Ukraine,” but “at least one or two of them were a little bit surprised with what I laid out to them because the circle of advisers had gotten so small.” Also, Burns returned to Washington “with a very strong impression that Putin had just about made up his mind to go to war.”

The CIA director believed that the decision was based on Putin’s “own fixation on controlling Ukraine,” as he “was convincing himself that strategically the window was closing on his opportunity to control Ukraine.” Burns: “His conviction was that without controlling Ukraine and its choices, it’s not possible

for Russia to be a great power and have this sphere of influence that he believes is essential. And it’s not possible for him to be a great Russian leader without accomplishing that.” Putin let Burns know that “tactically” he saw the ’21-’22 winter as a “favorable landscape,” with the Europeans “distracted” and “quite skeptical” of the US reaction. Back in Washington, the Administration debated “how much sup- port was required,” as it did not want to “inadvertently speed up the Russian clock, incentivize Putin, or give him a pretext to make a decision he had not made.” The US government “leaning too far forward could create dynamics either within the alliance or as we were trying to build world opinion against the Russians that made us look like we were the provocateurs,” Colin Kahl, the Under-Secretary of Defense for Policy, later told journalists.7


More than a year later, US officials outlined their thinking with respect to sanctions in the months pre- ceding Russia’s invasion. For a February 24, 2023 article, Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo told reporters that Biden had made clear that the Administration was going to use sanctions to both “hold Russia accountable” and deter by making clear what Washington would do. US officials believed that Russia thought all the West could marshal was an “off-the-shelf” package. The US government had a five-pronged strategy: (1) sanction Russia’s banking system; (2) limit its access to cutting-edge technol- ogy; (3) diminish its energy exports while also keeping steady global supplies of oil; (4) seize the physi- cal assets of the kleptocracy to demonstrate to the Russian people that they were duped; and (5) “me- thodically eject Russia from the international economic order,” explained Daleep Singh, deputy NSA for international economics.8


In turn, the Russian leadership sought to leverage uncertainty in its reactions to deter further Western involvement. Speaking to an online investment forum, Vladimir Putin, Russia’s President, warned NATO on November 30, 2021 against deploying troops and weapons to Ukraine, saying this would rep- resent a “red line” for Moscow and would trigger a strong response. The Alliance’s eastward expansion had already threatened Russia’s core security interests, Putin said, and NATO could use Ukraine’s terri- tory to deploy missiles capable of reaching Moscow within five minutes. Russia had therefore been forced to counter these growing threats by developing new hypersonic weapons, arms that would soon enter service.9


Also, Russian officials started to suggest that a direct confrontation between Russia and NATO could be- come a reality. On December 2, Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told the OSCE that the strategic stabil- ity architecture was “rapidly being destroyed” and NATO was refusing to “constructively examine” Rus- sia’s proposals to “deescalate tensions and avoid dangerous incidents.” The Alliance’s “military


7 Erin Banco et al, “‘Something Was Badly Wrong’: When Washington Realized Russia Was Actually Invading Ukraine,” Politico, February 24, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2023/02/24/russia-ukraine-war-oral-history-00083757].


8 Erin Banco et al, “‘Something Was Badly Wrong’: When Washington Realized Russia Was Actually Invading Ukraine,” Politico, February 24, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2023/02/24/russia-ukraine-war-oral-history-00083757].


9 Vladimir Isachenkov, “Putin warns West: Moscow has ‘red line’ about Ukraine, NATO,” AP News, November 30, 2021 [https://ap- news.com/article/europe-russia-ukraine-vladimir-putin-moscow-cd558699728e9ae935eaadf940efeb18], and “Russia Calling!

Investment Forum,” Website of the President of Russia, November 30, 2021 [http://en.kremlin.ru/events/president/tran- scripts/67241].

infrastructure” was drawing closer to Russia’s borders and the “nightmare scenario of military confron- tation” was returning.10 No one should doubt Russia would defend its security interests, Russia’s ambas- sador to the United States, Anatoly Antonov wrote in a US outlet on December 30. If NATO kept “con- structing military-strategic realities imperiling the existence of our country,” Russia would be forced to “create similar vulnerabilities for them.” The “military exploration” of Ukraine by NATO was “an existen- tial threat” for Russia, and “urgent action” was needed, Antonov noted ominously.11


In February 2023, US officials revealed some of the diplomatic steps they had taken in January 2022. For a February 24, 2023 article, Michael Carpenter, the US ambassador to the OSCE in Vienna, told journalists that, together with the Polish OSCE chairperson, they had sought to engage Russia on its

grievances at the beginning of January 2022 within a renewed European Security Dialogue. “Russia basi- cally refused to engage, and that’s when it became increasingly clear the Kremlin really had no interest in diplomacy all along. It was bent on war,” Carpenter said.12


As war became more probable, the US government issued a series of public and private warnings. For instance, in a news conference on January 19, Biden said that Russia had in fact already decided to in- vade Ukraine. The US President also offered a forceful warning. Such an attack would be “a disaster for Russia” as US allies and partners were “ready to impose severe costs and significant harm on Russia and the Russian economy.” Russia would be “held accountable” if it invaded. Yet the US President also sug- gested that a “minor incursion” might not prompt a severe response, signaling that there were disagree- ments within NATO on what to do with respect to various levels of Russian aggression.13 The next day, January 20, the White House sought to walk back the President’s caveat. He had been “absolutely clear” with Putin. “Any assembled Russian units move across the Ukrainian border, that is an invasion” for which Russia would pay a “heavy price.”14


In February 2023, US officials outlined some of the diplomatic efforts made just before Russia’s invasion.

For a February 24, 2023 article, Mark Milley told journalists that there had been “a lot of effort” by Aus-

tin, Blinken, Sullivan, Biden, and himself to “try to dissuade Russia from doing this and to warn them if

they did it these will be likely consequences.” US ambassador to the UN Linda Thomas-Greenfield con-

cluded that Russia’s envoy to New York, Vasily Nebenzya, was simply unaware of what was actually hap-

pening. Burns said that the Administration’s consensus has been that “the basic decision to invade and a

lot of the planning was in a circle of probably no more than three or four people around Putin.” Sullivan

noted that the Administration was baffled by Russian behavior – all evidence was pointing towards war,

but the IC was “overwhelmingly” in agreement that this was “a crazy thing to do.” Hence, there was an


10 “Russia to unveil security pact proposals in bid to restrain NATO,” Reuters, December 2, 2021 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/russia-unveil-proposals-new-european-security-pact-soon-lavrov-2021-12-02/].


11 Anatoly Antonov, “An Existential Threat to Europe’s Security Architecture?,” Foreign Policy, December 30, 2021 [https://for- eignpolicy.com/2021/12/30/russia-ukraine-nato-threat-security/].


12 Erin Banco et al, “‘Something Was Badly Wrong’: When Washington Realized Russia Was Actually Invading Ukraine,” Politico, February 24, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2023/02/24/russia-ukraine-war-oral-history-00083757].


13 “Remarks by President Biden in Press Conference,” Website of the White House, January 19, 2021 [https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2022/01/19/remarks-by-president-biden-in-press-conference- 6/].


14 Molly Nagle, “Biden clarifies comments on Ukraine, says any Russian move across border would be an ‘invasion,’” ABC News, January 20, 2022 [https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/biden-clarifies-comments-ukraine-russian-move-border-inva- sion/story?id=82376647].

element of “what the hell are you guys doing.” Derek Chollet, the State Department counselor, noted

that Washington could not “control others if they choose to do incredibly stupid things.”15


On January 21, US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken met Lavrov in Geneva, and again cautioned against invasion. Reportedly, the US official told his Russian counterpart that, in response to an invasion, Western sanctions would be fast and merciless, isolating Russia and crippling its economy. Also, Blinken reportedly said that NATO would provide Ukraine with massive military assistance. “If one Russian sol- dier or missile touched one inch of NATO territory, the United States would defend its allies,” the Wash- ington Post later reported on the meeting. Blinken found Lavrov’s response “strident and unyielding.”16 During the subsequent press conference, Blinken said that a Russian invasion would be met with “swift, severe, and a united response” from the United States and its “partners and allies.”17


1.

Warning

A month before the invasion, the Russian leadership started to bring its nuclear arsenal into the polit- ical narrative, already suggesting an expansive interpretation of the official doctrine. Dmitry Medvedev, the Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council and a former president and prime minister, stated in an interview on January 27, that there was no need to review Russia’s nuclear

doctrine. Moscow had “the right” to use strategic nuclear forces “in response to an attack involving weapons of mass destruction against us or our allies and in response to any other threat to our coun- try’s existence, in other words, to a danger that threatens the very existence of our state.” This was “a

comprehensive formula” that made it “possible to achieve various goals,” Medvedev said.18


On the same January 27, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi told Blinken that “regional security should not be guaranteed by strengthening or even expanding military blocs.” Actors should create a “balanced, effective and sustainable European security mechanism through negotiations, with Russia's legitimate security concerns being taken seriously and addressed.”19


At the end of January 2022, Putin’s top economic advisors warned against the consequences of Western sanctions if war broke out. At the President’s residence outside Moscow, Herman Gref, the CEO of Sberbank and one of the most liberal members of Putin’s extended circle, gave a presentation that had been worked by those present, including by Elvira Nabiullina, the central bank governor.

Harsh sanctions would set Russia’s economy back decades. GDP could fall by a third within two years. Real incomes could be cut by a fifth. Russians’ quality of life would lag behind even developing countries as restrictions on imports would make Russia struggle not only to find advanced technologies, but es- sentials such as medicines and food, the economic advisors noted. However, Putin cut Gref off and asked him what Russia should do to avoid the worst of the sanctions.20


15 Erin Banco et al, “‘Something Was Badly Wrong’: When Washington Realized Russia Was Actually Invading Ukraine,” Politico, February 24, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2023/02/24/russia-ukraine-war-oral-history-00083757].


16 Shane Harris et al, “Road to war: As Putin prepared his invasion, the U.S. struggled to convince allies — and Zelensky — of the

danger,” The Washington Post, August 16, 2022 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/interactive/2022/ukraine- road-to-war/].


17 Jeremy Herb, Veronica Stracqualursi and Vasco Cotovio, “Blinken warns any Russian ‘invasion’ of Ukraine would be met with a ‘severe and a united response’ following Lavrov meeting,” CNN, January 21, 2022 [https://edition.cnn.com/2022/01/21/poli- tics/blinken-lavrov-geneva-meeting-ukraine/index.html].


18 “Medvedev sees no need to review Russia’s nuclear doctrine,” TASS, January 27, 2022 [https://tass.com/politics/1393713].


19 “Wang Yi Speaks with U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on the Phone at Request,” Website of the Chinese MFA, January 27, 2022 [https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/topics_665678/kjgzbdfyyq/202201/t20220127_10635268.html].


20 Max Seddon and Polina Ivanova, “How Putin’s technocrats saved the economy to fight a war they opposed,” Financial Times, December 16, 2022 [https://www.ft.com/content/fe5fe0ed-e5d4-474e-bb5a-10c9657285d2].

February 2022: The high-time of nuclear threat-making



2.

Escalatory

Ten days later, Putin continued developing the nuclear narrative. On February 7, the Russian Presi- dent implied at a joint press conference with French President Emanuel Macron during the latter’s visit to Moscow that Ukraine could drag NATO into a nuclear war. If Ukraine joined NATO and de- cided to take back Crimea through military means, European countries would be automatically drawn into a military conflict with Russia, Putin said. The Kremlin understood that “NATO’s united potential” was incomparably larger than that of Russia, but Russia was “one of the world’s leading nuclear pow- ers” and was “superior” to “many” NATO countries “in terms of the number of modern nuclear force components.” Putin claimed that neither he nor Macron wanted to see developments “unfold” that

way.21


3.

Warning

On February 19, sitting alongside Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko, Putin oversaw an an-

nual “strategic nuclear exercise,” usually held in fall. Russian forces tested nuclear-capable air-, sea-, and land-based ballistic and cruise missiles.22


4.

Warning

In a televised address on February 21, Putin accused Ukraine of seeking to acquire nuclear weapons and stated that the possibility of “foreign technological support” could not be ruled out.23 On Febru- ary 22, he sought to clarify his earlier statement, stating that tactical nuclear weapons in Ukraine

would be a “strategic threat” to Russia.24


In parallel, also on February 21, Moscow recognized the Ukrainian separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent states. The European Union as well as the United States and several other coun- tries responded by announcing a first wave of economic sanctions against Russia.25 Against this back- ground, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz suspended the certification process for the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline.26 On February 23, US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, after a meeting with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba, stressed that Washington would continue to deliver weap- ons to Ukraine even if Russia expanded its invasion, and would continue to support Kyiv with US Javelin anti-tank systems as well as other measures. The State Department’s Ned Price had earlier stated that aid to Ukraine “would be accelerated in the event of additional Russian aggression.” Since 2014, the


21 “News conference following Russian-French talks,” Website of the President of Russia, February 8, 2022 [http://en.krem- lin.ru/events/president/news/67735].


22 “Учение сил стратегического сдерживания (Strategic deterrence exercise),” Website of the President of Russia, February 19, 2022 [http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/67814], and Tom Balmforth and Maria Kiselyova, “Putin leads sweeping nuclear exercises as tensions soar,” Reuters, February 19, 2022

[https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/putin-starts-russias-strategic-nuclear-exercises-tensions-soar-2022-02-19/].


23 “Address by the President of the Russian Federation,” Website of the President of Russia, February 21, 2022 [http://en.krem- lin.ru/events/president/news/67828].


24 “Vladimir Putin answered media questions,” Website of the President of Russia, February 22, 2022 [http://en.krem- lin.ru/events/president/news/67838].


25 A great resource for all information related to Western sanctions on Russia during its war of aggression against Ukraine is: Chad

P. Brown, “Russia’s war on Ukraine: A sanctions timeline,” PIIE [https://www.piie.com/blogs/realtime-economic-issues- watch/russias-war-ukraine-sanctions-timeline].


26 Melissa Eddy, “Germany puts a stop to Nord Stream 2, a key Russian natural gas pipeline,” The New York Times, February 22, 2022 [https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/22/business/nord-stream-pipeline-germany-russia.html].

United States had committed more than 2.7 billion US dollars in security assistance to build the capacity of Ukraine’s forces, including more than 650 million US dollars in 2021.27


In February 2023, reporters unearthed some of the dynamics taking place in Russia just before the inva- sion. In 2014, Russian officials had urged Putin not to send troops into Crimea. He had made the choice alone. When the West, fearful of escalation and of endangering European economic ties to Russia, had responded with mild sanctions, Putin had become convinced that he had made the right decision, ac- cording to his officials. During the subsequent pandemic, Putin had become more and more isolated, with few links to more liberal advisers and increasingly fixated on Russia’s greatness. “He really believes all the stuff he says about sacrality and Peter the Great. He thinks he will be remembered like Peter,” a former senior official said. Also, Putin let himself be convinced by pro-Russian politicians in Ukraine around Viktor Medvedchuk that a majority of the population would welcome an annexation campaign. Due to prevalent corruption, the FSB confirmed Medvedchuk’s assessment. At a February 21 meeting of the Russian Security Council, even Nikolai Patrushev had suggested giving diplomacy another chance as military means were not as promising as they seemed. Putin was “overconfident” and overruled Patrushev. Putin had assumed a rapid and massive incursion would tumble the regime in Kyiv. Hence,

Putin had informed Lavrov of his decision merely hours before the invasion. “It’s all gone horribly wrong,” a former senior Russian official confided to reporters. Immediately after the invasion, several dozen oligarchs gathered at the Kremlin for a rushed meeting. They were aware that the invasion would trigger western sanctions that could destroy their fortunes. “Everyone was completely losing it,” a per- son who attended the meeting told the journalists.28


Some details emerged on February 24, 2023 about US preparations before Russia’s invasion. Blinken told an interviewer that Washington had been working with Kyiv to “help them see what was coming” and “make the necessary preparations,” but Zelensky had been concerned about making these prepara- tions public as this would “risk taking down his economy and foreign investment.” Blinken had shared information with Zelensky already in October 2021 that Russia would likely invade and Washington had subsequently worked with Kyiv to aid preparations – thus, US officials had been much less surprised by Ukrainian resilience than the public. The Administration could rely on intelligence providing “very ex- plicit information about what the Russians were actually thinking and what they were planning and what they were plotting to do with those forces.” With respect to Russian intentions, Blinken said the

invasion had not been about “NATO enlargement” or “some threat to Russia’s security,” but “all about

Putin’s vision that Ukraine should not be an independent country and should be absorbed back into Rus- sia.”29


During the night of February 23-24, as Russian troops were already moving into the neighboring coun- try, Putin announced a “special military operation” in Ukraine. “Irresponsible Western politicians” had created “fundamental threats” by expanding NATO eastwards and, thus, moving military infrastructure closer to Russia’s border. Any further NATO expansion or the “ongoing efforts to gain a military foot-

hold” in Ukraine were “unacceptable.” NATO was just a “tool of US foreign policy.” In “territories adja- cent to Russia,” which were “our historical land” to Putin, a hostile “anti-Russia” was taking shape. It was


27 Joe Gould, Sebastian Sprenger and Rachel S. Cohen, “Pentagon studying fallback supply lines to Ukraine ahead of expanded Rus- sian invasion,” Defense News, February 23, 2022 [https://www.defensenews.com/global/europe/2022/02/23/pentagon-study- ing-fallback-supply-lines-to-ukraine-in-case-of-expanded-russian-invasion/].


28 Max Seddon et al, “How Putin blundered into Ukraine — then doubled down,” Financial Times, February 23, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/80002564-33e8-48fb-b734-44810afb7a49].


29 Jeffrey Goldberg and Morgan Ome, “Blinken: I Understand Why Zelensky Is Demanding That the U.S. ‘Do Even More and Do It Even Faster’,” Atlantic, February 26, 2023 [https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/02/antony-blinken-ukraine-jeffrey- goldberg-zelensky/673188/].

“fully controlled from the outside” and “doing everything to attract NATO armed forces and obtain cut- ting-edge weapons.” The West had now crossed the “red line” that Russia had repeatedly mentioned. To achieve its goals, NATO was “supporting the far-right nationalists and neo-Nazis in Ukraine, those who will never forgive the people of Crimea and Sevastopol for freely making a choice to reunite with Rus-

sia.” Moscow had to take “bold and immediate action” to “defend” its people, and Putin had decided to “carry out a special military operation.” It sought to “demilitarize and denazify Ukraine, as well as bring to trial those who perpetrated numerous bloody crimes against civilians, including against citizens of the Russian Federation.”30


5.

Escalatory

Washington was pursuing a “policy of containing Russia, with obvious geopolitical dividends,” Putin added. However, NATO’s policy was for Russia “a matter of life and death.” The Western actions were “not only a very real threat” to Russia’s interests but to “the very existence” of the state and to its “sovereignty,” Putin said. Hence, he addressed “those who may be tempted to interfere in these de-

velopments from the outside,” saying that “no matter” who tried to stand in Russia’s way or “create threats for our country and our people,” had to know that “Russia will respond immediately, and the consequences will be such as you have never seen in your entire history” – what many interpreted as a veiled threat to employ nuclear weapons against those who interfered in Russia’s attempt to elimi-

nate an existential threat.31


6.

Warning

Later in the same speech, Putin also emphasized that Russia was “one of the most powerful nuclear states” and had a “certain advantage in several cutting-edge weapons.” Within this clearly nuclear context, however, the Russian President defined the preconditions for a possible nuclear strike much more narrowly: “There should be no doubt for anyone that any potential aggressor will face defeat and ominous consequences should it directly attack our country.”32 That a direct attack on Russia could be answered with nuclear weapons was consistent with both Russia’s nuclear doctrine,

adopted in 2020, and the declaratory policies of other nuclear powers.33


30 “Address by the President of the Russian Federation,” Website of the President of Russia, February 24, 2022 [http://en.krem- lin.ru/events/president/news/67843], and “Full text: Putin’s declaration of war on Ukraine,” The Spectator, February 24, 2022 [https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/full-text-putin-s-declaration-of-war-on-ukraine], and Vladimir Isachenkov et al., “Russia attacks Ukraine as defiant Putin warns US, NATO,” AP News, February 24, 2022

[https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-europe-russia-moscow-kyiv-626a8c5ec22217bacb24ece60fac4fe1].


31 “Address by the President of the Russian Federation,” Website of the President of Russia, February 24, 2022 [http://en.krem- lin.ru/events/president/news/67843], and “Full text: Putin’s declaration of war on Ukraine,” The Spectator, February 24, 2022 [https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/full-text-putin-s-declaration-of-war-on-ukraine], and Vladimir Isachenkov et al., “Russia attacks Ukraine as defiant Putin warns US, NATO,” AP News, February 24, 2022 [https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-eu- rope-russia-moscow-kyiv-626a8c5ec22217bacb24ece60fac4fe1].


32 “Full text: Putin’s declaration of war on Ukraine,” The Spectator, February 24, 2022 [https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/full-text-putin-s-declaration-of-war-on-ukraine].


33 On Russia’s doctrine, see: “Foundations of State Policy of the Russian Federation in the Area of Nuclear Deterrence,” CNA, June 4, 2020 [https://www.cna.org/archive/CNA_Files/pdf/foundations%20of%20state%20policy%20of%20the%20russian%20feder- ation%20in%20the%20area%20of%20nuclear%20deterrence.pdf, on US doctrine, see “Fact Sheet: 2022 Nuclear Posture Review and Missile Defense Review,” Website of the US Department of Defense, March 28, 2022 [https://media.de- fense.gov/2022/Mar/29/2002965339/-1/-1/1/FACT-SHEET-2022-NUCLEAR-POSTURE-REVIEW-AND-MISSILE-DEFENSE-RE-

VIEW.PDF], on French doctrine, see: “Speech of the President of the Republic on the Defense and Deterrence Strategy,” Website of the Élysée, February 7, 2020 [https://www.elysee.fr/en/emmanuel-macron/2020/02/07/speech-of-the-president-of-the-repub- lic-on-the-defense-and-deterrence-strategy], on UK doctrine, see: “Global Britain in

a competitive age,” Website of the UK Government, March 16, 2021 [https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/up- loads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/975077/Global_Britain_in_a_Competitive_Age-_the_Integrated_Review_of_Secu-

rity Defence Development_and_Foreign_Policy.pdf], and on China’s doctrine, see: Gerald C. Brown, “Understanding the Risks and Realities of China’s Nuclear Forces,” Arms Control Today, June, 2021 [https://www.armscontrol.org/act/2021-06/features/un- derstanding-risks-realities-chinas-nuclear-forces#endnote3].

7.

De-escalatory

Representatives of NATO countries strongly condemned the Russian invasion.
