898 Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon “Why Tanks Are Tripping Up the West,” New York Times, January 19, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/01/19/world/europe/tanks-ukraine-germany-us.html].


899 Stefan Kornelius, “Die USA sind wütend auf Scholz (The United States are angry at Scholz),” Süddeutsche Zeitung, January 22, 2023 [https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/kampfpanzer-usa-bundeskanzler-scholz-1.5736789?reduced=true].

Ukraine Defense Contact Group at Ramstein, still no decision could be reached on sending Leopard 2 main battle tanks to Ukraine, despite pleas from President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to do so. Yet, German and US officials sought to downplay the disagreements and several countries promised to send more military aid. For instance, the US government pledged to send a package worth around 2.5 billion US Dollars, including 90 Stryker combat vehicles.900


Pressure continued to build up on the German Chancellory. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, who was in Kyiv on January 20, urged Germany to deliver the tanks.901 Polish Foreign Minister Zbigniew Rau tweeted that arming Ukraine was not “some kind of decision-making exercise” and that Ukraine paid a price in blood because of the hesitation over Leopard deliveries.902 On January 21, the foreign ministers of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania called on Germany to deliver Leopards to Ukraine.903 Baerbock said on January 22 that she would not “stand in the way” of Poland sending Leopard tanks to Ukraine. In Washington, the new Republican chairman of the US House Foreign Affairs Committee, Mi- chael McCaul, argued publicly that the Administration should send at least one M1 Abrams to Ukraine to persuade Germany to greenlight the Leopards. In Warsaw, Morawiecki told reporters on January 23 that Poland would ask Germany for permission to send Leopards to Ukraine but suggested that his gov- ernment would deliver them with or without Germany’s approval – thereby restating a claim he had al- ready made on January 18. On the same January 23, Sullivan and Plötner spoke three times over the phone, and Sullivan, Austin and Milley met Biden at the White House to get final negotiating guid- ance.904 Pistorius meanwhile told journalists in Berlin that a decision would come “soon.”905 On Janu- ary 24, Poland formally asked Germany for permission to transfer its Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine – Ber- lin retorted that a decision would indeed come “soon.”906


Throughout the entire tank episode, Russian officials sought to dissuade the West, and especially Ger- many, from delivering the tanks to Ukraine. On January 19, Peskov said in Moscow that it would be “ex- tremely dangerous” for Germany to supply tanks. “It will mean bringing the conflict to a whole new level which, of course, will not bode well from the point of view of global and pan-European security,” he told reporters.907


900 Erika Solomon and Cassandra Vinograd, “A meeting of Ukraine’s allies ends with no consensus on sending Kyiv Western tanks,” The New York Times, January 20, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/01/20/world/russia-ukraine-news/a-meeting-of- ukraine-allies-ends-with-no-consensus-on-sending-german-tanks?smid=url-share].


901 Cassandra Vinograd, “Amid Mounting Frustration With Germany, Ukraine Holds Out Hope It Will Get Tanks,” The New York Times, January 21, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/21/world/europe/ukraine-germany-leopard-tanks.html].

903 “Baltische Außenminister drängen auf sofortige Leopard-Panzerlieferung aus Deutschland (Baltic foreign ministers urge imme- diate Leopard tank delivery from Germany),” Spiegel, January 21, 2023 [https://www.spiegel.de/ausland/ukraine-krieg-baltische- aussenminister-draengen-auf-sofortige-leopard-panzerlieferung-aus-deutschland-a-26335832-3d46-49ab-a101-3d0a3f31aa5b].


904 James Politi, Courtney Weaver, Laura Pitel and Guy Chazan, “Transatlantic ‘growing pains’: how Olaf Scholz made Joe Biden shift on tanks for Ukraine,” Financial Times, January 26, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/ea1cd074-c912-4dd7-9977- 72ac41da0a52].


905 Ron DePasquale, “Poland says permission from Germany is ‘a secondary issue’ with Leopard tanks,” New York Times, January 23, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/01/23/world/russia-ukraine-news/poland-steps-in-as-pressure-grows-on-ger- many-to-supply-leopard-tanks?smid=url-share].


906 Matthew Mpoke Bigg, “Poland asks Germany’s permission to send its Leopard tanks to Ukraine,” New York Times, January 24, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/24/world/europe/germany-ukraine-tanks.html].


907 “‘A whole new level’ of war if NATO arms Ukraine, Russia warns,” Al Jazeera, January 19, 2023 [https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/1/19/a-whole-new-level-of-war-if-nato-arms-ukraine-russia-warns].

168.

Warning

On the same January 19, nuclear rhetoric returned to Moscow. Medvedev warned NATO that Rus- sia’s defeat in Ukraine could trigger a nuclear war. “The defeat of a nuclear power in a conventional war may trigger a nuclear war,” Medvedev wrote on Telegram. “Nuclear powers have never lost ma- jor conflicts on which their fate depends,” he concluded. Asked if Medvedev’s remarks signified that Russia was escalating the crisis, Peskov said: “No, it absolutely does not mean that.” Peskov said Medvedev’s remarks were in full accordance with Russia’s nuclear doctrine, as it allowed for a nu- clear strike after “aggression against the Russian Federation with conventional weapons when the

very existence of the state is threatened.”908


On January 22, Vyacheslav Volodin, the chairman of Russia’s lower house, the State Duma, threatened Europe and the United States with “global catastrophe” over their continued military support for

Ukraine. Additional arms deliveries would lead to retaliation with “more powerful weapons,” he stated. Nuclear powers had not used WMD in local conflicts in the past because their citizens and territorial in- tegrity had not been threatened. Foreign politicians had to understand that “this could end in a global tragedy that will destroy their countries.”909 The pressure Germany was facing showed “nervousness” among Ukraine’s allies, Peskov said on January 23. But the Ukrainian people would ultimately have to “pay” for this “pseudo-support.”910 The next day, Peskov added that Leopard deliveries would “not bode well” for and leave “an indelible mark” on Russian-German relations, which were already “at a low point.”911 In Washington, Antonov told reporters on January 25 that the Biden Administration was “de- liberately trying to inflict strategic defeat” on Russia. “If the United States decides to supply tanks, it will be impossible to justify such step using arguments about defensive weapons. This would be another bla- tant provocation against the Russian Federation. No one should have illusions about who is the real ag- gressor in the current conflict.”912


On January 25, the tank debate came to a first conclusion. Germany agreed to send Ukraine 14 Leopard 2 tanks from the Bundeswehr, mere hours before the United States pledged to send 31 M1 Abrams tanks.913 Earlier in the day, Biden and Scholz had spoken over the phone to coordinate the announce- ment. The US President also called Sunak, Macron, and Meloni. This was “not an offensive threat to Russia,” Biden emphasized during the announcement at the White House. “If Russian troops return to Russia, where they belong, this war would be over today.”914


908 Guy Faulconbridge and Felix Light, “Putin ally Medvedev warns NATO of nuclear war if Russia is defeated in Ukraine,” Reuters, January 19, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/putin-ally-medvedev-warns-nuclear-war-if-russia-defeated-ukraine- 2023-01-19/].

909 Carlo Martuscelli, “Top Russia official threatens West with ‘global catastrophe’ over weapons to Ukraine,” Politico, January 23, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/top-russia-official-vyacheslav-volodin-threatens-west-with-global-catastrophe-over- weapons-to-ukraine-war/].


910 “Песков заявил, что все накачивающие Киев вооружениями страны несут за это ответственность (Peskov said that all

countries pumping weapons into Kiev are responsible),” Tass, January 23, 2023 [https://tass.ru/politika/16861059].


911 Elena Teslova, “Kremlin says export of Leopard tanks to Ukraine will leave 'indelible mark' on Russian-German relations,” Anadolu, January 24, 2023 [https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/kremlin-says-export-of-leopard-tanks-to-ukraine-will-leave-indel- ible-mark-on-russian-german-relations/2796030].


912 “Ambassador Anatoly Antonov’s answer to a media question,” Facebook Page of the Embassy of Russia in the USA, January 25, 2023 [https://www.facebook.com/RusEmbUSA/posts/pfbid0rJY8bKeeJGMFRVqHvAmXEJtthUVRm7rvatqnYR5w4VBn- ZhQGxZCKwF7Z7Yd4Gzywl]


913 Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze, “Germany says it will send an initial shipment of 14 tanks to Ukraine,” The New York Times, January 25, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/01/25/world/russia-ukraine-news/germany-leopard-tanks- ukraine?smid=url-share].


914 Peter Baker, “Biden announces 31 Abrams tanks for Ukraine, but says the move is not meant to escalate the war,” The New York Times, January 25, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/01/25/world/russia-ukraine-news/biden-announces-31-abrams-

The Russian reaction was swift. The Russian ambassador in Berlin, Sergei Nechayev said that Ger- many’s “extremely dangerous decision” would take the conflict “to a new level of confrontation” and lead to “permanent escalation.” Also, it destroyed “the remnants of mutual trust, [caused] irreparable damage to the already deplorable state of Russian-German relations, and [casted] doubt on the possibil- ity of their normalisation in the foreseeable future.”915 In Moscow, Peskov noted that the tanks deliver- ies were a “losing scheme” that would burden Europe without strengthening the Ukrainian military.916 As Western states made public when battle tanks might arrive in Ukraine, Moscow showed its discon- tent both on the battlefield and through harsher statements. The US Administration stated that it would not send Abrams from the Pentagon’ stock, but would acquire them first – which would take months if not years.917 On January 26, UK defense minister Alex Chalk said Britain would start train- ing Ukrainian tank crews the following week, aiming to have the 14 Challenger 2 delivered by the end of March. In Berlin, Pistorius noted that Germany also planned to deliver a first company of Leopards by the end of March. In response to these developments, Peskov said that Moscow “categorically disa- greed” that Western deliveries did “not mean involvement of these countries or the alliance in the hostil- ities ongoing in Ukraine.” In contrast: “Moscow views everything that has been done by the alliance and the capitals I have mentioned as direct involvement in the conflict,” he added. On the same day, Russia also launched 55 missiles at targets across Ukraine, 47 of which were shot down. 918


Analysts within the US government still believed Ukraine had few chances to recapture Crimea. On Jan- uary 26, senior Department of Defense officials told House Armed Services Committee lawmakers in a classified briefing that the Pentagon did not believe Ukraine had the ability to force Russian troops out of Crimea. Among the briefers were Laura Cooper, the deputy assistant secretary of defense for Russia and Douglas Sims, director of operations on the Joint Staff. This assessment mirrored a statement by the Joint Chiefs chair Milley during the January 20 meeting at Ramstein that, in 2023, it remained “very, very difficult to militarily eject Russian forces” from occupied Ukraine. “That doesn’t mean it can’t hap- pen. Doesn’t mean it won’t happen, but it’d be very, very difficult.”919


Meanwhile further background on the Western debates surrounding military assistance for Ukraine trickled into media reports. A senior European diplomat provided context on the theory of escalation underlying these internal discussions: After Russia’s invasion, the Western allies had agreed on an “un- written policy,” not to supply Ukraine with a fully comprehensive package of weapons out of fear that “we would trigger a big response from Russia,” a “strong Russian reaction, including nuclear.” The West should provide its support gradually, assessing the Russian response at every step. “You may call this a


tanks-for-ukraine-but-says-the-move-is-not-meant-to-escalate-the-war?smid=url-share], and Alexander Ward et al, “Inside Wash- ington’s about-face on sending tanks to Ukraine,” Politico, January 25, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/01/25/in- side-washingtons-about-face-on-sending-tanks-to-ukraine-00079560].


915 “Russia scorns Germany for sending Leopard battle tanks to Ukraine,” Al Jazeera, January 25, 2023 [https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/1/25/russia-denounces-germany-over-dangerous-tanks-decision].


916 “Abrams tank deliveries to Kiev 'a losing scheme' for technological reasons, says Kremlin,” TASS, January 25, 2023 [https://tass.com/politics/1566775].

917 Lara Seligman, Paul McLeary, and Lee Hudson, “U.S. to send Ukraine more advanced Abrams tanks — but no secret armor,”

Politico, January 26, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/01/26/us-sends-ukraine-advanced-abrams-tanks-00079648].


918 Hanna Arhirova and Samya Kullab, “New barrage of Russian strikes in Ukraine kills at least 11,” AP News, January 27, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-417545bf8718da9dad1b3a047abf32f6].


919 Alexander Ward et al, “Ukraine can’t retake Crimea soon, Pentagon tells lawmakers in classified briefing,” Politico, February , 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/02/01/ukraine-crimea-russia-pentagon-00080799].

process of getting [Putin] accustomed,” the diplomat said. The delivery of aircraft was therefore “only a matter of when,” the diplomat predicted.920


Sources within the German Chancellery, in turn, told journalists that Scholz’s reluctance to deliver weapons without US backing was grounded in a belief that this could spur escalation. Behind closed doors, the German leader was venting against those who were arguing for tank deliveries. After Amy Gutman, the US ambassador to Germany, had said in mid-September that Washington had “big expecta- tions” from Berlin regarding weapons deliveries, Scholz had relied on scenario-analyses circulating within the Chancellery involving Russian sabotage against gas pipelines, cyber-attacks, or even nuclear use. Hence, Scholz now wanted to spread the risks by engaging the United States directly. He wanted the West to “cook the frog” (Putin) slowly and carefully in order to “avoid a global war.” In addition, elec- toral considerations also played a role, officials told journalists, with the German public divided and

fearful. In various European capitals, Scholz’ approach was seen as both German unwillingness to as-

sume responsibility and reluctance to accept a more independent European foreign policy.921


One deliveries-debate concluded, the next one commenced. On January 26, Western officials told re- porters that Washington had told Kyiv that supplying aircraft is a “no-go, for the moment.” An internal debate about supplying Ukraine with jet fighters had already been underway for a while, however, pushed by Ukrainian officials with support from Baltic states. Against this backdrop, Dutch foreign min- ister Wopke Hoekstra told the Dutch parliament on January 20 that his Cabinet would look at supply- ing F-16 fighter jets, if Kyiv requested them. “We are open-minded, there are no taboos,” he had ex- plained.922 Yet, alongside announcing that Germany would send the Leopoard-2 on January 25, Scholz ruled out providing fighter jets, citing the need to prevent further military escalation. “There will be no fighter jet deliveries to Ukraine,” he said. Deputy US national security advisor Jon Finer, in turn, said on January 26 that the Administration would be discussing fighter jets “very carefully” with Kyiv and its allies.923 “We have not ruled in or out any specific systems,” he added. However, an official at the De- fense Department told journalists the next day he did not think “we are opposed,” as a campaign inside the Pentagon to send fighter jets to Ukraine was gaining momentum.924 Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to Zelensky, said on January 28 that Kyiv and its Western allies were engaged in “fast-track” talks on possible deliveries of military aircraft and long-range missiles.925 Yet, Scholz doubled down on his skep- tical position talking to reporters on the same day. “The question of combat aircraft does not arise at all,”


920 Cristina Gallardo, “Ukraine got its tanks. Now it wants jet fighters too,” Politico, January 27, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/arti- cle/ukraine-volodymyr-zelenskyy-russia-war-after-tanks-the-west-mulls-discussion-on-fighter-jets/].


921 Markus Becker et al, “Olaf Scholz, die Panzerwende und die Angst vor der Eskalation (Olaf Scholz, the tank u-turn and the fear of escalation),” Spiegel, January 27, 2023 [https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/olaf-scholz-liefert-leopard-2-panzer-an- die-ukraine-das-letzte-tabuu-a-5972cfe4-4164-4ede-9936-c9fb33b51037], and Peter Dausend, Tina Hildebradt and Jörg Lau, “Mit dem Leo ins Risiko (Taking risks with the Leo),” Zeit, January 25, 2023 [https://www.zeit.de/2023/05/leopard-panzer-lieferung- ukraine-bundesregierung], and “Kanzler im Interview mit dem Tagesspiegel (Chancellor in an interview with the Tagesspiegel),” Website of the Chancellery, January 29, 2023 [https://www.bundeskanzler.de/bk-de/aktuelles/kanzler-im-tagesspiegel-interview- 2161058], and Karen DeYoung, Dan Lamothe, and Loveday Morris, “Tanks for Ukraine: How we got there,” The Washington Post, January 28, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/01/28/inside-story-biden-ukraine-tanks/].


922 Cristina Gallardo, “Ukraine got its tanks. Now it wants jet fighters too,” Politico, January 27, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/arti- cle/ukraine-volodymyr-zelenskyy-russia-war-after-tanks-the-west-mulls-discussion-on-fighter-jets/].


923 “Ukraine says pilots would need six months for F-16 combat training,” Reuters, January 27, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/ukraine-says-pilots-would-need-six-months-f-16-combat-training-2023-01-27/].


924 Lara Seligman et al, “At the Pentagon, push to send F-16s to Ukraine picks up steam,” Politico, January 28, 2023 [https://www.po- litico.com/news/2023/01/28/pentagon-send-f-16s-ukraine-00080045].


925 Susie Blann, “Ukraine: ‘Fast-track’ talks underway for missiles, planes,” AP News, January 28, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/russia-ukraine-zelenskyy-politics-government-donetsk-119eacfc993491b4b66a117ddfe91696].

he stressed. “I can only advise against entering into a constant competition to outbid each other when it

comes to weapons systems.”926


The fighter jet discussion did not abate, however. Andriy Yermak, a top aide to Zelenskyy, said on Janu- ary 30 that Poland would be willing to provide its F-16s to Ukraine in coordination with NATO.927 Asked by a reporter on the same day if Washington would transfer warplanes to Kyiv, Biden responded: “No.” When asked about Biden’s remark, a US official explained that there had been “no serious, high-level discussion about F-16s.”928 Yet, “by definition, nothing is excluded,” Macron told a press conference on the same day. Indeed, French officials noted that the possibility was on the table, but that a decision was unlikely in the immediate future.929 On January 31, British prime minister Sunak said he believed it was “not practical” to provide Ukraine with British fighter jets, but pledged to accelerate support to ena- ble “decisive gains” against Russia.930 On the same day, Biden answered that he was “going to talk” to Zelenskyy when asked again about his administration potentially sending fighter jets to Ukraine.931


Russia responded by cautioning against escalation risks. On January 30, Peskov warned that the West was “encouraging” Ukraine’s demands and professed its “readiness to provide such weapons.” It was a “dead-end situation” that would lead to “significant escalation,” and to “NATO countries more and more becoming directly involved in the conflict,” though it did not “have the potential to change the course of events and will not do so,” Peskov said.932


Against this tense backdrop, US-Russian exchanges on the future of arms control continued. Asked if Moscow could envisage there being no nuclear arms control treaty after 2026, Russia’s deputy foreign minister Sergei Ryabkov told reporters on January 30: “This is quite a possible scenario.”933 One day later, the US State Department sent a report to Congress stating that Russia had violated New START by refusing to allow on-site inspections and rebuffing Washington’s requests to meet to discuss its com- pliance concerns.934 In reaction, Antonov told journalists that it was Washington who was violating the treaty by “illegitimately” withdrawing more than 100 strategic weapons from treaty accounting. Given

the “hybrid war” the West was waging against Russia, it was “unjustified, untimely and inappropriate” to


926 Jones Hayden, “Scholz doubles down on refusal of fighter jets for Ukraine,” Politico, January 29, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.eu/article/germany-chancellor-olaf-scholz-doubles-down-on-refusal-of-fighter-jets-for-ukraine/].


927 “President's Office: Poland ready to supply Ukraine with F-16 fighters in coordination with NATO,” Kyiv Independent, January 30, 2023 [https://news.yahoo.com/presidents-office-poland-ready-supply-123728364.html].


928 Alexander Ward, “Biden seemingly rejects request to send U.S. F-16s to Ukraine,” Politico, January 30, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/news/2023/01/30/biden-f-16s-ukraine-00080276].


929 Leila Abboud et al, “France open to sending fighter jets to Ukraine,” Financial Times, January 31, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/4678ec97-bdff-4dfa-9507-dd6f6cb3dcc4?sharetype=blocked].


930 Sam Blewett, “UK says it is ‘not practical’ to give Ukraine British fighter jets,” The Independent, January 31, 2023 [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/ukraine-downing-street-cabinet-rishi-sunak-prime-minister-b2272778.html].


931 Kelly Garrity, “Biden says he will talk with Zelenskyy after rejecting Kyiv request for jets,” Politico, January 31, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/01/31/biden-says-he-will-talk-with-zelenskyy-after-seemingly-rejecting-kyivs-request- for-f-16-fighter-jets-00080387].


932 “Kremlin: More Western arms for Ukraine will only lead to escalation,” Reuters, January 31, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/kremlin-more-western-arms-ukraine-will-only-lead-escalation-2023-01-30/].


933 Guy Faulconbridge, “Russia warns United States: the end of nuclear arms control may be nigh,” Reuters, January 30, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/russia-says-nuclear-arms-treaty-with-us-may-end-after-2026-2023-01-30/].


934 Michael R. Gordon, “U.S. Says Russia Has Violated Nuclear-Arms Treaty by Blocking Inspections,” The Wall Street Journal, Janu- ary 31, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-says-russia-has-violated-nuclear-arms-treaty-by-blocking-inspections-

11675183584].

invite the US inspectors to Russian strategic facilities. However, Moscow intended to continue to “abide” by New START’s “central limits, continue to share notifications and related data.”935


February 2023: Of Western figherjets and Ukrainian incursions


169.

Warning

In response to Germany’s decision to send tanks to Ukraine, Putin warned on February 2 that Russia was not sending its tanks to the borders, but had “the means to respond, and it won’t end with the use of armor. Everyone must understand this.” It remained unclear whether the Russian leader was actu-

ally implying the potential use of nuclear weapons.936


In reaction to Putin’s statement, Burns noted in a speech on February 2 that Washington had to take seriously Moscow’s “saber rattling,” but its purpose was to intimidate the United States, its European allies, and the Ukrainian government. Thus, he argued, the Administration had “to stay on an even keel in weighing those threats carefully but also not being intimidated by them.” Seeking to frame Burns’ comments, US officials told journalists that, while concerns remained valid over Russia using a nuclear weapon, the tensions that had existed in autumn 2022 had since abated. A more stable battlefield,

China’s warnings, and improved communication between Moscow and Washington had contributed to a measure of stability. Putin had potentially concluded that nuclear threats were backfiring, a senior US official told reporters. Yet US officials also pointed out that Russia’s nuclear escalation threats were not over, and that the Kremlin could remind the West of its arsenal’s power by letting the West observe nu- clear weapons movements. The US government had no evidence that Russia was moving nuclear weap- ons towards the battlefield, but admitted that with respect to some of Russia’s tactical arms, US recon- naissance might not pick up such movement.937


US support for Ukraine remained strong. On February 2, the Biden Administration announced a $2.2 billion package of military aid to enable Ukraine to obtain long-range bombs. The Ground-Launched Small Diameter Bombs were able to strike targets within a range of over 90 miles, to be fired from HIM- ARS and M270 launchers.938 However, the new rockets were not to be drawn from American stockpiles, and would therefore take several months, if not over a year, to be delivered, US officials told the me- dia.939


170.

Warning

Russian nuclear warnings returned to the forefront. On February 4, asked whether Washington

providing Ukraine with advanced weaponry and allowing Kyiv to strike Russian targets on Crimea


935 “Посол РФ заявил, что Москва соблюдает ДСНВ на протяжении всех лет в отличие от Вашингтона (The Russian ambas- sador said that Moscow has complied with the START Treaty continuously over the years, unlike Washington),” TASS, February 1, 2023 [https://tass.ru/politika/16932853].


936 Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger, “Fears of Russian Nuclear Weapons Use Have Diminished, but Could Re-emerge,” New York Times, February 3, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/03/us/politics/russia-nuclear-weapons.html?searchResult- Position=1].


937 Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger, “Fears of Russian Nuclear Weapons Use Have Diminished, but Could Re-emerge,” New York Times, February 3, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/03/us/politics/russia-nuclear-weapons.html?searchResult- Position=1].


938 John Ismay, “Russia-Ukraine War. U.S. Package of $2.2 Billion in Ukraine Aid Includes New Guided Weapon,” New York Times, February 3, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/02/03/world/russia-ukraine-news].


939 Lara Seligman and Paul McLeary, “New U.S. aid package includes longer-range bombs for Ukraine,” Politico, February 3, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/02/03/ukriane-aid-includes-longer-range-bombs-00081112].

would force Russia to negotiate with Ukraine, Medvedev said that “the result will be just the oppo-

site. There will be no negotiations in this case, there will only be retaliation strikes. The whole of

Ukraine, which remained under the rule of Kyiv, will burn.” In reaction to the question of how Russia

would respond if Kyiv, with US permission, began to strike Crimea or strike deep into Russia,

Medvedev replied that Russia’s response could be “anything” and that Putin “spoke about this quite clearly.” He added: “We do not set ourselves any restrictions and, depending on the nature of the threats, we are ready to use all types of weapons. In accordance with our doctrinal documents, in- cluding the Fundamentals of Nuclear Deterrence. I can assure you that the answer will be quick,

tough and convincing.”940


Debates on supplying fighter jets continued. Biden had dismissed Kyiv’s plea for dozens of F-16s to pro- vide air support for troops and for protection against Russian attack planes on January 30 (see above). However, in private conversations senior US officials indicated in the first week of February that this “no” was probably temporary and that it did not preclude the Administration from deciding later to pro- vide F-16s, or to work out an agreement to allow another country to send its own F-16s to Ukraine. Ac- cording to American and European officials, such transfers could come from Denmark or the Nether- lands. Two officials noted that the US approval of sales or transfers of F-16s from partner nations to third-party countries could help reassure NATO countries that were concerned about being singled out by Russia for sending the advanced fighter planes.941


Also in early February, US officials and some congressional aides admitted to be working on possible jet deliveries behind the scenes. However, US and European officials stressed that they were focused on sending the weapons Kyiv needed for the immediate fight. Accordingly, a senior US DoD official stated that he did not think the US government was “opposed on the fourth-generation aircraft issue, I just think we have to make sure that we continue to prioritize.” Similarly, an Eastern European senior diplo- mat voiced on February 1 that delivering fighter aircraft was “an issue of longer-term perspective”, fur- ther stressing the need to deliver what was committed in January “as soon as possible.” Western diplo- mats also cautioned that it was impossible to send Kyiv jets and train pilots in time for a looming Russian offensive.942


Still, US officials stressed that bigger and better weapons that were publicly promised but not delivered right away sent a message to Russia, since a Ukrainian military with more fighter jets and tanks in per- haps a year would be able to mount counteroffensives to take back territory seized by Moscow. In what seemed to be a reaction to Macron’s stance of sending fighter jets to Ukraine only if such equipment would not be used “to touch Russian soil,” a US official said that after a year of warning the Ukrainians not to fire Western weaponry into Russia, the Ukrainian military had earned their trust.943 In response to the overall Western reluctance of sending fighter jets, Ukrainian Deputy Foreign Minister Andriy Melnyk stressed on February 1 that the war was “far from over,” stating that “Putin appears to have


940 Nadana Fridrikhson, “Dmitry Medvedev answered several of my questions in writing,” Telegram @FridrihShow, February 4, 2023 [https://t.me/FridrihShow/7596]; Kevin Liffey, “Russia’s Medvedev says more U.S. weapons supplies mean 'all of Ukraine will burn',” Reuters, February 4, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russias-medvedev-says-more-us-weapons-sup- plies-mean-all-ukraine-will-burn-2023-02-04/]. Andrew Stanton, “Russia Floats Nuclear Deterrence if Ukraine Attacks Crimea,” Newsweek, February 4, 2023 [https://www.newsweek.com/russia-floats-nuclear-deterrence-if-ukraine-attacks-crimea-1778989].


941 Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt, “What ‘No’ on F-16 Fighter Jets Might Mean for Ukraine,” New York Times, February 1, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/01/us/politics/ukraine-f16-russia.html].


942 Lara Seligman, Clea Caulcut, Cristina Gallardo and Cory Bennett, “Cool your jets: Why the West is making Ukraine wait for fighter planes,” Politico, February 1, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/fighter-jets-west-eu-us-ukraine-wait-planes-f-16- russia-war/].


943 Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt, “What ‘No’ on F-16 Fighter Jets Might Mean for Ukraine,” New York Times, February 1, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/01/us/politics/ukraine-f16-russia.html].

even more appetite than ever,” but that “without air support you can’t fight a modern war.” The same day, a military adviser to the Ukrainian government assessed that the discussion on jets was simply in its “early days,” expressing optimism that the Western position would change in the coming weeks.944


Some additional details emerged on Berlin’s position vis-à-vis Ukraine. In an interview on February 5, Scholz underlined that Putin had not threatened Germany nor himself personally in a telephone call of the two leaders. But their very different positions on the war in Ukraine had become clear. Scholz had made it very clear to Putin that Russia carried the sole responsibility for the war; adding that “we cannot simply accept this, because it fundamentally violates European peace.” Asked whether the delivery of Leopard-2 tanks would lead to an increased threat for Germany, Scholz answered that Putin’s words were “part of a series of abstruse historical comparisons that he uses to justify his attack on Ukraine,” further stating that Germany had “carefully weighed each arms shipment and closely coordinated it with our allies, first and foremost America. This joint approach prevents an escalation of the war.”945


Meanwhile, a week after Scholz had committed to sending Leopard-2 tanks to Ukraine for two tank bat- talions in coordination with other European nations, doubts were mounting in the chancellery and in the defense resort whether these plans were feasible, due to missing commitments by European part- ners. Government circles confirmed that the compilation of battalions proved to be a painstaking effort. At a video conference held by German defense minister Boris Pistorius in late January, no EU country wanted to make concrete commitments on participation in sending a package of modern Leopard-2 A6 models. Scholz, Pistorius and Tjorven Bellmann, political director at the German foreign office, had started to ask for support in individual phone calls to send both battalions to Ukraine by the end of March. However, officials in the chancellery voiced doubts that sending two battalions of 40 tanks each was realistic, and thus adapted their aims to 31 tanks per battalion.946


The intense lobbying from Berlin bore some fruits on February 7, when the Netherlands and Denmark committed to help finance the purchase of around 100 decommissioned Leopard 1 tanks. Both countries agreed to jointly finance the refurbishment of the tanks and provide training for Ukrainian crews along- side Germany. However, officials stated that neither the Netherlands nor Denmark would send any of their own tanks to Ukraine.947 Portuguese PM Antonio Costa told parliament on February 9 that Portu- gal was carrying out maintenance on Leopard 2 tanks, and would deliver three of them in March.948


Of the countries that had signaled they might send tanks to Ukraine if Germany allowed it, Finland, Swe- den, Belgium and Spain, commitments were still missing as of February 9. However, officials from some of these states stated they would work together with allies on training and financing. While a Belgian


944 Lara Seligman, Clea Caulcut, Cristina Gallardo and Cory Bennett, “Cool your jets: Why the West is making Ukraine wait for fighter planes,” Politico, February 1, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/fighter-jets-west-eu-us-ukraine-wait-planes-f-16- russia-war/].


945 Angelika Hellemann, Alexandra Würzbach and Niels Starnick, “‘Klimakleber? Viele schütteln den Kopf über solche Aktionen. Ich auch‘: Der Kanzler über Putin, Horrorszenarien und seinen Hochzeitstag,“ BILD, February 5, 2023 [https://www.bild.de/poli- tik/inland/politik-inland/olaf-scholz-im-bams-interview-klimakleber-viele-schuetteln-den-kopf-ich-auch-82789486.bild.html].


946 Matthias Gebauer, Marina Kormbaki and Gerald Traufetter, “Der Kanzler redet den Panzer-Parnern ins Gewissen,“ Spiegel, Feb- ruary 3, 2023 [https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/waffenhilfe-fuer-die-ukraine-kanzler-olaf-scholz-redet-den-panzer- partnern-ins-gewissen-a-9a1da89b-0b76-4c2d-a93a-d7116dca071f].


947 Bojan Pancevski, “Tanks Aren’t Arriving in Ukraine Despite Promises From European Allies,” Wall Street Journal, February 9, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/europeans-reluctance-to-give-ukraine-tanks-leaves-germany-out-in-the-cold-

11675948197].


948 Bojan Pancevski, “Tanks Aren’t Arriving in Ukraine Despite Promises From European Allies,” Wall Street Journal, February 9, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/europeans-reluctance-to-give-ukraine-tanks-leaves-germany-out-in-the-cold-

11675948197].

government spokesman stated that the state had no tanks to give, a senior Finnish official confirmed that Finland would be part of the Leopard 2 cooperation in some way, further noting that Finland had a policy of not revealing the aid it sent to Ukraine. A senior NATO official specified that Finland had sig- naled it might not directly engage in tank deliveries before having officially joined the alliance; and even after joining it would only be able to spare a few tanks. 949


Bilateral arms control issues between Washington and Moscow became heated. In its February 8 state- ment on the further reduction and limitation of strategic offensive arms, the Russian foreign ministry rejected “the US representatives’ allegations about Russia’s non-compliance” and further read that the

US “hostile actions … put in question the applicability of several crucial provisions of New START.” It fur- ther stated that the US had “actually launched a total hybrid war against Russia, which includes the risk of a direct military confrontation between two nuclear powers.” Still, the statement concluded by reaf-

firming Russia’s “unwavering commitment to New START.”950


Where in public NATO allies emphasized unity, positions on the future of the conflict in Ukraine seemed to diverge. When Macron and Scholz met Zelensky for dinner in Paris on February 8, they told him that he needed to start considering peace talks with Moscow, media reported weeks later, arguing that significant gains were unlikely and the price of a prolonged conflict was steep for all.951

Media reports surfaced on February 10 that US officials were providing or confirming coordinates for the vast majority of strikes with advanced US-provided rocket systems. This information was confirmed by three senior Ukrainian and one senior US official. The coordinates were delivered by US military per- sonnel from a European base outside of Ukraine. Ukrainian officials said that this process was intended to give Washington confidence about providing Kyiv with longer-range weapons. A senior US official stated that the key US role in providing targeting assistance served to ensure accuracy and conserve lim- ited stores of ammunition for maximum effectiveness, adding that the US provided targeting infor- mation solely in an advisory role. In an official statement, senior Pentagon officials highlighted the limi- tations of US involvement, underlining that the Ukrainians were “responsible for finding targets, prioritizing them and then ultimately deciding which ones to engage. The US does not approve targets, nor are we involved in the selection or engagement of targets.”952


On the same February 10, it was reported that current and former US officials had indicated that the Pentagon was urging Congress to resume funding for 2024 of a pair of top-secret programs which would allow American Special Operations troops to employ Ukrainian operatives to monitor Russian military movements and counter disinformation. Critics, including on Capitol Hill, stated such activities may draw the US into a more direct role in the Ukraine war, while defense officials highlighted the use- ful gain in intelligence and replied that the secretive surrogate programs would not contribute directly to Ukraine’s combat capabilities as they would be restricted to performing nonviolent tasks.953


949 Bojan Pancevski, “Tanks Aren’t Arriving in Ukraine Despite Promises From European Allies,” Wall Street Journal, February 9, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/europeans-reluctance-to-give-ukraine-tanks-leaves-germany-out-in-the-cold-

11675948197].


950 “Foreign Ministry statement regarding the Treaty on Measures for the Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms (New START),” Russian Foreign Ministry, February 8, 2023 [https://www.mid.ru/ru/foreign_pol- icy/news/1852877/?lang=en].


951 Bojan Pancevski and Laurence Norman, “NATO’s Biggest European Members Float Defense Pact With Ukraine,” Wallstreet Jour- nal, February 24, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/natos-biggest-european-members-float-defense-pact-with-ukraine-

38966950].


952 Isabelle Khurshudyan et al., Ukraine’s strikes rely on precision targets from U.S.,” Washington Post, February 10, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/02/09/ukraine-himars-rocket-artillery-russia/].


953 Wesley Morgan, “Pentagon looks to restart top-secret programs in Ukraine,” Washington Post, February 10, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/02/10/us-special-operations-ukraine-surrogate-program/].

Also on February 10, Russia targeted Ukraine’s infrastructure with drones, rockets and cruise missiles across the country. The attack involved 71 cruise missiles and seven Iranian-made drones, of which Ukraine shut down 61 and five, respectively, according to an official statement. Despite heavy fighting, there was no evidence of a major breakthrough. According to Ukrainian officials, two Russian missiles crossed into Romanian airspace, whereas Bucharest rejected the claim. Missiles hit inter alia several high-voltage infrastructure sites and damaged power transmission lines.954


US weapons deliveries were by no means without problems. On February 13, media reported that US officials uttered concerns about the stockpile as a further argument why the transfer of ATACMS (range of approximately 300 km) to Ukraine would not be happening anytime soon.955


The Alliance continued to argue a common line. In his speech on February 13, Stoltenberg stated that Putin was “not preparing for peace,” but “launching new offensives,“ underlining that NATO “must con- tinue to provide Ukraine with what it needs to win. And to achieve a just and sustainable peace.” Stolten- berg further called for increased munitions production and improved intelligence and surveillance, and underlined that the Russian spring offensive had already begun, with Russia sending “thousands and thousands of more troops, accepting a very high rate of casualties.” As a “second main focus” he noted that when the war ended, NATO “should ensure that Ukraine is able to deter and defend itself,” by work- ing with Ukraine on long-term reforms, interoperability and long-term transition to NATO standards.956


In meetings with allies on February 14, Austin highlighted the threat of Russia’s significant remaining air force. “He was very clear that we have a short window of time to help the Ukrainians to prepare for an offensive and that they had some pretty specific needs,” a senior US Administration official said. Later that day, Austin said that the US did not see imminent signs of a “massive aerial attack” in Ukraine, but that Washington and its allies were rushing as much air defense capability to Ukraine as they could. He added that “Russia has substantial aircraft … and a lot of capability left.” According to a senior NATO diplomat, “more than 80 per cent” of Russia’s air force was probably “safe and available.” Germany’s defense minister Boris Pistorius on February 14 confirmed that Rheinmetall would restart production of ammunition for Gepard anti-aircraft guns to support Kyiv. In this context, a US official voiced that fighter jets were not as capable against the Russian air force as an integrated air defense system.957

In the second week of February, US officials furthermore urged Ukrainian officials to prioritize the tim- ing and execution of the spring counteroffensive, and deprioritize defending Bakhmut. A senior US offi- cial claimed that if Russia took Bakhmut this would “not result in any significant strategic shift in the battlefield.”958


954 Marc Santora, “Russia-Ukraine War: Russia Fires Scores of Missiles While Ramping Up Winter Offensive,” New York Times, Feb- ruary 10, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/02/10/world/russia-ukraine-news?smid=url-share#ukraine-says-russia- fired-missiles-and-drones-in-waves-to-evade-air-defense-systems].


955 Paul McLeary, Lara Seligman and Alexander Ward, “U.S. tells Ukraine it won’t send long-range missiles because it has few to

spare,” Politico, February 13, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/02/13/u-s-wont-send-long-range-missiles-ukraine-

00082652].


956 Jens Stoltenberg, “Pre-ministerial press conference by NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg ahead of the meetings of NATO Defence Ministers,” North Atlantic Treaty Organization, February 13, 2023 [https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/opin- ions_211689.htm].


957 Felicia Schwartz and Henry Foy, “Western intelligence shows Russians amassing aircraft on Ukraine border,” Financial Times, February 14, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/3fd6e91f-71e4-4c02-9360-be20a2a78763].


958 Yasmeen Abutaleb and John Hudson, “US warns Ukraine it faces pivotal moment in war,” Washington Post, February 14, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/02/13/us-ukraine-war-critical-moment/].

The Biden Administration also seemed concerned with deepening Russian-Chinese ties. On the eve of the Munich security conference on February 16, spokesman for the Chinese foreign ministry Wang Webin said Beijing stood “ready to work with Russia to further advance our comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era.”959 On February 18, Blinken said Washington had indica- tions that Beijing was “considering providing lethal support to Russia in its aggression against Ukraine.” He stated to have made clear that “that would have serious consequences in our own relationship.”960 The same day, Harris also warned China against supporting Russia in a speech to the Munich security conference, and US officials said they had shared intelligence with allies.961


Nonetheless, Chinese officials did not seem deterred. On February 19, China’s UN ambassador Zhang Jun called on the US and Russia to “continue to negotiate with each other in finding a good solution.”962 On February 20, Wenbin pointed out that it was the US not China that had been “incessantly supplying weapons to the battlefield.” He asked Washington to “stop shirking responsibility and disseminating

fake news” and stressed that China would “continue firmly standing on the side of dialogue and the side of peace.”963 In reaction, Borrell warned February 20 against China sending arms to Russia, saying it would be a “red line.”964 On the same day, Swedish foreign minister Billström stated that if such a deci- sion was taken by China it would “definitely have consequences,” with Sweden standing “side by side with the United States on this message.” Lithuania’s Landsbergis also underlined that the EU would be on the same page as the US should China send arms to Russia. He also said that drawing from the lesson that the West reacted united to the Russian attack against Ukraine, “there would be enough arguments for China not to assist Russia in its genocidal war in Ukraine.”965 US officials and some European offi- cials said that Chinese officials were trying to make it appear as if China was a neutral broker seeking a

peace agreement when in reality it would be edging toward giving material aid to the Russian war effort. Zelensky reportedly said that China giving weapons to Russia would result in a “world war,” and that he hoped Chinese leaders would refrain from doing so after making a “practical assessment.”966 On Febru- ary 21, Chinese foreign minister Qin Gang said that China was “deeply worried that the Ukraine conflict will continue to escalate or even spiral out of control,” and called on “certain countries to immediately stop fueling the fire,” adding that they must “stop hyping up today Ukraine, tomorrow Taiwan.” The same day, China released a paper on the Global Security Initiative (GSI), Xi’s flagship security proposal


959 Edward Wong, “U.S. Warnings to China on Arms Aid for Russia’s War Portend Global Rift,” February 19, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/02/19/world/europe/us-china-weapons-russia-ukraine.html].


960 Chris Buckley, “China Says U.A. Is ‘Not Qualified’ to Issue Orders on Arms,” New York Times, February 20, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/20/world/asia/china-russia-us-arms.html]; Edward Wong, “U.S. Warnings to China on Arms Aid for Russia’s War Portend Global Rift,” New York Times, February 19, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/02/19/world/europe/us-china-weapons-russia-ukraine.html].


961 Edward Wong, “U.S. Warnings to China on Arms Aid for Russia’s War Portend Global Rift,” New York Times, February 19, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/19/world/europe/us-china-weapons-russia-ukraine.html].


962 “Putin raises tension on Ukraine, suspends START nuclear pact,” AP, February 22, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia- ukraine-putin-politics-de0af48be7ea480ccb0175f55a065363].


963 Chris Buckley, “China Says U.A. Is ‘Not Qualified’ to Issue Orders on Arms,” New York Times, February 20, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/20/world/asia/china-russia-us-arms.html].


964 Martin Pollard, Laurie Chen and Bernard Orr, “China says certain countries must stop ‘fueling the fire’ in Ukraine,” Reuters, Feb- ruary 21, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-says-it-is-deeply-worried-about-escalation-ukraine-conflict-2023- 02-21/].


965 Stuart Lau, “EU top diplomat says China will cross ‘red line’ if it sends arms to Russia,” Politico, February 20, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-diplomat-josep-borrel-china-russia-ukraine-war/].


966 Edward Wong, “U.S. Warnings to China on Arms Aid for Russia’s War Portend Global Rift,” New York Times, February 19, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/19/world/europe/us-china-weapons-russia-ukraine.html].

which aims to uphold the principle of “indivisible security.”967 Also on the same March 21, at a press conference with Kuleba in Brussels, Borrell told journalists that Wang Yi had told him in a private dis- cussion at the MSC that China was “not providing arms to Russia” and “will not provide arms to Rus-

sia.”968


On February 19, Russia’s defense ministry stated that radioactive substances had allegedly been transported to Ukraine from a European country and that Kyiv was preparing a large-scale “provoca- tion.” The statement further read that the aim of the provocation was “to accuse Russia's army of alleg- edly carrying out indiscriminate strikes on hazardous radioactive facilities in Ukraine, leading to the leakage of radioactive substances and contamination of the area.” Ukraine and its allies dismissed these accusations as cynical attempts to spread disinformation and accused Moscow to be planning incidents itself, seeking to blame Ukraine.969


Probably around February 20, Russia unsuccessfully tested a SARMAT missile. Moscow had notified Washington in advance of the launch in accordance to its arms control obligations, and US officials noted such testing was “routine,” posed no risk to the United States, and was not seen by the Administration as an escalation. US officials believed that, had the test been successful, Putin would have highlighted the capability in his subsequent speech.970


171.

Warning

Nuclear rhetoric returned even at the Presidential level. In his state-of-the-nation address on Febru- ary 21, Putin repeated his narrative that the Ukraine war had been forced on Russia, particularly by NATO’s eastward expansion since the Cold War: “It’s they who have started the war. And we are using force to end it.” The “Kyiv regime” and “Western overlords” had “effectively occupied this country.”

He alleged that the US government intended “to transform a local conflict into a phase of global con-

frontation,” and stressed that Russia would “react accordingly, because in this case we are talking about the existence of our country.”971


During the same speech, Putin also announced the suspension of Russia’s participation in the New START treaty. According to Putin, some people in Washington were considering breaking a moratorium on nuclear testing. He stressed that “if the US conducts tests, then we will. No one should have danger-

ous illusions that global strategic parity can be destroyed,” further stating that “a week ago, I signed a decree on putting new ground-based strategic systems on combat duty.” Putin further said Ukraine had sought to strike a facility far inside Russia where it stationed nuclear bombers.972 In reaction to Putin’s


967 Martin Pollard, Laurie Chen and Bernard Orr, “China says certain countries must stop ‘fueling the fire’ in Ukraine,” Reuters, Feb- ruary 21, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-says-it-is-deeply-worried-about-escalation-ukraine-conflict-2023- 02-21/].


968 “Ukraine: Remarks by High Representative/Vice-President Josep Borrell at the joint press conference with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Kuleba and NATO Secretary-General Stoltenberg,” EEAS, February 21, 2023 [https://www.eeas.europa.eu/eeas/ukraine- remarks-high-representativevice-president-josep-borrell-joint-press-conference_en].


969 “Russia accuses Kyiv of planning to stage nuclear incident,” Reuters, February 19, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/eu- rope/russia-accuses-kyiv-planning-stage-nuclear-incident-2023-02-19/].


970 Oren Liebermann and Natasha Bertrand, “US believes Russia had failed intercontinental ballistic missile test around when

Biden was in Ukraine,” CNN, February 22, 2023 [https://edition.cnn.com/2023/02/21/politics/russia-intercontinental-ballistic- missile-test/index.html].


971 “Putin raises tension on Ukraine, suspends START nuclear pact,” AP, February 22, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia- ukraine-putin-politics-de0af48be7ea480ccb0175f55a065363].


972 Guy Faulconbridge, “Russia's Putin issues new nuclear warnings to West over Ukraine,” Reuters, February 22, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/putin-update-russias-elite-ukraine-war-major-speech-2023-02-21/]; “Putin raises tension on

speech, Russia’s foreign ministry said later on February 21 that Moscow intended to continue abiding by the restrictions outlined in New START on the number of warheads it could deploy. 973 It also said Russia would continue to exchange information about test launches of ballistic missiles per earlier agreements with the United States.974


Russian rhetoric notwithstanding, the Biden Administration demonstrated strong support for Ukraine. On February 20-21, Biden made a surprise visit to Ukraine – an audacious move meant to demonstrate American resolve to help Ukraine defeat the Russian forces. Biden was the first President in generations to travel to an area that was not under the control of US forces. American military planes hovered in eastern Poland, but officials told journalists that they never entered Ukrainian airspace out of concern that it would be interpreted as the sort of direct US intervention the Administration had sought to avoid.975

The US President gave a speech on February 21 in Poland to mark the one-year anniversary of Rus-

sia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Biden said that “democracies of the world will stand guard over free- dom today, tomorrow and forever” and that “Ukraine will never be a victory for Russia.” However, he stressed that neither the United States nor European nations were seeking “to control or destroy Rus- sia.” The West was not “plotting to attack Russia, as Putin said today.” Biden also noted that “millions of Russian citizens who only want to live in peace with their neighbors are not the enemy. This war was never a necessity; it’s a tragedy. President Putin chose this war. Every day the war continues is his

choice. He could end the war with a word.” Biden moreover pledged continued support for Ukraine dur- ing the “hard and bitter days ahead, victories and tragedies,” adding “let there be no doubt, the commit- ment of the United States and our NATO Alliance and Article 5 is rock solid.”976


The Biden Administration condemned Putin’s decision to suspend New START on the same day, casti- gating Putin but also stressing that the US would not abandon efforts to cooperate on nuclear precau- tions. Blinken called the suspension “deeply unfortunate and irresponsible,” adding that Washington would “be watching carefully to see what Russia actually does.” Blinken told reporters that “we’ll of course make sure that, in any event, we are postured appropriately for the security of our country and our allies.”977


Ukraine, suspends START nuclear pact,” AP, February 22, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-putin-politics- de0af48be7ea480ccb0175f55a065363].


973 Guy Faulconbridge, “Russia's Putin issues new nuclear warnings to West over Ukraine,” Reuters, February 22, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/putin-update-russias-elite-ukraine-war-major-speech-2023-02-21/].


974 “Putin raises tension on Ukraine, suspends START nuclear pact,” AP, February 22, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia- ukraine-putin-politics-de0af48be7ea480ccb0175f55a065363].


975 “Putin raises tension on Ukraine, suspends START nuclear pact,” AP, February 22, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia- ukraine-putin-politics-de0af48be7ea480ccb0175f55a065363]; Matt Berg and Nahal Toosi, “U.S. rebukes Putin as ‘irresponsible’ on nukes,” Politico, February 21, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/02/21/blinken-putin-nuclear-treaty-00083740]; Nandita Bose and Guy Faulconbridge, “Biden says Ukraine ‘stands strong’, Russia gives nuclear warning,” Reuters, February 22, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/biden-says-russia-will-never-defeat-ukraine-after-kremlin-suspends-nuclear-2023-02- 21/]. For Biden’s trip to Ukraine, Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear, “Biden’s Surreal and Secretive Journey Into a War Zone,” New York Times, February 20, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/20/us/politics/biden-kyiv-ukraine.html?smid=url-share].


976 “Remarks by President Biden Ahead of the One-Year Anniversary of Russia’s Brutal and Unprovoked Invasion of Ukraine,” White House, February 21, 2023 [https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2023/02/21/remarks-by-pres- ident-biden-ahead-of-the-one-year-anniversary-of-russias-brutal-and-unprovoked-invasion-of-ukraine/].


977 Matt Berg and Nahal Toosi, “U.S. rebukes Putin as ‘irresponsible’ on nukes,” Politico, February 21, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/news/2023/02/21/blinken-putin-nuclear-treaty-00083740].

172.

Warning

Moscow responded with more nuclear rhetoric. Also on February 22, Medvedev stated that Wash-

ington had been supplying high “gigantic volumes of arms” to Ukraine “to defeat, contain and destroy Russia.” He added that “if the US wants to defeat Russia, then we are on the verge of a global conflict. If the US wants to defeat Russia, then we have the right to defend ourselves with any weapon, includ- ing nuclear weapons.” He also stated that Russia had suspended its participation in the New START treaty so the West could not defeat it on the battlefield, urging US elites “to think what they’ve done.” Medvedev furthermore alleged that “if Russia stops its special operation, without achieving victory, there will be no Russia, it will be torn apart. If the US stops supplying weapons to the Kyiv regime, the

war will end.”978


In Washington, the Biden Administration offered some clarifications on China’s potential intentions. On February 24, Blinken told an interviewer that Washington had “picked up information” over the previ- ous months that China was considering sending lethal aid and systematically avoiding sanctions on Rus- sia. This had been the reason Blinked had met with Wang Yi in Munich, to tell him that such policy

choices in Beijing would be a “serious problem in the relationship.”979 On February 26, Burns clarified that US officials believed that China was considering sending weapons to Russia, though they “don’t see that a final decision has been made yet, and we don’t see evidence of actual shipments of lethal equip- ment.”980


Beijing seemed bent to both appease Washington and retain its freedom of movement. The Chinese Foreign Ministry released a position paper on Ukraine on February 24, after Wang had visited Mos- cow and met Putin on February 22, after having attended the Munich Security Conference the previous weekend. The Chinese “peace plan” reiterated Beijing’s opposition to the use of nuclear weapons, but also called for the resumption of peace talks and an end to unilateral sanctions. It also criticized NATO expansion and “Cold War mentality.”981


Some details emerged in Moscow with respect to the Kremlin’s stance towards New START. Putin said in an interview recorded on February 22 and broadcasted on February 26 that, when “all leading NATO countries had declared their main goal to inflict a strategic defeat” on Russia, Moscow had to “take into account their nuclear capabilities” – thus suggesting that arms control negotiations would have to involve Britain and France. Putin also appealed to nationalist sentiments in Russia by claiming that the West was bent on breaking the Russian Federation apart.982


Some internal Russian dynamics emerged from Western reporters’ inquiries. For an article published on

February 23, Putin confidants argued that the Russian leader had become even more isolated since


978 Elena Teslova, “Medvedev says if US stops arms deliveries to Ukraine, war will end,” Anadolu Agency, February 22, 2023 [https://www.aa.com.tr/en/world/medvedev-says-if-us-stops-arms-deliveries-to-ukraine-war-will-end/2827825].


979 Jeffrey Goldberg and Morgan Ome, “Blinken: I Understand Why Zelensky Is Demanding That the U.S. ‘Do Even More and Do It Even Faster’,” Atlantic, February 26, 2023 [https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/02/antony-blinken-ukraine-jeffrey- goldberg-zelensky/673188/].


980 “Transcript: CIA director William Burns on "Face the Nation,” Feb. 26, 2023, CBS News, February 26, 2023 [https://www.cbsnews.com/news/william-burns-cia-director-face-the-nation-transcript-02-26-2023/].


981 Nectar Gan and Simone McCarthy, “China calls for Russia-Ukraine ceasefire as claims to neutrality questioned,” CNN, February 24, 2023 [https://edition.cnn.com/2023/02/23/china/china-position-political-settlement-ukraine-intl-hnk/]. See also “China’s Position on the Political Settlement of the Ukraine Crisis,” Website of the MFA of the PRC, February 24, 2023 [https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/zxxx_662805/202302/t20230224_11030713.html].


982 Andrew Katell, “Putin: will ‘take into account’ NATO’s nuclear capability,” AP, February 26, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/putin-nato-politics-russia-government-united-states-0bffecbd258654bed617653ee078ff35].

the start of the war. “People who don’t trust anyone start trusting a very small number of people who lie to them,” one said. Given Putin’s prizing of loyalty and secrecy over competence, his underlings were telling him what he wanted to hear, a number of confidants assessed. “He’s of sound mind. He’s reasona- ble. He’s not crazy. But nobody can be an expert on everything. They need to be honest with him and they are not,” a longtime Putin confidant told reporters. Some of the more liberal officials had attempted to convince Putin to end the war by pointing to the economic damage of sanctions. But the Russian

leader had insisted that he had “already factored in the discounts.” He admitted that he had underesti- mated how difficult it would be to achieve his aims. But he still refused to end the conflict. Many within the Russian elite assumed the fight had become existential for Putin. However, the Russian leader had gamed out the possibility of using a nuclear weapon in Ukraine and had come to the conclusion that it would not benefit him, two people close to the Kremlin told reporters. Overall, their assessment was that Putin hoped Russia could still outlast Western commitment to Ukraine. A former Kremlin official noted that the alternative was too difficult for Putin to contemplate – facing a disastrous defeat for Rus- sia, he would have to abandon power, maybe even lose his life.983


US officials tried to reassure with respect to Russia’s nuclear intentions. On the same February 23, Sul- livan told an expert audience that there was no concern that Putin would use strategic nuclear weapons on Ukraine or against NATO. But there were internal concerns within the Administration that Moscow might use tactical nuclear weapons on the Ukrainian battlefield, though there was no acute sign that it was going to happen soon. The US national security advisor also said that Washington would have to of- fer Kyiv “commitments” strong enough to deter Russia from invading again – but he noted that the end of fighting or real negotiations were not in sight.984


Once again, differences in views within the Alliance resurfaced. France, Britain, and Germany sought to establish stronger ties between NATO and Ukraine in order to encourage Kyiv to start negotiations with Moscow, journalists reported on February 24. A week prior, London had laid out a blueprint to give Ukraine much broader access to advanced military equipment, weapons and ammunition to defend itself once the war ended. Reportedly, all three capitals supported the initiative as a way to boost Ukrainian confidence and give Kyiv an incentive to start talks with Russia, but also to show Russia how committed the West was. However, the proposal would not include neither security guarantees, nor any stationing of NATO forces in Ukraine, and NATO membership would not be part of the package.985


Mere days before Scholz was scheduled to meet Biden in Washington, US-German relations appeared strained with respect to weapons deliveries to Ukraine. Sullivan told a TV journalist on February 26 that the White House had not wanted to send Abrams, as these would not be “useful on the battlefield in this fight,” but Biden had relented to obtain German deliveries on Leopard tanks. Spokespersons of the German government denied a direct linkage and insisted the bilateral talks had been “constructive.”986 The Biden Administration also kept restating its support for Ukraine, but also its desire to keep the con- flict limited and the need to dissuade Russian use of nuclear weapons. Blinken told an interviewer on February 26 that US support for Ukraine was “fundamental” and “for as long as it takes,” but underlined


983 Max Seddon et al, “How Putin blundered into Ukraine — then doubled down,” Financial Times, February 23, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/80002564-33e8-48fb-b734-44810afb7a49].


984 Alexander Ward et al, “What Jake Sullivan privately said about the war,” Politico, February 24, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/02/24/what-jake-sullivan-privately-said-about-the-war-00084290].


985 Bojan Pancevski and Laurence Norman, “NATO’s Biggest European Members Float Defense Pact With Ukraine,” Wallstreet Jour- nal, February 24, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/natos-biggest-european-members-float-defense-pact-with-ukraine-

38966950].


986 Alexander Ward, “Tanks for nothing,” Politico, February 27, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security- daily/2023/02/27/tanks-for-nothing-00084521].

that that Administration did not want to “broaden this war” and “do anything to create a wider confla- gration.” Blinken also noted that, beyond US warnings, China and India engaging Putin directly about “their absolute opposition to any use of nuclear weapons” had “some effect.”987 On the next day, Febru- ary 27, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen made a surprise visit to Kyiv and stated during a meeting with Zelensky that she brought with her “a clear message from President Biden and the American peo- ple: We will stand with Ukraine for as long as it takes.”988


On February 28, a Ukrainian drone crashed around 100 km southeast of Moscow in an apparent at- tempt to reach the capital, Russian authorities claimed.989


173.

Warning

On the same day, a US official underlined the high costs of Russian nuclear use. Colin Kahl told Con- gress on February 28 that the good news was that he did not think Russia was likely to use nuclear weapons.“ Any use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine, on any scale would be considered a world chang- ing event that would bring about severe consequences far in excess of anything the Russians have ex- perienced to date,” he said. “A lot of the restraints we've been operating under would no longer [con-

tinue] in a world where Russia crossed that threshold.”990


March 2023: Russian nuclear rhetoric returns in full force


At the beginning of March, in Washington, the Biden Administration seemed bent to sanction China if it chose to deliver weapons to Russia. A report emerging on March 1 noted that the US government was sounding out allies about the possibility if imposing such sanctions – but details had not yet been final- ized.991


In an attempt to urge Beijing to use its influence over Moscow, ahead of the G20 meeting, Scholz stated on March 2 that it was “disappointing” that Beijing “was no longer willing to reaffirm what was still the consensus” during the meetings of G20 finance ministers in India the week before – “a clear condemna- tion of the Russian attack.” Still, he praised China’s “unequivocal” opposition to Russian nuclear threats, which according to Scholz “has helped de-escalate the situation,” also acknowledging that the recent 12- point peace plan of Beijing reaffirmed this “clear message” against the use of nuclear, biological or chem- ical weapons of mass destruction. He added that his message to Beijing was clear, “use your influence in


987 Jeffrey Goldberg and Morgan Ome, “Blinken: I Understand Why Zelensky Is Demanding That the U.S. ‘Do Even More and Do It Even Faster’,” Atlantic, February 26, 2023 [https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/02/antony-blinken-ukraine-jeffrey- goldberg-zelensky/673188/].


988 Kelly Garrity, “Biden will back Ukraine for ‘as long as it takes,’ Yellen says in Kyiv,” Politico, February 27, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/02/27/treasury-sec-trip-ukraine-00084557].


989 “Drone crashes in failed attack southeast of Moscow, regional governor says,” Reuters, February 28, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/moscow-says-ukraine-launched-failed-drone-attacks-russian-territory-overnight-2023-02-28/].


990 Ben Makuch, “Putin Unlikely to Use Nukes in Ukraine, Pentagon Says,” Vice, February 28, 2023 [https://www.vice.com/en/arti- cle/bvmwk4/pentagon-putin-nukes-ukraine]. See also “Full Committee Hearing: Oversight of US Military Support to Ukraine,” HASC Website, February 28, 2023 [https://armedservices.house.gov/hearings/full-committee-hearing-oversight-us-military-sup- port-ukraine].


991 Trevor Hunnicutt and Michael Martina, “US seeks allies' backing for possible China sanctions over Ukraine war,” Reuters, March 1, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/us-seeks-allies-backing-possible-china-sanctions-over-ukraine-war-sources-2023-03- 01/].

Moscow to press for the withdrawal of Russian troops.” He also reiterated towards Beijing: “Do not sup- ply weapons to Russia.”992


Meanwhile, also on March 2, Blinken and Lavrov had a short 10-minute conversation during a G20 meeting in New Delhi. According to a US official, Blinken said that the United States would continue to support Ukraine in its defense against Russia for as long as it takes to end the war and that Russia should rejoin the New START treaty.993


Tensions in Ukraine continued unabated. On the same March 2, Putin accused Ukrainian saboteurs of crossing the border in the southern Bryansk region and staging “terrorist attacks” – officials in Kyiv stated these were false “provocations” that could be used by Moscow to escalate the conflict.994 How- ever, on March 6, Ukrainian special forces said that they had indeed destroyed an unmanned observa- tion tower in the Bryansk region.995


174.

Warning

One day later, Russian officials again warned that the conflict in Ukraine could escalate. Ryabkov told the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva on March 3 that US and NATO were following a “policy of fueling the conflict in Ukraine” and warned that “increasing involvement in the military confrontation

is fraught with a direct military clash of nuclear powers with catastrophic consequences.”996


On the same March 3, Scholz made a low-key visit to Washington to meet Biden. Russia’s war in

Ukraine was thought to be one of the topics for discussion, but few details emerged.997


Over the following days, after months of struggle, the battle over Bakhmut seemed to be reaching a cli- max. While the city held little strategic value, both sides seemed convinced that this was a contest to see which side could break the other.998


In Germany, the chancellor again discussed China’s involvement in Ukraine. Close to Berlin, at a two-day retreat of the German government, Scholz said on March 5 that China had declared it would not send Russia weapons for its war against Ukraine, suggesting Germany had received bilateral assurances to this end. If China were to aid Russia, this "would have consequences," Scholz said, but he was “relatively


992 Hans von der Burchard, “Scholz urges China to talk to Ukraine, not deliver weapons to Russia,” Politico, March 02, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/germany-olaf-scholz-urges-china-to-talk-to-ukraine-not-deliver-weapons-to-russia-war-zeiten- wende/].


993 Kelly Hooper, “Blinken, Lavrov speak briefly at G-20 meeting,” Politico, March 2, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/news/2023/03/02/blinken-lavrov-speak-briefly-at-g-20-meeting-00085159].


994 Matthew Bodner and Henry Austin, “Putin claims 'terrorist attack' near Ukrainian border; Kyiv denies involvement,” NBC News, March 2, 2023 [https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/russia-claims-ukrainian-sabotage-bryansk-putin-terrorist-attack- rcna73034].


995 Marc Santora, “Ukraine Claims a Drone Strike on a Military Target Inside Russia,” New York Times, March 6, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/06/world/europe/drone-attacks-bryansk-russia.html].


996 James Keaten, “Russian envoy says nuclear powers may clash over Ukraine,” AP, March 2, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/russia-ukraine-war-us-nuclear-un-disarmament-0c7cff508a1c86814bb9b1feeea32b33].


997 Erika Solomon, “Germany’s Scholz Visits Washington Amid Worries Over Ukraine ‘End Game’,” New York Times, March 3, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/03/world/europe/scholz-biden-ukraine-war.html].


998 Carlotta Gall, “Ukrainian Soldiers, Nearly Encircled, Push Russians Back,” New York Times, March 6, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/03/06/world/europe/ukraine-bakhmut-battle.html].

optimistic” that China would refrain from such steps. Von der Leyen, who also attended the retreat, said the EU had “no evidence” regarding lethal supplies from Beijing to Moscow.999


Questions pertaining to China seemed particularly important as much suggested the war was going to be long-lasting. The US intelligence community assessed that the war in Ukraine was not going to end soon. On March 8, Haines told Congress that Russia’s military was unlikely to make “major territorial gains” in 2023, which could present an opportunity for additional nuclear threats. Putin assessed that time worked in his favor and that “prolonging the war” might be “his best remaining pathway to eventu- ally securing Russian strategic interests in Ukraine, even if it takes years.”1000


During the night of March 8-9, Russia launched a massive rocket attack across Ukraine striking critical infrastructure and residential buildings in ten regions. Moscow said the strikes were in retaliation for the alleged Ukrainian incursion into the Bryansk region. Russia used around 80 missiles and 8 drones in its largest attack in weeks, out of which Ukraine intercepted 34 missiles and 4 drones, Ukrainian forces stated. Among the missiles were 6 Kinzhal cruise missiles. Almost half of Kyiv’s residents were left with- out heat, and the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant lost power.1001 On March 9, a Ukrainian military spokesperson noted that Ukraine had no weapons capable of shooting Kinzhals

down. Their use significantly increased the proportion of Russia’s missiles reaching targets. Russia had also fired more ballistic missiles and fewer cruise missiles, which might have also increased the success rate of strikes.1002


Meanwhile, the debate on sending fighter jets to Ukraine continued. On March 9, Slovak Defense Minis- ter Jaroslav Nad said his Polish counterpart had told him that Warsaw would agree to a joint process to hand over MiG-29 jets to Ukraine, adding that the time had come also for Slovakia to take a decision on the matter. The same day, Pawel Szrot, head of the Polish president’s office, stated that Poland would

deliver the fighter jets “in a broader international coalition.”1003


Reactions to the Russian announcement to suspend its New START participation also continued. On March 10, the US State Department confirmed that the US was still sending New START notifications to Russia even though Moscow had stopped sending theirs to Washington on February 28. Accordingly, State Department spokesperson Ned Price said “Russia has not provided any New START notifications since it notified the United States that its purported suspension has taken effect. As the United States ex- plores next steps, we remain in full compliance with the treaty.”1004


999 Gabriel Rinaldi and Hans von der Burchard, “Germany’s Scholz says China ‘declared it will not deliver’ weapons to Russia,” Po- litico, March 5, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/china-ukraine-war-russia-weapon-deliveries-scholz-putin-zelenskyy-xi- jinping/].


1000 Amanda Macias, “U.S. intel chiefs warn Putin is expanding his nuclear weapons arsenal as the war in Ukraine drags on,” CNBC, March 8, 2023 [https://www.cnbc.com/2023/03/08/us-intel-chiefs-warn-putin-is-becoming-more-reliant-on-nuclear-weap- ons.html]. See also Senate Hearing, March 8, 2023 [https://www.intelligence.senate.gov/hearings/open-hearing-worldwide- threats-3].


1001 Hanna Arhirova and Elena Becatoros, “Russian missile barrage slams into Ukrainian cities,” AP, March 9, 2023 [https://ap- news.com/article/ukraine-russia-war-kyiv-odesa-kharkiv-40714ec02d628a95458594da6ba8a80e].


1002 John Ismay, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer, “Questions surround Russia’s use of hypersonic missiles in its latest attack,” New York Times, March 9, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/09/world/europe/hypersonic-missiles-russia- ukraine.html].


1003 “Slovak defence minister says time to decide on sending MiG-29s to Ukraine,” Reuters, March 9, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/slovak-defence-minister-says-time-decide-sending-mig-29-jets-ukraine-2023-03-09/].


1004 Alexander Ward and Matt Berg, “What HFAC’s McCaul wants from State,” Politico, March 10, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/03/10/what-hfacs-mccaul-wants-from-state-00086528].

In mid-March, a collision between Russian fighter jets and a US drone caught international attention. On March 14, a Russian fighter jet collided with a US MQ-9 Reaper drone, marking the first time one of these aerial intercepts “resulted in a splashing of one of our drones,” according to NSC spokesperson Kirby.
