The drone was making a routine flight in international airspace, and Washington had not consid- ered it necessary to advise Russia in advance of such flights, as they had been going on for more than a year, Kirby noted. Prior to the collision, two Su-27 warplanes had dumped jet fuel on the drone and flew in front of it in a “reckless, environmentally unsound and unprofessional manner,” US European Com- mand stated, adding that these “aggressive actions by Russian aircrew are dangerous and could lead to miscalculation and unintended escalation.” One of the Russian aircrafts then struck the drone’s propel- ler, which led the Reaper to crash into the Black Sea, stated Air Force General James Hecker, com- mander of US Air Forces Europe, further stressing that “US and Allied aircraft will continue to operate in international airspace and we call on the Russians to conduct themselves professionally and safely.”

Hecker added that the collision followed “a pattern of dangerous actions” involving US and allied aircraft and Russian planes. Price said the US ambassador in Moscow had voiced concerns to the Russian For- eign Ministry. The US State Department summoned Anatoly Antonov, the Russian ambassador in Wash- ington. A State Department spokesperson stated that Antonov met with Assistant Secretary for Euro- pean and Eurasian Affairs Karen Donfried “to discuss Russia’s unsafe and unprofessional operations over the Black Sea, which resulted in the downing today of an unmanned US aircraft.”1005


In turn, Antonov said the drone had been conducting “unacceptable” activity in Russia’s vicinity, claim- ing that the drone had been collecting data and passing it to Ukraine to enable it to conduct strikes on Russian territory.1006 Following the meeting with Donfried on March 14, Antonov further described the US drone flight as a “provocation” and argued that there was no reason for US military aircraft and war- ships to be near Russia’s border. He insisted that the Russian warplanes did not hit the US drone or fire their weapons, adding that Moscow wanted “pragmatic” ties with Washington and stating “we don’t want any confrontation between the US and Russia.”1007


Accordingly, the Russian Defense Ministry stated the US drone was flying over the Black Sea near Cri- mea and intruded in an area that was declared off limits by Russia as part of what it called its “special military operation” in Ukraine, causing the military to scramble fighters to intercept it. “As a result of a sharp maneuver, the MQ-9 drone went into unguided flight with a loss of altitude and crashed into the water,” the statement read. “The Russian fighters didn’t use their weapons, didn’t come into contact with the unmanned aerial vehicle, and they safely returned to their base.”1008


Russian posturing continued at the highest levels. On the same March 14, Putin visited an aviation pro-

duction plant and stated that Western states were seeking to “improve their geopolitical standing” in

Ukraine, but Moscow was fighting for the “existence of Russian statehood.” He said: “For us, it’s not a ge- opolitical task,” but “it’s the task of survival of Russian statehood and the creation of conditions for the

future development of our country” – he did, however, not mention any means by which he thought to


1005 Nahal Toosi and Lawrence Ukenye, “Russian jet’s collision with U.S. drone sparks diplomatic flurry,” Politico, March 14, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/03/14/prussian-jet-collides-with-u-s-drone-00086994].


1006 Elena Becatoros and Darlene Superville, “US and Russia ratchet up rhetoric over downing of drone,” AP, March 15, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-russia-war-drone-pentagon-9f4b3e8fdd719c0fa91a0683228b9e51].


1007 Karl Ritter, “US says Russian warplane hits American drone over Black Sea,” AP, March 15, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/ukraine-russia-war-kramatorsk-peace-plan-fde09a8ea4d9b692637ad8f76cd05f3a].


1008 Karl Ritter, “US says Russian warplane hits American drone over Black Sea,” AP, March 15, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/ukraine-russia-war-kramatorsk-peace-plan-fde09a8ea4d9b692637ad8f76cd05f3a].

wage such struggle.1009 During the same visit, Putin announced that the Russian Ministry of Industry and Trade had prepared a list of unspecified workers who could defer military service. Such steps could potentially signal his priority of high-quality weapons production over having skilled soldiers fight in Russia’s military, some analysts noted.1010


Also on March 14, Peskov stated, after welcoming a Chinese peace proposal, that Kyiv’s refusal to talk left Moscow with only military options. “We must achieve our goals,” he stated, “given the current stance of the Kyiv regime, now it’s only possible by military means.”1011 On the next day, March 15, Peskov noted that US-Russia relations were “at their lowest point, in a very lamentable state,” with the collision being the latest manifestation of loosening ties. He added, however, that “at the same time, Russia has never refused constructive dialogue, and is not refusing it now.”1012


Also on March 15, Patrushev said on Russian state TV Rossiya 1 that Russia would try to recover the wreckage of the American MQ-9 in the Black Sea to study it.1013


The Biden Administration showed itself unimpressed by Russian posturing. On the same day, March 15,

Austin reiterated that the US would “continue to fly and to operate wherever international law allows it,” adding that it was “incumbent upon Russia to operate its military aircraft in a safe and professional

manner.” He further called the incident “a pattern of aggressive and risky, and unsafe actions by Russian pilots in international airspace.”1014 The same day, Austin also had a rare phone call with his Russian counterpart Shoigu. At a Pentagon briefing, Austin stated that as he had “said repeatedly,” it was “im- portant that great powers be models of transparency and communication, and the United States will continue to fly and to operate wherever international law allows.” According to the Russian Ministry of Defense, Shoigu countered that the incident was caused by the US noncompliance with a flight re- striction zone declared by Russia, with the ministry statement further calling US drone flights off the

coast of Crimea “provocative in nature.” Also on March 15, Milley spoke with Gerasimov, discussing “several security-related issues of concern,” according to a Pentagon spokesperson. The two men had last spoken in October 2022.1015


Meanwhile, the discussion about providing Ukraine with fighter jets continued. On March 14, Polish PM

Mateusz Morawiecki stated that Poland could give Ukraine MiG-29 fighter jets in the coming for to six


1009 Ivan Nechepurenko, “Putin claims the West is trying to ‘pull apart’ Russia,” New York Times, March 15, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/03/15/world/europe/putin-claims-the-west-is-trying-to-pull-apart-russia.html].

1011 Karl Ritter, “US says Russian warplane hits American drone over Black Sea,” AP, March 15, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/ukraine-russia-war-kramatorsk-peace-plan-fde09a8ea4d9b692637ad8f76cd05f3a].


1012 “Kremlin: relations with US in dire state amid drone incident,” Reuters, March 15, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/kremlin-relations-with-us-dire-state-amid-drone-incident-2023-03-15/].


1013 Alexander Ward and Matt Berg, “Senators want to force admin talk on Saudi ties,” Politico, March 15, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/03/15/senators-want-to-force-admin-talk-on-saudi-ties-00087156]; Rob

Picheta, “A spat between the US and Russia over a downed drone is escalating. Here’s what you need to know,” CNN, March 16, 2023 [https://edition.cnn.com/2023/03/15/europe/reaper-drone-russia-us-ukraine-explainer-intl/index.html].


1014 Alexander Ward and Matt Berg, “Senators want to force admin talk on Saudi ties,” Politico, March 15, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/03/15/senators-want-to-force-admin-talk-on-saudi-ties-00087156].


1015 Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt, “The Pentagon chief says he spoke to his Russian counterpart about the drone incident,” New York Times, March 15, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/03/16/world/russia-ukraine-news?smid=nytcore-ios- share&referringSource=articleShare#pentagon-chief-russia-drone-incident].

weeks.1016 On March 15, Polish government spokesman Mueller noted that some other countries also had pledged MiGs to Kyiv.1017


The US Administration sought to avoid the jets discussion, but promised on March 15 to “fully and quickly” provide Ukraine with the weapons it needed for a spring counteroffensive against Russia. Aus- tin stated that the allies “must provide Ukraine with the full capabilities for the fight ahead,” adding that he was “confident that we will continue to step up to meet Ukraine’s needs into the spring and well be- yond.” Pentagon leaders said on the same day that the equipment and training being provided would enable Ukraine to win the war – where and when it chose to do so. “The increased Ukrainian capability will allow the Ukrainian leadership to develop and execute a variety of options in the future, to achieve their objectives and bring this war to a successful conclusion,” Milley said, further noting that: “We’re generating combat power, to a degree that we believe that it will provide them opportunities to change the dynamics on the battlefield, at some point going forward, whatever point that is.”1018


Also on March 15, Lithuanian vice FM Meilunas said that Ukraine had to be supplied with more weap- ons, stressing that “the best solution would be to find possibilities to increase production in NATO mem- ber states.”1019


The following day, on March 16, Polish President Duda said that Poland planned to give Ukraine about a dozen MiG-29 fighter jets, adding that Warsaw would hand over four of the Soviet-made warplanes “within the next few days.” However, it remained unclear how this would unfold. On the same day, Polish defense minister Mariusz Blaszczak said Poland wanted “to hand over MIGs in a broader coali- tion” with neighboring Slovakia and perhaps other countries. The German government appeared caught off guard, with Pistorius stating on the same day that so far everyone had “agreed that it’s not the time to send fighter jets,” adding that he had not yet received any confirmation from Poland that this had changed. The White House called Poland’s move a sovereign decision and lauded the Poles for continu- ing to “punch above their weight” in assisting Kyiv. However, US officials also stressed that Poland’s ac- tions would not have any bearing on Biden. “There’s no change in our view with respect to fighter air- craft at this time,” Kirby said.1020 One day later, on March 17, the Slovak government said it would send 13 MIG-29 warplanes to Ukraine – however, most of the jets had to be used for spare parts, as they were not in working order. “Promises must be kept,” acting PM Eduard Heger noted, but did not specify the timing of any deliveries. In response, the Russian embassy in Bratislava contended that such trans-

1019 Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt, “Ukraine Burns Through Ammunition in Bakhmut, Putting Future Fights at Risk,” New York Times, March 16, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/16/world/europe/ukraine-ammunition-bakh- mut.html].


1020 “Poland to be 1st NATO member to give Ukraine fighter jets,” AP, March 16, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-po- land-russia-war-jets-migs-6d843ccbd50fef5f96091a5bff8f3e01]; Andrew Higgins and Lara Jakes, “Poland Says It Will Arm Ukraine With Warplanes, Raising Stakes,” New York Times, March 16, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/16/world/eu- rope/ukraine-poland-planes.html].

fers would be illegal, “explicitly” prohibited by Russian-Slovak agreements. In Moscow, Peskov com- mented that these deliveries would be “subject to destruction” and that Poland or Slovakia wanted “to dispose of their old unnecessary equipment this way.”1021


Meanwhile, concerning Russian arms supplies, media revealed on March 16, that between June and De- cember 2022, Beijing-connected Chinese companies had sent Russian entities 1000 assault rifles and other equipment that could be used for military purposes, including drone parts and body armor. State- owned China North Industries Group Corporation Limited sent the CQ-A rifles to the Russian company Tekhkrim in June 2022. In late 2022, Russian entities received 12 shipments of drone parts by Chinese companies and over 12 tons of Chinese body armor, routed via Turkey, media reported. China was thus supplying Russia with previously unreported “dual-use” equipment. In reaction to these revelations, a spokesperson of the Chinese embassy in Washington stated that Beijing was “committed to promot- ing talks for peace” in Ukraine, adding that “China did not create the crisis. It is not party to the crisis, and has not provided weapons to either side of the conflict.” Also in reaction to the revelations, Poland’s Ambassador to the EU Sadoś said that “due to the potential very serious consequences, such infor- mation should be verified immediately.”1022


In Washington, US military assessments mirrored earlier pronouncements. Speaking for a podcast re- cording in mid-March, Milley repeated his earlier assessment on Ukraine, saying that it would be “ex- tremely difficult” for Kyiv to force out all Russian troops in 2023. It was “not impossible,” but “extremely difficult.” Hence, “in the world of probabilities,” he did not think it was “likely.” Neither side could

“achieve their political objectives through military means, and that state of nature will exist for some

period of time,” he said.1023


During the second half of March, the focus was on Xi’s visit to Russia, the UK sending depleted uranium shells to Ukraine, and Putin’s announcement to station tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus.

On March 17, the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Putin for his alleged role in illegally transferring Ukrainian civilians into Russian territories. In response, Moscow dismissed the warrant as meaningless, as Russia was not a party to the ICC. Medvedev alluded the ICC warrant could only be used as toilet paper. Biden noted that Putin had “clearly committed war crimes” and the ICC warrant made a “very strong point.”1024


1021 Andrew Higgins, “Slovakia follows Poland in pledging warplanes for Ukraine, but most of its jets are in disrepair,” New York Times, March 17, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/17/world/europe/slovakia-ukraine-jets-mig29.html] and “Slo- vakia’s transfer of Soviet-, Russian-made weapons to Kiev illegal — Russian embassy,” TASS, March 17, 2023 [https://tass.com/defense/1590301].


1022 Erin Banco and Sarah Anne Aarup, “‘Hunting rifles’ — really? China ships assault weapons and body armor to Russia,” Politico, March 16, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/03/16/chinese-rifles-body-armor-russia-ukraine-00087398].


1023 Daniel Lippman et al, “How the Iraq war changed top Biden officials,” Politico, March 20, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily]. Also, “How the War in Ukraine Ends: A conversation with General Mark Milley,” None of the Above, March 21, 2023 [https://soundcloud.com/noneoftheaboveegfpodcast/how-the-war-in-ukraine-ends-a].


1024 Nicolas Camut, “ICC issues arrest warrant for Putin over child deportations from Ukraine,” Politico, March 17, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/icc-arrest-warrant-vladimir-putin-war-crimes-ukraine/]. Also, Mark Landler, “Arrest Warrant From Criminal Court Pierces Putin’s Aura of Impunity,” New York Times, Mach 17, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/03/17/world/europe/icc-putin-ukraine-war.html].

Putin visited Sevastopol in Crimea on March 18.1025 On March 19, he visited Mariupol, in what ap- peared to be a gesture of defiance.1026


Xi met Putin at the Kremlin on March 20, the highest-profile leader to visit Russia since the invasion.

The Russian leader pledged to study China’s peace proposal for Ukraine “with respect,” while Xi did not mention Ukraine at all in his public remarks. Putin said that China took a “fair and balanced position on the majority of international problems.” Xi hailed the two nations as “good neighbors and reliable part- ners.”1027 In Washington, Blinken noted that Xi’s visit suggested China felt “no responsibility to hold the Kremlin accountable for the atrocities committed in Ukraine” and “would rather provide diplomatic

cover for Russia to continue to commit those very crimes.” Blinken was skeptical of China’s mediation efforts, noting that a cease-fire that did not remove Russia’s forces from Ukraine “would effectively be supporting the ratification of Russian conquest.” The fundamental element of any plan to end the

fighting had to be “upholding the sovereignty and territory of Ukraine.”1028


Diverting some attention away from Xi’s visit and offering a strong signal of Japanese solidarity with Ukraine, on March 21, Japanese PM Kishida visited Kyiv after having met with Modi in New Delhi.1029 On March 21, media reported that China has shipped more than $12 million in drones and drone parts to Russia since it invaded Ukraine, according to official Russian customs data from a third-party data provider. The shipments often came through small-time middlemen and exporters. The result was a steady supply of new drones to Russia that it can use in its war against Ukraine.1030


175.

De-escalatory

On the second day of Xi’s visit to Moscow, March 21, Russia and China released a joint statement. With respect to nuclear policy, the statement could potentially be seen as de-escalatory, as Russia and China reaffirmed that “a nuclear war cannot be won and should not be fought.” Observers believed the statement had been included at China’s request. However, Moscow and Beijing called on all P5 nu- clear-armed states to “reduce the risk of nuclear war and avoid any armed conflict between nuclear- weapon states.” Also, the statement came short of restating Chinese opposition to the use of nuclear

threats.1031


With respect to Ukraine, the statement brought Beijing close to Moscow’s position. It started from the premise that both sides opposed “any countries or national blocs jeopardizing the reasonable security interests of other nations in the quest for military, political or other forms of superiorities.” Thus, it

noted that a resolution of the Ukraine “crisis” should “respect all countries’ reasonable security concerns


1025 Shashank Bengali and Victoria Kim “Putin Visits Occupied Crimea, a Day After War-Crimes Warrant,” New York Times, March 18, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/18/world/europe/ukraine-grain-deal-un-russia.html].


1026 Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrés R. Martínez, “Defiant Putin Visits Mariupol, a City Razed by Russian Forces,” New York Times, March 19, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/19/world/europe/putin-mariupol-crimea- ukraine.html].

1028 Michael Crowley, “Blinken Says Xi’s Visit to Moscow Offers ‘Diplomatic Cover’ for Putin’s War Crimes,” New York Times, March 20, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/20/world/europe/blinken-xi-russia-war-crimes.html].


1029 Ben Dooley and Victoria Kim, “Japan’s Prime Minister Becomes Latest G7 Leader to Visit Ukraine,” New York Times, March 21, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/21/world/europe/japan-kishida-ukraine.html].


1030 Paul Mozur, Aaron Krolik and Keith Bradsher, “As War in Ukraine Grinds On, China Helps Refill Russian Drone Supplies,” New York Times, March 21, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/21/business/russia-china-drones-ukraine-war.html].


1031 The statement is available in Chinese here [https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/zyxw/202303/t20230322_11046188.shtml].

and prevent the formation of bloc confrontation.” They urged NATO to abide by its commitments as a regional and defensive organization, and called on NATO to respect the sovereignty, security, interests as well as diversity of civilizations, history and culture of other countries, and treat their peaceful devel- opment in an objective and fair manner. Against this background, Russia reiterated “efforts to resume peace talks as soon as possible, which [were] praised by the Chinese side,” said the statement. “Russia welcomes China’s willingness to play a constructive role in resolving the Ukraine crisis through political and diplomatic means.” However, the statement did not mention Chinese military support for Russia or any Russian intention to support a ceasefire or withdraw Russian troops.1032


Overall, the meeting served to strengthen the bilateral relations between China and Russia, and both parties appeared to think it had been a success. After the state dinner on March 21, as the leaders bid

farewell, Xi told Putin that “right now there are changes, the like of which we haven’t seen for 100 years.

And we are the ones driving these changes together.”1033


Months later, Western and Chinese officials leaked to the press that Xi had personally warned Putin against using nuclear weapons in Ukraine. During spring and summer 2023, Chinese officials privately took credit for convincing the leadership in Moscow to give up on veiled nuclear threats. Senior US offi- cials agreed that Chinese officials were taking credit for “sending the message at every level” in Russia. According to a senior adviser the Chinese government, deterring Putin from using nuclear weapons in

Ukraine had been central to Beijing’s attempt to repair relations to European governments in the after- math of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Russian nuclear use would risk turning Europe against China, the adviser said, while sustained pressure from Beijing to prevent such an act might help improve relations with the continent. 1034


176.

Warning

In Moscow, responding to media reports that Britain would supply Ukraine with shells made with de- pleted uranium for the Challenger 2 battle tank, Shoigu noted on March 21 that “another step has been taken” and there were “fewer and fewer steps” before a potential “nuclear collision” between Russia and the West. In Beijing, Putin said that Russia would be forced to “respond accordingly,” given that the West “collectively” was “already beginning to use weapons with a nuclear component.” In London, a spokesperson of the UK defense ministry responded that Russia was “deliberately

trying to disinform,” as depleted uranium had “nothing to do with nuclear weapons.”1035


Chinese support for Russian policy seemed forthcoming in the aftermath of the bilateral meeting. Chi- nese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang reiterated on March 22 the key tenets of Beijing’s position.

Xi’s visit to Russia was a “journey of friendship, cooperation and peace,” and accused the US of lacking

impartiality and of “fanning the flames” of the conflict by providing weapons to Ukraine to Washington’s

own benefit. Wang reiterated China’s claim that it remained neutral in the conflict, stated that it had “no


1032 Stuart Lau, “Xi, Putin back ‘peace talks’ for Ukraine war — but blame NATO and make no offer to withdraw,” Politico, March 21, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/xi-jinping-vladimir-putin-back-peace-talks-ukraine-war-blame-nato-no-offer-withdraw- china-russia/]. Also “Xi, Putin sign joint statement on deepening comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for the new era,” Xinhua, March 22, 2023 [https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202303/22/WS641a0faaa31057c47ebb5bb7.html].


1033 Valerie Hopkins, Twitter, March 21, 2023 [https://twitter.com/VALERIEinNYT/status/1638299396885315585].


1034 Max Seddon, James Kynge, John Paul Rathbone, and Felicia Schwartz, “Xi Jinping warned Vladimir Putin against nuclear attack in Ukraine,” Financial Times, July 5, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/c5ce76df-9b1b-4dfc-a619-07da1d40cbd3].


1035 Dan Sabbagh and Ian Sample, “Putin says Russia ‘will respond’ if UK supplies depleted uranium shells to Ukraine,” Guardian, March 21, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/mar/21/putin-says-russia-will-respond-if-uk-supplies-depleted- uranium-shells-to-ukraine]. Also, “Russia's Putin blasts UK move to send ammo with depleted uranium to Ukraine,” Reuters, March 21, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-blasts-uk-move-send-ammo-with-depleted-uranium-ukraine-2023- 03-21/].

selfish motives on the Ukraine issue,” and stressed that what China had done was promoting peace talks. He underlined that China would “continue to play a constructive role in promoting a political settlement of the Ukraine issue.” In other comments on Ukraine, Wang said Russia and China had agreed that the UN Charter had to be observed and international law respected, and that they opposed unilateral sanc- tions imposed by the US and others to economically punish Putin and his supporters. He further under- lined that “the two sides pointed out that the solution to the Ukraine crisis must respect the legitimate security concerns of all countries and prevent the formation of bloc confrontation and fanning flames,” with “responsible dialogue” being “the best way to solve the issue steadily.”1036


Just hours after Xi concluded the state visit, Russia launched a new wave of missile and drone attacks across Ukraine, shelling residential buildings in the south and killing seven people in a school dormitory in the Kyiv region.1037


Also on March 22, Slovak defense minister Jaro Nad noted that Washington offered to sell Slovakia a dozen new Bell AH-1Z Viper helicopters at a discount after the country sent its retired MiG fighter jets to Ukraine. Slovakia had not yet approved the deal. The deal would be “hugely advantageous” to Slovakia, Nad said, as it included parts, training and some 500 AGM-114 Hellfire II missiles.1038


177.

Warning

Concomitantly, nuclear warnings re-surfaced in Moscow. On the same March 22, Ryabkov said that the risk of a nuclear conflict was “higher than anything we have had for the past few decades,” noted that Russia was committed to keeping the world “safe and free” from the threat of nuclear war, but warned that Moscow was in a “de-facto” open conflict with Washington over Ukraine. Speaking at an event entitled “A World Without START: What’s Next,” Ryabkov said there was “no question” of Mos- cow restoring the treaty for now, criticizing Washington's “hostile course” in “practically all domains” towards Russia. Various Russian experts at the event agreed with Ryabkov that arms control was a “phenomenon associated with peace,” and that a return to New START involved not just negotiations

over Ukraine, but “a change of the hostile approach of the United States towards Russia.”1039


Responding to Russia’s accusations on the same day, Cleverley said depleted uranium shells were not nuclear munitions. Putin was uttering “threats” every time London or NATO were seeking to support Ukraine in its defense. “There is no nuclear escalation. The only country in the world that is talking

about nuclear issues is Russia, the British foreign secretary said.”1040 On the same day, the Russian MFA

said in a statement that Moscow would not leave “unanswered” Britain’s decision to supply Ukraine


1036 “China calls Xi’s Russia visit one of friendship, peace,” AP, March 22, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/china-russia-putin-xi- us-ukraine-war-fcfd22eb1f48b3de6f115c2943c77169].


1037 Jared Malsin, “Russia Launches Attacks Across Ukraine, Killing Seven in School Dormitory,” Wall Street Journal, March 22, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/russia-fires-armed-drones-across-ukraine-killing-three-in-school-dormitory- aae731d6?mod=world_lead_story].


1038 Jaro Nad’, “Jaro Nad’ - minister obrany SR”, Facebook, March 22, 2023 [https://www.facebook.com/JaroNadPub- lic/posts/pfbid02eH9pApr2U5Gk4J2T1NqRRkYQNSGaiA36E17pALrkvDEUzgFC8gBkeavaZUL5g2iYl].


1039 Caleb Davis, “Russia says risk of nuclear conflict at highest level in decades,” Reuters, March 22, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/russia-says-risk-nuclear-conflict-highest-level-decades-2023-03-22/]. See also “Ничто не вечно под войной,” Kommersant, March 22. 2023 [https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/5888929].


1040 Dan Milmo, “UK says 'no nuclear escalation' in supplying depleted uranium shells to Ukraine,” Guardian, March 22, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/22/russia-ukraine-war-live-imf-and-ukraine-agree-15bn-funding-deal- us-rejects-chinas-impartiality-claim?page=with:block-641ae8998f0889459a75fd60#block-641ae8998f0889459a75fd60].

with such tank shells, and Lavrov noted that London’s actions were taking the situation to a “new dan- gerous level.”1041


Against this contentious background, Kyiv again signaled that it needed more military support. On March 23, Zelensky, speaking virtually to a EU heads of state gathering, pleaded for more support. He said Ukraine needed long-range missiles and modern fighter jets. In their joint statement, EU leaders urged “all countries not to provide material or other support for Russia’s war of aggression,” a message clearly directed at China. They also approved supplying Kyiv with one million rounds of ammunition for artillery over the next year.1042


The first 4 of the 13 MIG-29s Slovakia had pledged to send to Ukraine had been delivered, and the re- maining would arrive in the coming weeks, the Slovak defense ministry said on the same March 23.1043


178.

Escalatory

Also on March 23, in Moscow, Medvedev brought nuclear saber-rattling back to the forefront. The

threat of a nuclear conflict “hasn’t decreased, it has grown,” he said. “Every day when they provide

Ukraine with foreign weapons brings the nuclear apocalypse closer,” Medvedev added. Russia’s rela- tions with the West were “already worse than they [had] ever been in history,” he claimed. In addi- tion, he moved from warning to escalation by blasting German justice minister Marco Bushmann, who had said that Putin would be arrested on the ICC’s warrant if he visited Germany. “Let’s imagine […] the leader of a nuclear power visits the territory of Germany and is arrested,” Medvedev said,

adding that it would amount to a declaration of war against Russia. “In this case, our assets will fly to hit the Bundestag, the chancellor’s office and so on.” Also, he claimed that Russia’s nuclear forces had provided a strong deterrent amid the fighting in Ukraine. “We would have been torn to pieces without them.” Hence, it was “useless to have talks” with the West. Last but not least, he questioned Ukraine’s very existence. “Honestly speaking, Ukraine is part of Russia. But due to geopolitical reasons and the course of history we had tolerated that we were living in separate quarters and had been forced to

acknowledge those invented borders for a long time,” he said.1044


1041 “Russia warns of 'serious consequences' if UK supplies depleted uranium shells to Ukraine,” Guardian, March 23, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/22/russia-ukraine-war-live-imf-and-ukraine-agree-15bn-funding-deal- us-rejects-chinas-impartiality-claim?page=with:block-641b0e1f8f0823818506b22e].


1042 Monika Pronczuk “E.U. leaders give final approval to sending a million artillery shells to Ukraine,” New York Times, March 23, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/03/23/world/russia-ukraine-news/eu-leaders-gather-to-discuss-aid-to-ukraine-as- kyivs-military-demands-grow?smid=url-share]. See also “European Council conclusions on Ukraine,” Website of the European Council, March 23, 2023 [https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2023/03/23/european-council-conclu- sions-on-ukraine/].


1043 Anushka Patil “Slovakia makes its first delivery of pledged Soviet-era fighter jets to Ukraine,” New York Times, March 24, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/03/23/world/russia-ukraine-news]. Also, “Prvé Štyri Stíhacie Lietadlá Mig-29 Sú Už Na Ukrajine,” Website of the Slovak Defense Ministry, March 23, 2023 [https://www.mosr.sk/52653-sk/prve-styri-stihacie-lietadla- mig-29-su-uz-na-ukrajine/].


1044 Vladimir Isachenkov, “Russia’s security chief blasts West, dangles nuclear threats,” AP, March 23, 2023 [https://ap- news.com/article/medvedev-nuclear-putin-arrest-warrant-germany-ukraine-6dcde92e06f41a7c5cb7386f7939df33].

Spain’s prime minister Pedro Sánchez said also on March 23 he would discuss a peace plan for Ukraine with Xi during an official visit to China the subsequent week – a “stable and lasting peace” that guaran- teed Ukraine’s “territorial integrity” that was being “violated by Russia.” Two days later, on March 25,

he added that he would push for a “fair and lasting” peace.1045


Concerning European diplomatic and economic ties with China, on March 24 in Brussels, Borrell said the “friendship” between China and Russia had limits, and that Europe should welcome any attempts by Beijing to distance itself from Moscow’s war in Ukraine. He said China had “not crossed any red lines for us” – it had forged close economic and diplomatic ties, but not a military alliance with Russia.1046


179.

Warning

On March 24, Medvedev repeated his nuclear warnings. He said Moscow was readying for a Ukrain- ian counteroffensive that “everyone knows” Kyiv was preparing for, adding that the Russian General Staff “calculates this and prepares its decisions.” If Ukraine attempted to retake Crimea, Moscow was ready to use “absolutely any weapons,” including those mentioned in Russia’s nuclear doctrine when the very existence of the state was threatened. An attempt to split away territory meant “an encroach- ment on the existence of the state,” Medvedev said. He hoped Russia’s “friends across the ocean” un- derstood this. However, he also noted that he thought statements about the return of Crimea to

Ukraine were mere propaganda.1047


On March 26, Putin stated that Russia was “not creating any military alliance with China.” He confirmed that “yes, we have cooperation in the sphere of military-technical interaction,” stressing Russia was “not hiding this. Everything is transparent, there is nothing secret.” He added that “for decades many have desired turning China against the Soviet Union and Russia, and vice versa,” also accusing the US and NATO of seeking to build a new global “axis” that he said bore some resemblance to the World War Two alliance between Nazi Germany, fascist Italy and imperial Japan. Putin named Australia, New Zealand and South Korea as being in line to join a “global NATO” and referenced a defense agreement signed by Britain and Japan earlier in 2023.1048


As Russia agreed to extend the Black Sea grain deal, Erdoğan called Putin on March 26 to thank him for his “positive attitude.” The two leaders discussed developments regarding the war in Ukraine, and Erdoğan expressed the importance of ending the conflict through negotiations as soon as possible.1049


1045 José Bautista, “Spain’s prime minister plans to visit Beijing for talks on China’s contentious peace proposal,” New York Times, March 23, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/23/world/europe/spain-sanchez-china-xi-ukraine.html], and Paul Mathi- asen “Spain's PM Sanchez to push for 'territorial integrity' for Ukraine in China visit,” Reuters, March 26, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/spains-pm-sanchez-push-territorial-integrity-ukraine-china-visit-2023-03-26/].


1046 “EU's Borrell: Russia-China partnership has limits,” Reuters, March 24, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/eus-borrell- russia-china-partnership-has-limits-2023-03-24/].


1047 Pjotr Sauer, “Russian forces preparing for Ukrainian counteroffensive, says Medvedev,” Guardian, March 24, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/mar/24/russian-forces-preparing-ukrainian-counteroffensive-dmitry-medvedev]. See “Киев готовится к наступательным операциям, заявил Медведев,” RIA Novosti, March 24, 2023 [https://ria.ru/20230324/nastuplenie-1860329473.html] and “Медведев: попытка Украины отвоевать Крым даст основание РФ к применению любого оружия,” TASS, March 24, 2023 [https://tass.ru/politika/17360995].


1048 Alexander Marrow, “Russia, China are not creating military alliance, Putin says,” Reuters, March 26, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/putin-russia-china-not-creating-military-alliance-agencies-2023-03-26/]. “Ukraine war live. Russia and China 'not creating a military alliance' - Putin,” Guardian, March 26, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/mar/26/russia-ukraine-war-live-us-reacts-cautiously-to-russias-plan-to-station-tactical-nuclear- weapons-in-belarus?page=with:block-641fc7af8f0893440cca17aa&filterKeyEvents=false].


1049 “Putin and Erdogan held phone call, discussed grain deal,” Reuters, March 26, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/mar/26/russia-ukraine-war-live-us-reacts-cautiously-to-russias-plan-to-station-tactical-nuclear- weapons-in-belarus?page=with:block-641fc7af8f0893440cca17aa&filterKeyEvents=false]; “Ukraine war live. US responds to Rus-

180.

Warning

In what was the most mediatized Russian nuclear pronouncement of the month, on March 26, Putin suggested to a journalist that Russia would deploy nuclear weapons to Belarus by the summer. In re- sponse to a question focused on Britain’s decision to send weapons containing depleted uranium to Ukraine, Putin condemned the British move and then said he was moving ahead with a plan, first re- vealed last year, to give Russia the ability to base nuclear weapons in Belarus. Ten Belarusian jets had already been retrofitted to carry Russian nuclear weapons. A storage facility for the warheads would be ready by July 1. The Russian leader insisted this decision was “nothing unusual” as Washington

had been “doing this for decades.” Putin also stated that Belarusian President Lukashenko had agreed to the deployment, and insisted that such a move would not violate nuclear nonproliferation agree- ments. Russia was replicating the US practice of nuclear sharing and would remain in control of

weapons placed in Belarus.1050


Western officials condemned Putin’s remarks. On March 26, NATO spokesperson Oana Lungescu called Putin’s rhetoric “dangerous and irresponsible,” but noted that the Alliance had not registered any changes that would have prompted it to adjust its posture. Lungescu further called Russia’s reference to NATO’s nuclear sharing “totally misleading,” since NATO allies would “act with full respect of their inter- national commitments,” while Russia had “consistently broken its arms control commitments.”1051


The foreign ministry of Ukraine condemned the remarks, claimed that basing nuclear weapons would violated the NPT, and called for an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council. It further called

Putin’s rhetoric “another provocative step” that undermined “the international security system as a whole,” with the statement also calling for members of the international community to convey to the Russian regime “the categorical unacceptability of its next nuclear provocations and to take decisive measures to effectively deter and prevent any possibility of the aggressor state’s use of nuclear weap-

ons.”1052 The secretary of Ukraine’s National Security and Defense Council, Oleksiy Danilov, stated Rus- sia was holding Minsk as a “nuclear hostage,” adding that the move was “a step towards the internal de- stabilization of the country.” 1053 Ukrainian presidential aid Podolyak accused Putin of violating the nuclear-proliferation treaty and resorting to “scare” tactics.1054


sia plan to station nuclear weapons in Belarus,” Guardian, March 26, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/mar/26/russia-ukraine-war-live-us-reacts-cautiously-to-russias-plan-to-station-tactical-nuclear- weapons-in-belarus?page=with:block-641fc7af8f0893440cca17aa&filterKeyEvents=false].


1050 Anton Troianovski, Vivek Shankar and Andrew Higgins, “Putin Says He Could Put Tactical Nuclear Weapons in Belarus by Sum- mer,” New York Times, March 26, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/world/europe/russia-ukraine-putin-bela- rus.html]. David Ljunggren, “Putin says Moscow to place nuclear weapons in Belarus, US reacts cautiously,” Reuters, March 26, 2022 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/putin-says-moscow-has-deal-with-belarus-station-nuclear-weapons-there-tass- 2023-03-25/]. Jones Hayden, “Putin says Russia to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus,” Politico, March 25, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/putin-says-russia-to-deploy-tactical-nuclear-weapons-in-belarus-reports/]; and “Putin an- nounces deal with Belarus to station nuclear weapons there,” NBC News, March 26, 2023 [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fdm7kN7nWLc].


1051 Dan Peleschuk, “NATO criticises Putin's 'dangerous and irresponsible' nuclear rhetoric,” Reuters, March 27, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-security-chief-says-basing-russian-nuclear-weapons-belarus-will-2023-03- 26/].


1052 “Ukraine war live. Kyiv calls Russia's tactical nuclear weapons plans 'another provocative step',” Guardian, March 26, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/26/russia-ukraine-war-live-us-reacts-cautiously-to-russias-plan-to-sta- tion-tactical-nuclear-weapons-in-belarus?filterKeyEvents=false].


1053 Karl Ritter, “Ukraine demands emergency UN meeting over Putin nuclear plan,” AP, March 26, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/russia-ukraine-war-belarus-tactical-nuclear-weapons-3aed32661ae3c218c59117d1ce593777].


1054 “Ukraine war live,” Guardian, March 26, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/26/russia-ukraine-war- live-us-reacts-cautiously-to-russias-plan-to-station-tactical-nuclear-weapons-in-belarus?filterKeyEvents=false].

The same day, the US defense department stated that it had “not seen any reason” to adjust [US] stra- tegic nuclear posture nor any indications Russia [was] preparing to use a nuclear weapon,” adding that Washington remained “committed to the collective defense of the NATO alliance.” Similarly, US NSC spokesman Kirby said the US government had “not seen any indication that [Putin had] made good on this pledge or moved any nuclear weapons around,” further clarifying that Washington had “seen no in- dication he has any intention to use nuclear weapons, period, inside Ukraine.” Washington was monitor- ing the situation daily, but there was nothing that suggested the US to change its strategic deterrent pos- ture.1055 The Chairman of the US House of Representatives Michael McCaul said he regarded Russia’s plan as disturbing and designed to intimidate the West: “I think this is saber-rattling on the part of Putin basically to try to frighten.”1056 Borrell voiced that “Belarus hosting Russian nuclear weapons would mean an irresponsible escalation” and a “threat to European security,” adding that “Belarus can stop it” and that the EU stood “ready to respond with further sanctions.”1057


On March 27, Belarus opposition leader Tsikhanouskaya said the move “grossly” contradicted “the will of the Belarusian people” and reflected the “further subjugation of Belarus under Russian con-

trol.”1058 The same day, German foreign ministry spokesperson Sasse stated that Berlin saw Moscow’s announcement as “another attempt at nuclear intimidation and we consider this rhetoric to be irrespon- sible and expressly reject it.”1059


Also on March 27, Zakharova released a statement meant to respond to the critiques of Putin’s Belarus interview, but the statement did not underpin the most extreme interpretation of the Russian leader’s claims. She called the Western reaction to the development of Russia’s cooperation with Belarus in the military nuclear sphere “inadequate,” and noted that it could not “but cause bewilderment.” She further pointed out that NATO allies had introduced the concept of “joint nuclear missions” themselves, and stated that Washington had “lowered the threshold for the use of nuclear weapons in recent years, shift- ing the focus to limited scenarios for their use.” Zakharova concluded by underlining that Russia had re- served “the right to take the necessary additional steps to ensure the security of Russia and its allies,” but stopped short of giving any indication that Russia indeed intended to deploy nuclear weapons to Belarus.1060


Meanwhile, Western tank deliveries made their way to Ukraine. On March 27, media reported that the 18 Leopard 2 battle tanks promised by Germany had been handed over at the Ukrainian border, with


1055 “Ukraine war live. US sees no indication that Russia moved nuclear weapons to Belarus,” Guardian, March 26, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/26/russia-ukraine-war-live-us-reacts-cautiously-to-russias-plan-to-sta- tion-tactical-nuclear-weapons-in-belarus?filterKeyEvents=false]; and “US Says No Indication Russia Has Moved Nuclear Weapons” Defense Post, March 26, 2023 [https://www.thedefensepost.com/2023/03/26/russia-moving-nuclear-weapons/].


1056 Dan Peleschuk, “NATO criticises Putin's 'dangerous and irresponsible' nuclear rhetoric,” Reuters, March 27, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-security-chief-says-basing-russian-nuclear-weapons-belarus-will-2023-03- 26/].


1057 “Ukraine war live,” Guardian, March 26, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/26/russia-ukraine-war- live-us-reacts-cautiously-to-russias-plan-to-station-tactical-nuclear-weapons-in-belarus?filterKeyEvents=false].


1058 “Ukraine war live,” Guardian, March 27, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/27/russia-ukraine-war- live-nato-criticises-putin-for-dangerous-nuclear-rhetoric-donbas-town-of-avdiivka-post-apocalyptic].


1059 “Regierungspressekonferenz vom 27. März 2023,” German Federal Government, March 27, 2023 [https://www.bundesregie- rung.de/breg-de/suche/regierungspressekonferenz-vom-27-maerz-2023-2173396].


1060 “Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova’s comment on a number of Western countries expressing concern over Rus- sia-Belarus nuclear cooperation,” Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation, March 27, 2023 [https://mid.ru/ru/for- eign_policy/news/1859880/?lang=en].

about 40 Marder infantry fighting vehicles also having reached Ukraine.1061 On March 28, Ukrainian de- fense minister Reznikov said the first British Challenger 2 main battle tanks had arrived in Ukraine and would soon being combat missions.1062


The nuclear debate surrounding a possible nuclear deployment to Belarus continued. Also on March 28, Belarus’s foreign ministry stated that it had been forced to house Russian nuclear weapons on its ter- ritory by the aggressive actions of NATO countries that were threatening Belarus’ own security. Minsk also said the plans to station Russian tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus would not contravene interna- tional non-proliferation agreements as Belarus would not have control over the weapons. The ministry said it was forced to respond because “unilateral coercive measures in politics and the economy are ac- companied by the buildup of military potential in the territory of neighboring countries – NATO mem- bers in close proximity to our borders. Considering these circumstances and the legitimate concerns and risks in the field of national security arising from them, Belarus is taking forced response actions to strengthen its own security and defense capability.” It also noted that Belarus regarded the actions of the West as “direct and gross interference in the internal affairs of an independent state, aimed at chang- ing the geopolitical course and changing the internal political system of Belarus.”1063


Russia continued to explain its position on New START. Lavrov told an interviewer on March 28 that there were no contacts with Washington regarding strategic arms control. For Moscow to resume con- tacts with Washington, the US government had to “amend” its ways and return to “civilized principles of maintaining relations between states.”1064


181.

Warning

The nuclear rhetoric continued in Moscow. In remarks published on March 28, Patrushev, the secre- tary of Russia’s Security Council, warned the US and its allies against harboring hopes for Russia’s de- feat in Ukraine. He alleged that some American politicians believed the US could launch a preventa- tive missile strike on Russia to which Moscow would be unable to respond, a purported belief that he described as “short-sighted stupidity, which is very dangerous.” Patrushev then alluded to Russia’s nuclear potential: “Russia is patient and isn’t trying to scare anyone with its military superiority, but it has unique modern weapons capable of destroying any adversary, including the United States, in

case of a threat to its existence,” he said.1065


New START data provision discussions continued. Reacting to Russia’s announced suspension of New START, the White House on March 28 stated that it would cease exchanging the biannual data update on its nuclear forces following Moscow’s refusal to do so. This was a “proportionate and reversible”


1061 Matthias Gebauer, “Deutsche Leopard-Panzer in der Ukraine angekommen,” Spiegel, March 27, 2023 [https://www.spie- gel.de/politik/deutschland/deutsche-leopard-panzer-in-der-ukraine-angekommen-a-a275a157-d33a-4df0-a43e-bd57a0a7b6f9].


1062 “Ukraine defence minister thanks UK for sending 'fantastic' tanks,” Reuters, March 28, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/ukraine-defence-minister-thanks-uk-sending-fantastic-tanks-2023-03-28/].


1063 Andrew Osborn, “Belarus says it will host Russian nuclear weapons to counter NATO,” Reuters, March 28, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/belarus-says-it-decided-host-russian-nuclear-weapons-after-nato-pressure-2023-03- 28/]; “Ukraine war live: Belarus foreign ministry: country forced to host nuclear missiles due to Nato actions”, Guardian, March 28, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/28/russia-ukraine-war-live-news-updates-multiple-russian-drones- shot-down-over-kyiv-blasts-attack?page=with:block-642297b58f0893440cca2bd5#block-642297b58f0893440cca2bd5].


1064 “Sergey Lavrov’s interview,” Website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation, March 28, 2023 [https://mid.ru/en/foreign_policy/news/1860091/].


1065 Vladimir Isachenkov, “Russia stops sharing missile test info with US, opens drills,” Politico, March 28, 2023 [https://ap- news.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-nuclear-weapons-drills-ea08b851e6e49b99b9fd2366f890ccdf?utm_source=homep- age&utm_medium=TopNews&utm_campaign=position_04].

countermeasure in order to induce Russia to return to compliance, NSC’s Kirby said.1066 The decision had been conveyed to Russia on March 27 by the Pentagon’s Assistant Secretary of Defense for Space Policy John Plumb. “Russia responded that they will not be providing that information,” he told the

House Armed Services’ Strategic Forces subcommittee. “And so as a diplomatic countermeasure, the

United States will not be providing that information back.” The Pentagon would also look into other pos- sible countermeasures, he added, “and what we’re trying to do is balance both responding to Russia’s irresponsible behavior but continuing to demonstrate what we believe [what] a responsible nuclear power’s action should be.”1067 The following day, on March 29, Russia’s deputy foreign minister Ryab- kov stated that Russia had stopped informing the United States about its nuclear activities, including missile test launches. “There will be no notifications at all. All notifications, all kinds of notifications, all activities under the treaty will be suspended and will not be conducted regardless of what position the US may take,” he said. US State Department deputy spokesman Patel said the Biden administration was aware of Ryabkov’s comments but it had not “received any notice indicating a change,” adding that Washington had “across-the-board concerns about Russia’s reckless behavior as it relates to the New START treaty.”1068


The next day, on March 30, Ryabkov reversed his statement, saying that while Moscow had suspended “every kind of information exchange, as well as other elements of verification activity deriving from the New START Treaty within the treaty’s framework,” notifications of ballistic missile launches would con- tinue, in line with a 1988 US-Soviet agreement. “The Russian Federation will still voluntarily honor the principal qualitative limits on strategic weapons set by the treaty, and will continue to fulfill the Ballistic Missile Launch Notification Agreement of 1988,” Ryabkov said.1069


Against this background of New START discussions, on March 29, Russia’s MOD stated that it began exercises with its Yars intercontinental ballistic missile system and several thousand troops in Siberia. “In total, more than 3,000 military personnel and about 300 pieces of equipment are involved in the ex- ercises,” the ministry noted, adding that the movements would involve measures to conceal the deploy- ment from foreign satellites and other intelligence assets. Putin has aimed to make the Yars missile sys- tem, which replaced the Topol system, part of Russia’s “invincible weapons” and the mainstay of the ground-based component of its nuclear arsenal. The Yars missile systems reportedly have an opera- tional range of 11 to 12,000 km, are able to carry multiple independently targetable nuclear warheads and can be mounted on a truck carriers or deployed in silos.1070


1066 Steve Holland and Arshad Mohammed, “US to stop exchanging nuclear data with Russia after Moscow's treaty suspension,” Reuters, March 28, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-will-not-give-moscow-nuclear-data-after-russian-treaty-sus- pension-white-house-2023-03-28/].


1067 Alexander Ward, Matt Berg and Lawrence Ukenye,“‘We should’ve notified you earlier’,” Politico, March 28, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/03/28/we-shouldve-notified-you-earlier-00089151].


1068 “Ukraine war live: Russia has stopped informing the US about its nuclear activities,” Guardian, March 29, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/mar/29/russia-ukraine-war-live-zelenskiy-fears-war-could-be-hampered-by- washington-divisions-moscow-starts-drills-with-new-icbm?page=with:block-64242d578f08531ffe52eaf4#block- 64242d578f08531ffe52eaf4]; Vladimir Isachenkov, “Russia stops sharing missile test info with US, opens drills”, AP, March 29, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-nuclear-weapons-drills- ea08b851e6e49b99b9fd2366f890ccdf?utm_source=homepage&utm_medium=TopNews&utm_campaign=position_04].


1069 Francesca Ebel, „Russia says notifications of ballistic missile launches will continue,“ Washington Post, March 30, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/03/30/russia-nuclear-start-treaty-notifications/], and Vladimir Isachenkov, “Russia to keep missile test notices under Cold War-era deal,” AP, March 30, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia-us-nuclear- start-treaty-test-warnings-5e7efae0ab2d52ece5d5e1e8609152b0].


1070 “Russia starts exercises with Yars intercontinental ballistic missiles,” Reuters, March 29, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/russia-starts-exercises-with-yars-intercontinental-ballistic-missiles-2023-03-29/]; also, Vladimir Isa- chenkov, “Russia stops sharing missile test info with US, opens drills,” AP, March 29, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/russia- ukraine-war-nuclear-weapons-drills-ea08b851e6e49b99b9fd2366f890ccdf?utm_source=homepage&utm_me- dium=TopNews&utm_campaign=position_04].


182.

Warning

Nuclear innuendos continued in Moscow. With reference to Putin announcing to station tactical nu- clear missiles in Belarus, Ryabkov also stated on March 29 that Putin’s move followed the failure by Kyiv’s allies to heed previous “serious signals” from Moscow. He hoped NATO leaders could assess “how serious” the situation was. He lamented that the “serious signals” Russia had sent had only been “scratching the surface” and not “left any external imprint” on NATO’s positions. Russia had to

“reckon with the changing reality." Putin’s statement reflected “an entire range of measures that have been and will be taken.” By ignoring Moscow’s signals, Western elites were “demonstrating their fun- damentally, deeply irresponsible attitude toward their own countries, their own peoples, and toward

international security,” Ryabkov emphasized.1071


Western support for Ukraine remained steady. On the same March 29, the German Bundestag’s budget committee agreed to send an additional €12bn worth of military support to Ukraine, €8bn of which to be spent directly on purchasing weapons and equipment for Ukraine, and €4bn to replenish German military stocks. Pistorius called the aid package “a very, very important step to show how seri- ous we are about our long-term commitment to Ukraine in their fight against Putin.”1072 That same March 29, the Spanish defense minister Robles announced that Spain would send six leopard 2A4 tanks to Ukraine.1073


On the question of providing Ukraine with F-16 fighter jets, Pentagon policy chief Kahl reiterated to sen- ators on March 29 that Western combat aircraft was “currently Ukraine’s seventh priority capability area.” He moreover cautioned that Western fighters would require considerable money to maintain, and could total over $1 billion over three years depending on how many aircraft are provided and in what condition.1074


Meanwhile, IAEA’s Grossi said on March 29 when visiting the Zaporizhzhia NPP that with increased Russian and Ukrainian military forces in southern Ukraine, fighting may soon escalate. He stated it was “obvious that military activity is increasing in the whole region, so every possible measure and precau- tion should be taken so that the plant is not attacked and can be protected.”1075


1071 “Russia hoping that NATO understands gravity of move to deploy nukes in Belarus - diplomat,” TASS, March 29, 2023 [https://tass.com/politics/1596131?utm_source=google.de&utm_medium=organic&utm_campaign=google.de&utm_refer- rer=google.de].


1072 “Germany to send additional 12 billion euros in military support to Ukraine,” Reuters, March 29, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/germany-send-additional-12-billion-euros-military-support-ukraine-2023-03-29/]; Christopher F.

Schuetze, “Germany, stressing its long-term commitment, promises additional military aid to Ukraine,” New York Times, March 29, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/03/29/world/russia-ukraine-news?smid=url-share#germany-stressing-its-long- term-commitment-promises-additional-military-aid-to-ukraine].


1073 “Spain to send six tanks to Ukraine after Easter,” Reuters, March 29, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/spain- send-six-tanks-ukraine-after-easter-2023-03-29/].


1074 “National Security Daily: No Western Warplanes for Ukraine,” Politico, March 29, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newslet- ters/national-security-daily/2023/03/29/the-worlds-mounting-nuclear-problems-00089366].


1075 Matthew Mpoke Bigg, “Russia and Ukraine are ramping up forces in the region of a nuclear complex, the U.N.’s watchdog warns,” New York Times, March 29, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/03/29/world/russia-ukraine-news/russia-and- ukraine-are-ramping-up-forces-in-the-region-of-a-nuclear-complex-the-uns-watchdog-warns?smid=url-share].

On March 30, Kirby stated that Russia was seeking to acquire more munitions from North Korea to bol- ster its war on Ukraine. “We remain concerned that North Korea will provide further support and Rus- sia’s military operations against Ukraine and we have new information that Russia is actively seeking to acquire additional munitions from North Korea,” he said.1076


On March 31, Lavrov stated that Russia faced “existential threats” to its security and development from “unfriendly states” as he presented an updated foreign policy doctrine. The 42-page document set out changes to Russia’s view of the world – in particular its increasingly confrontational relationship with

the West – that had already been repeatedly articulated by Putin. Lavrov said the start of its “special mil- itary operation” in Ukraine had ushered in “revolutionary changes” in world affairs that needed to be

reflected in how Russia could take “symmetric and asymmetric measures in response to unfriendly ac-

tions.” The document named the United States as the main threat to international stability and the

driver of an “anti-Russian line.” But it also said Moscow sought “peaceful coexistence” and a “balance of interests” with Washington. It underlined Russia’s desire to maintain “strategic stability.”1077


In Beijing on March 31, the Xi-Sanchez meeting revealed the gap between China and the West. The Spanish PM encouraged Xi to talk to the Ukrainian leadership and learn first-hand about Kyiv’s peace formula. According to the Chinese readout Xi called for an end to a “Cold War mentality” and to the pres- sure of “extreme” sanctions. China’s stance might potentially have been influenced by von der Leyen’s long-awaited EU positioning on China from a day earlier, March 30, where she had said that China was becoming “more repressive at home and more assertive abroad,” and noted that how China continued to interact with Putin’s war would be a “determining factor” for EU-China relations going forward.1078


183.

Warning

Nuclear rhetoric was also ramped up in Minsk. “Putin and I will decide and introduce here, if neces- sary, strategic weapons, and they must understand this, the scoundrels abroad, who today are trying to blow us up from inside and outside,” Lukashenko said on March 31. “We will protect our sover- eignty and independence by any means necessary, including through the nuclear arsenal.” While Putin had emphasized that Russia would retain control over any tactical nuclear weapons stationed in Belarus, the Belarusian leader noted: “Don’t say we will just be looking after them, and these are not our weapons,” he said. “These are our weapons and they will contribute to ensuring sovereignty and independence,” Lukashenko noted, as the West was “preparing to invade Belarus, to destroy our country.”1079


Despite the bluster in Minsk, diplomats from Belarus took a more constrained approach in New York. A

UN Security Council meeting was convened on March 31 at the initiative of the United States and


1076 Alexander Ward, “Russia seeking munitions from North Korea, Kirby says,” Politico, March 31, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/news/2023/03/30/russia-seeking-munitions-from-north-korea-00089672].


1077 “Russia seeks to balance US, meet ‘existential threats’ in new foreign policy doctrine,” Reuters, March 31, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-seeks-balance-us-meet-existential-threats-new-foreign-policy-doctrine-2023- 03-31/]. See “The Concept of the Foreign Policy of the Russian Federation,” Website of the Russian MFA, March 31, 2023 [https://mid.ru/en/foreign_policy/fundamental_documents/1860586/].


1078 Eduardo Baptista, “In Beijing, Spanish PM urges Xi to speak with Ukraine's Zelenskiy,” Reuters, March 31, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/spanish-pm-says-he-encouraged-chinas-xi-speak-with-zelenskiy-2023-03-31/]. Also, Philip Blenkinsop, “EU must cut risks in ties with 'hardening' China - EU chief,” Reuters, March 30, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/eu-needs-de-risk-ties-with-changing-china-eu-executive-chief-2023-03-30/].


1079 Yuras Karmanau “Russia might put strategic nukes in Belarus, leader says,” AP, March 31, 2022 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/russia-nuclear-weapons-belarus-ukraine-ad058c18a3ff259bcbb64cf61ea6251d] and “Lukashenko: Russia could put intercon- tinental missiles in Belarus if necessary,” Reuters, March 31, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/belarus-lukashenko- says-russian-nuclear-arms-needed-deter-threats-west-2023-03-31/].

Ukraine. Belarus had been forced by “national security risks” to train pilots and modernize aircraft to deliver nuclear weapons, Belarusian diplomats stated. The same risks had spurred the “possible – I em- phasize the possible – deployment of tactical nuclear warheads on the territory of Belarus.” Russia’s en- voy noted that his country would not transfer control over the weapons to Belarus. Almost all UNSC members were critical of Russia’s announcement – even China. “We call for the abolition of the nuclear- sharing arrangements and advocate no deployment of nuclear weapons abroad by all nuclear weapons states, and the withdrawal of nuclear weapons deployed abroad,” said China’s envoy.1080


April 2023: A quiet spring on the nuclear rhetoric front


Western criticism arose as Russia assumed the leadership of the UN Security Council at the beginning of April. Russian permanent representative to the UN Nebenzya stated on March 31 that he planned to oversee several debates, including one on arms control, adding that he would discuss a “new world or- der” that was coming to “replace the unipolar one.” In reaction to the opinion that Russia should not be given the right to chair the SC because of events in Ukraine, he stressed that “without Russia, not only would the work of the Security Council lose its meaning, but also the work of the UN as a whole.” The same March 31, the Kremlin stated that it planned to exercise all its rights on the council. Also on March 31, Russia’s deputy permanent representative Polyanskiy denied that his mission was becom-

ing a pariah at the UN. “Absolutely not. We feel that the west is embattled in the UN right now because more countries understand our position,” Polyanskiy said, adding that he thought “it’s rather the west is isolated, but not us in the General Assembly.” As for Putin’s ICC arrest warrant, Polyanskiy dismissed it as “totally irrelevant to any of our activities.”1081 In response, on April 1, Zelensky called Russia’s UNSC role an “absurd and destructive” development and said that it proved “the complete bankruptcy of inter- national institutions.”1082 The same day, Kuleba called it “a slap in the face to the international commu- nity.” He urged other members of the UNSC to prevent Moscow from abusing its presidency.1083 The fol- lowing day, April 2, Borrell stated that the EU would stand against any abuse during Russia’s

leadership, stressing that Russia violated “the very essence of the UN legal framework.”1084


Around the same time, Finland’s accession to NATO generated a number of warnings and counter-warn- ings. On April 3, reacting to Stoltenberg’s announcement that Finland would become the 31st member of NATO, Grushko warned that Russia would strengthen its “military potential in the west and in the north-west,” stressing that if the “forces and resources of other NATO members” were deployed in Fin- land, Moscow would “take additional steps to reliably ensure Russia’s military security.”1085 Following


1080 Edith M. Lederer, “Russia clashes with US over tactical nukes for Belarus,” AP, March 31, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/russia-ukraine-belarus-united-nations-nuclear-0139f0f7f830e275b509cbfa4737915a] and Elena Chernenko, “О ядерном несдержанно,” Kommersant, March 31, 2023 [https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/5912291].

1081 George Wright, “Russia assumes UN Security Council presidency despite Ukrainian anger,” BBC, April 1, 2023, [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-65146557]; Grigory Sapozhnikov, “Nebenzya: Without Russia the UN would lose its meaning,” TASS, March 31, 2023 [https://tass.com/politics/1596965]; Julian Borger, “‘Absurdity to a new level’ as Russia takes charge of UN security council,” Guardian, 31 March, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/mar/31/absurdity-to-a- new-level-as-russia-takes-charge-of-un-security-council].


1082 “«Абсурдна новина»: Зеленський відреагував на головування Росії в Радбезі ООН,” Radio Svoboda, April 1, 2023 [https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/news-zelenskyy-radbez-oon-rosiya-viyna/32345212.html].


1083 “Kuleba: Russian UN Security Council presidency 'a slap in the face to the international community',” Kyiv Independent, April 1, 2023 [https://kyivindependent.com/kuleba-russian-un-security-council-a-slap-in-the-face-to-the-international-community/].


1084 “Zelenskiy Calls Russia's UN Security Council Presidency 'Absurd,” Radio Free Europe, April 2, 2023 [https://www.rferl.org/a/zelenskiy-russia-un-security-council-ukraine/32345772.html


1085 “Russia says it will beef up military in northwest as Finland joins NATO - RIA,” Reuters, April 3, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/russia-says-it-will-beef-up-military-northwest-finland-joins-nato-ria-2023-04-03/].

Finland’s official NATO accession on April 4, Stoltenberg stated that the Alliance was “removing the room for miscalculation in Moscow about NATO’s readiness to protect Finland,” which made Finland “safter and stronger, and all of us safer.”1086


In reaction, Peskov said that NATO’s expansion to Finland was an “encroachment on our security and on Russia’s national interests,” adding that Moscow would watch closely for any NATO military deploy- ments there. He also said Finland’s NATO accession would “force” Russia to “take countermeasures to ensure our security.” Also in Moscow, the Russian foreign ministry underlined that Russia would be “forced to take military-technical and other retaliatory measures to counter the threats to our national security arising from Finland’s accession to NATO,” adding that the development marked “a fundamen-

tal change in the situation in northern Europe, which had previously been one of the most stable regions in the world.” Shoigu noted the accession of Finland created “the risks of a significant expansion of con- flict.” But he said it would not affect the outcome of what Russia calls its “special military operation” in Ukraine.1087


Meanwhile, arms deliveries to Ukraine remained front and center. Poland delivered the first batch of So- viet-era MiG-29 fighter jets to Ukraine, the Polish government stated on April 3.1088


On April 5, Duda said at a joint news appearance with Zelenskiy during the latter’s state visit to Warsaw that Poland would send 14 MiG-29 fighter jets in total to Ukraine.1089 As the Alliance was highly unlikely to admit Ukraine anytime soon, Warsaw would push NATO leaders to provide “additional security guar- antees” for Ukraine when they met for their annual summit in summer 2023, Duda also noted. He did

not specify what these would be, saying only that they would serve as a “prelude” to full membership. Also, Poland and Ukraine signed an agreement for joint production of 125-millimeter tank shells and other arms, and separate deals for the sale of Polish self-propelled mortars, combat vehicles and anti- aircraft systems.1090 Spanish defense minister Robles stated that same April 5 that Madrid would send six Leopard 2A4 tanks to Ukraine in the second half of April, thereby pushing back the initial shipment date.1091


1086 Steven Erlanger, “Finland Joins NATO in a Power Shift and Rebuke to Putin,” New York Times, April 4, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/04/04/world/europe/finland-nato-russia-ukraine.html].


1087 Andrew Osborn and Jake Cordell, “Russia says Finland’s NATO accession is dangerous historic mistake,” Reuters, April 4, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-finlands-nato-accession-carries-risk-escalation-2023-04-04/]; Jon Henley, “Fin- land becomes 31st member of Nato in Brussels ceremony,” Guardian, April 4, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/2023/apr/04/finland-nato-member-brussels-ceremony]; Matt Berg, Alexander Ward and Lawrence Ukenye, “Na- tional Security Daily: The inbox,” New York Times, April 4, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security- daily/2023/04/04/pompeo-not-helping-ukraine-costs-more-00090309].


1088 “Ukraine war live: Poland delivers first MiG-29 jets to Ukraine, says official,” Guardian, April 3, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/apr/03/russia-ukraine-war-live-moscow-to-station-nuclear-weapons-near-belaruss-western-border- envoy-says?page=with:block-642aaf2e8f08cfbe54d09467#block-642aaf2e8f08cfbe54d09467]; “Marcin Przydacz: Wołodymyr

Zełenski w środę przyjedzie do Polski,” Radio RMF, April 3, 2023 [https://www.rmf24.pl/tylko-w-rmf24/poranna- rozmowa/news-marcin-przydacz-wolodymyr-zelenski-w-srode-przyjedzie-do-pol,nId,6693491#crp_state=1].


1089 Leonie Chao-Fong, “Zelenskiy welcomed with military honours on visit to Poland,” Guardian, April 5, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/05/zelenskiy-welcomed-military-honours-visit-poland-ukraine].


1090 Andrew Higgins “Zelensky Gets Hero’s Welcome in Poland, Cementing Ukraine’s Ties,” New York Times, April 5, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/05/world/europe/russia-ukraine-zelensky-poland.html].


1091 “Ukraine war live: Spain delays sending Leopard tanks to Ukraine,” Guardian, April 5, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/apr/05/russia-ukraine-war-live-zelenskiy-heads-to-poland-as-macron-and-von-der-leyen-arrive-in- china?page=with:block-642d37b58f081b317503559a#block-642d37b58f081b317503559a].

Ahead of Macron’s state visit to China, speculations were ripe as to what Paris could achieve. Three Biden Administration officials told reporters on April 2 they had little expectation that Macron would achieve a breakthrough, as Xi was unlikely to act on Macron’s requests or curtail any of China’s assertive moves in the Pacific.1092 The Elysee Palace stated on April 5 that Macron and Biden had agreed in a tel- ephone call to engage China to hasten the end of the war in Ukraine.1093 China’s ambassador to the EU Fu Cong noted that China was not on Russia’s side in the war and that some people “deliberately misinter- pret this because there’s the so-called ‘no limit’ friendship or relationship.” He added that “no limit” was “nothing but rhetoric.” Fu said that China had not provided military assistance to Russia, nor recognized its efforts to annex Ukrainian territories, including Crimea and the Donbas. Beijing had not condemned the invasion, he said, because it understood Russia’s claims about a defensive war against NATO en-

croachment, and because China believed the “root causes” were “more complicated” than Western lead- ers said. China would not provide arms for Russia to use in Ukraine in the future, the ambassador said.1094


Having arrived in Beijing, Macron warned on April 5 that anyone helping the “aggressor” Russia in the Ukraine conflict would become an “accomplice in breach of international law.” It was not in China’s in- terest to provide weapons to Russia in its war against Ukraine, he added. He did not agree with every- thing in China’s 12-point peace plan for the war in Ukraine, but he did say Beijing could play a more con- structive role in the “path to peace.” His aim in Beijing was to “relaunch a strategic and global

partnership with China” and so engage the country in a “shared responsibility for peace and interna- tional stability,” Macron said.1095 In Kyiv, Kuleba underlined that any peace plan proposed by China that allowed for Russian rule over any Ukrainian territory, including Crimea, was a non-starter.1096


In Brussels, taking stock of Russian-Chinese relations, Stoltenberg stated on April 5 that Putin’s an- nouncement that Russia would station tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus demonstrated that the Rus- sia-China joint statement amounted to just “empty promises,” further noting that Russia was becoming more and more dependent on China, partly due to international sanctions imposed on Moscow over its war in Ukraine.1097 Responding to Stoltenberg’s statement, Peskov stated on April 6 that it was NATO that was “expanding towards Russia, not Russia taking its military infrastructure towards the borders of NATO,” adding that Russia would keep an eye on any NATO military deployments to Finland and re- spond accordingly. “This movement adds to our concerns and worries for our safety ... and we are taking


1092 “Emmanuel Macron wants to charm China – after failing with Putin,” Politico, April 2, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/arti- cle/war-ukraine-xi-jinping-emmanuel-macron-vladimir-putin-beijing-china-visit-european-union/].


1093 “Macron, Biden want to engage China to end war in Ukraine, Elysee says,” Reuters, April 5, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/macron-biden-want-engage-china-end-war-ukraine-elysee-says-2023-04-05/].


1094 “China’s Ambassador to the EU Tries to Distance Beijing From Moscow,” New York Times, April 5, 2023 [https://www.ny- times.com/2023/04/05/world/europe/eu-china-embassador-russia-fu-cong.html].


1095 “Ukraine war live: Anyone supporting Russia in Ukraine conflict is an ‘accomplice,’ warns Macron,” Guardian, April 5, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/apr/05/russia-ukraine-war-live-zelenskiy-heads-to-poland-as-macron-and- von-der-leyen-arrive-in-china?page=with:block-642d5d728f08547fbc6654d9#block-642d5d728f08547fbc6654d9]; Alexander Ward, “National Security Daily: The inbox,” Politico, April 5, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security- daily/2023/04/05/what-taiwans-tsai-privately-told-3-senators-00090644]; and Roger Cohen, “Macron in China, Says He’ll Urge Xi to Work for Peace in Ukraine,” New York Times, April 5, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/05/world/europe/macron- xi-china-ukraine.html].


1096 Alexander Ward, “National Security Daily: The inbox,” Politico, April 5, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national- security-daily/2023/04/05/what-taiwans-tsai-privately-told-3-senators-00090644].


1097 “Russia’s Belarus nuclear threat shows ‘empty promises’ of China statement: Stoltenberg,” Reuters, April 5, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russias-belarus-nuclear-threat-shows-empty-promises-china-statement-stoltenberg- 2023-04-05/].

measures to ensure our security. And so it will be every time NATO approaches our borders, in order to

rebalance the security architecture on the continent,” he said.1098


Continuing this rhetoric of pointing fingers to the West, on April 5, Putin told US ambassador Lynne Tracy that the United States was responsible for the dramatic deterioration of relations between Wash- ington and Moscow. “Relations between Russia and the United States, which global security and stability directly depend on, are going through a deep crisis, unfortunately,” Putin told the new envoy during her credentials presentation, adding “supporting the color revolutions, supporting the coup d'état in Kyiv in 2014, in the end led to today’s Ukrainian crisis.” No response of Tracy was reported.1099


At the same time, in what appeared to be the clearest statement of Ukraine’s interest in negotiations

since peace talks had been halted in April 2022, on April 5, Andrii Sybiha, deputy head of the presi-

dent’s office of Ukraine, stated that if the Ukrainian counteroffensive would succeed, Ukraine would be “ready to open [a] diplomatic page to discuss” and have peace talks over Crimea.1100


On April 6, media continued to report on Macron’s and Von der Leyen’s state visit to Beijing. After meet- ings in Beijing, Macron stated that he had urged Xi to bring Russia “back to reason and everyone back to the negotiating table” on the war in Ukraine, while Xi said he wanted to avoid escalation and supported Europe’s strategic autonomy. Macron also said he and Xi had agreed that nuclear weapons should be ex- cluded from the conflict in Ukraine. A few hours later, Peskov said in Moscow he saw no prospect for
