China to mediate in the Ukraine conflict and that Russia had “no other way” than to continue with its of- fensive, adding that “so far” there were “no prospects for a political settlement.”1101 A few days later, on April 10, Peskov stated it was hard to imagine France playing a role in brokering peace in Ukraine, as Paris was “both indirectly and directly involved in this conflict on the side of Ukraine.”1102


Also meeting Xi on April 6 in Beijing, Von der Leyen warned Beijing that any arms shipments to Russia would “significantly harm” relations with the EU. She called on Beijing to use its “influence in a friend- ship that is built [over] decades” to “really exert” responsibility and be “very clear in the messaging” with Moscow. After the same meeting, Xi stated that China and the EU should establish correct mutual understanding and avoid misunderstanding and misjudgment. 1103


Meanwhile, discussions on weapons deliveries to Ukraine continued as the Pentagon stated on April 4

that the US would send Ukraine about $500 million in ammunition and equipment and spend more than


1098 “Ukraine war live: Russia ‘taking measures’ in response to Nato expansion, says Kremlin,” Guardian, April 6, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/apr/06/russia-ukraine-war-live-powerful-blasts-in-occupied-melitopol-von- der-leyen-and-macron-in-china?page=with:block-642eb86d8f08156fb81ea299#block-642eb86d8f08156fb81ea299].


1099 Alexander Ward, “National Security Daily: Broadsides,” Politico, April 5, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/na- tional-security-daily/2023/04/05/what-taiwans-tsai-privately-told-3-senators-00090644]; “Vladimir Putin received the creden- tials of seventeen foreign ambassadors,” Website of the President of Russia, April 5, 2023 [http://www.kremlin.ru/events/presi- dent/news/70868/videos].


1100 Christopher Miller and Felicia Schwartz “Ukraine ‘ready’ to talk to Russia on Crimea if counteroffensive succeeds,” Financial Times, 5 April, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/d68b4007-4ddf-4320-b29a-f2eee2662d6e].


1101 Amy Hawkins and Angelique Chrisafis, “Macron urges Xi to bring Russia ‘back to reason’ over Ukraine,” Guardian, April 5, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/06/macron-urges-xi-china-russia-ukraine-war].


1102 “Ukraine war live,” Guardian, April 10, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/apr/10/russia-ukraine-war- live-pentagon-assesses-impact-of-apparent-intelligence-leak-zelenskiy-condemns-palm-sunday-shelling?page=with:block- 6433eee48f08156fb81ec4fa#block-6433eee48f08156fb81ec4fa].


1103 Stuart Lau, “Von der Leyen warns Xi not to arm Russia with Chinese weapons,” Politico, April 6, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.eu/article/ursula-von-der-leyen-warn-xi-jinping-not-arm-russia-chinese-weapons-china/].

$2 billion to buy an array of munitions, radar and new weapons to help Kyiv counter drones in the com- ing months. The aid was to be taken from military stockpiles, so it would arrive quickly, and included ammunition for HIMARS, air defense interceptors, and artillery rounds, Blinken stated.1104 On April 6, as Ukraine’s defense minister Reznikov arrived in Greece, the Greek defense minister Nikolaos Panag- iotopoulos said Athens would “provide every support to Ukraine at this very important, crucial stage of the war,” promising more artillery, small arms ammunition shipments, access to Greek hospitals for mil- itary personnel and additional Soviet-era BMP infantry fighting vehicles. 1105


At the same time, debates continued on whether and when to grant Ukraine NATO membership. On April 6, four officials involved in the NATO foreign ministers meeting stated that the United States, Ger- many and Hungary were rebuffing the efforts by some European countries to provide Ukraine a path to NATO membership. Poland and the Baltic states had sought to grant Kyiv a “road map” to join the alli- ance. “We’ve got several weeks of hard negotiations ahead to try and close those gaps and craft some

kind of political outcome,” a Western official stated. “But yes, there are some significant differences on that at the moment.” Still, two individuals who had attended these meetings said a growing number sup- ported offering Ukraine “a political path” to membership in Vilnius that would “thicken” the bonds be- tween NATO and Kyiv. Washington, however, was pushing back against that proposal, they said. Practi- cal support such as ammunition deliveries should be the main priority for Vilnius, US officials stated, with discussions over a potential postwar political relationship only distracting from that goal.1106

The next day, on April 7, Lavrov stated that Moscow wanted any Ukraine peace talks to focus on creat-

ing a “new world order,” adding that Russia rejected a “unipolar world order led by one hegemon.”1107


A leak of classified US intelligence reports offered insights into Ukraine-related questions in the second week of April. Comprising around a 100 pages of intelligence and operational briefs from Pentagon’s Joint Chiefs, the documents suggested US understanding of Russian planning remained extensive, but also that Washington had leveraged human and signals intelligence to penetrate Ukrainian and Allied decision-making circles. They left no doubt about how deeply enmeshed the United States was in the day-to-day conduct of the war, providing the precise intelligence and logistics that helped explain

Ukraine’s success against Russia. In terms of predictions, the documents revealed that the US analysts assessed that Ukraine’s forces were in more dire straits than Kyiv had publicly acknowledged – without an influx of munitions, Ukraine’s air defense system may soon collapse, the US IC had concluded. Last but not least, initial reporting on the documents also offered another explanation for why Washington was reluctant to provide Kyiv with long-range options. One document revealed that Zelensky had ar- gued for “striking Russian deployment locations in Russia’s Rostov Oblast” using unmanned aerial vehi- cles. Another report assessed that China could use Ukrainian strikes on targets deep inside Russia “as an opportunity to cast NATO as the aggressor, and may increase its aid to Russia if it deems the attacks were significant.”1108


1104 Lolita C. Baldor and Matthew Lee, “US is providing Ukraine with $2.6 billion in military aid,” AP, April 4, 2023 [https://ap- news.com/article/ukraine-russia-war-security-aid-billions-e02b957dc15fcb1004bf54a2232c1f5e].


1105 Srdjan Nedeljkovic and Derek Gatopoulos, “Greece to send more arms to Ukraine, but sets limits,” AP, April 6, 2023 [https://apnews.com/b8255c6473e7f01cced6202af2c073da].


1106 Henry Foy and Felicia Schwartz, “US opposes offering Ukraine a road map to Nato membership,” Financial Times, April 6, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/c37ed22d-e0e4-4b03-972e-c56af8a36d2e].


1107 “Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov links peace in Ukraine to a 'new world order',” Euronews, April 8, 2023, [https://www.eu- ronews.com/2023/04/07/russian-foreign-minister-lavrov-links-peace-in-ukraine-to-a-new-world-order].


1108 Julian E. Barnes et al, “Leaked Documents Reveal Depth of U.S. Spy Efforts and Russia’s Military Struggles,” New York Times, April 8, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/08/us/politics/leaked-documents-russia-ukraine-war.html?searchResultPo- sition=13]; David Sanger, “How the Latest Leaked Documents Are Different From Past Breaches,” New York Times, April 9, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/09/us/politics/leaked-pentagon-documents-ukraine.html?searchResultPosition=11]; and Natasha Bertrand and Kylie Atwood, “Leaked Pentagon documents provide rare window into depth of US intelligence on allies and

Meanwhile on April 11, in a criticized move that further underlined unconstrained Russian-Hungarian relations, Hungary’s foreign minister Péter Szijjártó arrived in Moscow to sign a new energy deal, mak- ing him one of the only officials from an EU county to have met with Russian officials in Moscow since the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Szijjártó stated that the Russian state energy giant Gazprom would maintain an option to supply additional gas to Hungary in 2023 on top of the shipments agreed under a long-term deal. He insisted that access to Russian energy supplies was crucial for Hungary’s security, regardless of the political considerations brought on by the war.1109 Yet mere days earlier, among the leaked Pentagon documents, a “top secret” CIA update from March 2 revealed that Orbán had branded the United States as “one of his party’s top three adversaries” during a political strategy session on Feb- ruary 22. However, the leaked documents also indicated Hungary may had been secretly letting allies use its airspace to move arms toward the battlefield, despite pledges to bar such transfers.1110


Weapons deliveries to Ukraine continued to be a topic of debate. On April 10, Denmark’s acting defense minister Troels Lund Poulsen confirmed Denmark’s intention to provide refurbished 100 Leopard 1 battle tanks to Ukraine. The following day, April 11, Poulsen said that a Danish decision on whether to supply western fighter jets to Ukraine was likely to take place “before the summer.”1111 Also on April 10 in Canada, Trudeau pledged fresh military support for Ukraine after meeting with his Ukrainian coun- terpart Denys Shmyhal. Canada would send 21,000 assault rifles, 38 machine guns and 2.4m rounds of ammunition to Ukraine and impose sanctions on 14 Russian individuals and 34 entities, including secu- rity targets linked to the private mercenary Wagner group, Trudeau said. 1112 In addition, a leaked US document revealed that Serbia had declined to provide training to Ukrainian forces, but had committed to sending lethal aid or had supplied it already. The document also said Serbia had the political will and military ability to provide weapons to Ukraine in the future, media reported on April 11.1113 However, on April 13, Serbian president Aleksandar Vučić insisted that Serbia had never sold weapons or am- munition to Ukraine or Russia, adding he was “quite certain” that Serbian ammunition would appear “on one side or the other in the battlefield” in Ukraine, after having been exported to Turkey, Spain or the Czech Republic.1114


foes,” CNN, April 10, 2023 [https://edition.cnn.com/2023/04/09/politics/pentagon-leaked-documents-us-spying-allies-foes/in- dex.html].


1109 Justin Spike, “Hungary forces new energy deals with Russia amid Ukraine war,” AP, April 11, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/hungary-makes-new-energy-agreement-russia-c069d83bc748cb820c3958bbecf13f17].


1110 “Here is what the leaked US war files tell us about Europe,” Politico, April 14, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/what-the- leaked-us-war-files-tell-us-about-europe/].


1111 “Ukraine war live: Decision on western fighter jets for Ukraine likely ‘before summer’, says Denmark,” Guardian, April 11, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/apr/11/russia-ukraine-war-live-ukrainian-pm-arrives-in-canada-gershkovich- wrongfully-detained-says-us?page=with:block-6435555e8f0885230b2d8935#block-6435555e8f0885230b2d8935].


1112 “Ukraine war live: Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau, has pledged fresh military support for Ukraine after meeting with his Ukrainian counterpart, Denys Shmyhal.,” Guardian, April 11, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/apr/11/russia-ukraine-war-live-ukrainian-pm-arrives-in-canada-gershkovich-wrongfully-detained- says-us?page=with:block-64359c3b8f0891526bb40718#block-64359c3b8f0891526bb40718].


1113 “Leaked documents show Serbia agreed to supply arms to Kyiv,” Guardian, April 12, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/apr/12/russia-ukraine-war-live-russia-risks-becoming-economic-colony-of-china-as-isolation-deep- ens-says-cia-director?page=with:block-643642038f08791e579d327a#block-643642038f08791e579d327a].


1114 “Ukraine war live: Serbian president denies it sold military aid to Ukraine,” Guardian, April 13, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/apr/13/russia-ukraine-war-live-pentagon-leaker-reportedly-worked-on-military-base-world-bank-to- fund-ukraine-energy-repairs?page=with:block-643839428f08791e579d455d#block-643839428f08791e579d455d].

At the same time, leaked US documents spurred debate about Chinese support for Russia’s war efforts. On April 13, journalists reported that, according to a leaked US document, an intercept of Russian intel- ligence had revealed that China’s Central Military Commission had approved the “provision of lethal aid” to Russia in its war in Ukraine earlier in 2023 and had planned to disguise military equipment as civilian items. In response to these revelations, a senior US administration official stated that the Admin- istration had no evidence that China had indeed “transferred weapons or provided lethal assistance to Russia,” but Washington was monitoring the situation “closely.” This US stance notwithstanding, an- other leak shared some light on potential rationales in Washington. A separate US intelligence assess- ment from the same period also included in the Pentagon leaks had assessed that Beijing would view a “significant” Ukrainian attack within Russia using US or NATO weapons as “indicative that Washington was directly responsible for escalating the conflict and possibly as further justification for China to pro- vide Russia with lethal aid.”1115 In response, China’s foreign minister Qin Gang on April 14 said that

China would adopt “a prudent and responsible attitude” regarding the export of weapons, adding that China would “not provide weapons to relevant parties of the conflict, and manage and control the ex- ports of dual-use items in accordance with laws and regulations.” He reiterated China’s willingness to help facilitate negotiations to find a peaceful resolution to the conflict and said all parties should remain “objective and calm.” In turn, the same day, White House National Security Council spokeswoman Wat- son cautioned the White House would “continue to monitor closely.”1116


With media continuing to focus on the leaked US documents, a US Defense Intelligence Agency assess- ment was revealed on March 14 according to which the war between Ukraine and Russia was expected to continue into 2024. The analysis concluded that, even if Ukraine recaptured “significant” amounts of territory and inflicted “unsustainable losses on Russian forces” – an outcome US intelligence analysts

found unlikely, Ukraine’s gains would not lead to peace talks. “Negotiations to end the conflict are un- likely during 2023 in all considered scenarios,” the document said. It further anticipated that the year would end with the two sides achieving only “marginal” territorial gains as a result of “insufficient troops and supplies for effective operations.” In the event that Russia dealt a significant blow against

Ukraine and captured more territory, Moscow was likely to “posture forces to achieve further objectives, such as regime change” in Ukraine, the assessment read. In the scenario in which Ukraine gained a deci- sive advantage, however, US intelligence believed that Kyiv was likely to “conduct riskier offensive oper- ations for additional gains.” In response to such a Ukrainian approach, Russia could be expected to “in- crease nonconventional attacks on Ukraine,” though, importantly, “nuclear use” remained “unlikely,” the document noted.1117


Also on March 14, media reported that Russia had put its Pacific naval fleet on high alert as part of a surprise inspection aimed at building its defensive capabilities. Shoigu said: “The main objective of this inspection is to increase the ability of the armed forces to repel the aggression of a probable enemy from the direction of ocean and sea.”1118


1115 Karen DeYoung and Missy Ryan, “Russia says China agreed to secretly provide it with ‘lethal aid,’ files reveal,” Washington Post, April 14, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/04/13/russia-china-weapons-leaked-documents- discord/].


1116 “China vows not to sell arms to any party in Ukraine war,” AP, April 14, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/china-taiwan- weapons-germany-ukraine-2a51d2c64c12fca75683d20fbafba475].


1117 John Hudson, “No Russia-Ukraine peace talks expected this year, U.S. leak shows,” Washington Post, April 14, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/04/12/leaked-documents-ukraine-war/].


1118 “Russia conducts surprise inspection of Pacific Fleet,” Reuters, April 14, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/rus- sia-puts-pacific-fleet-high-alert-surprise-inspection-2023-04-14/].

Ukraine’s westward grain and food exports became a sore point in relations with a number of Eastern European countries in mid-April. Governments in Poland, Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Slovakia had already called on the EU in March to take steps to curb the influx of Ukrainian produce that had been pushing down prices and said Europe should consider reinstating the tariffs that had been lifted after Russia’s invasion. On April 15, after having reached an agreement with Kyiv to halt Ukrainian grain de- liveries to Poland, Warsaw imposed a unilateral ban of dozens of other types of food, to the dismay of the EU and other European governments. In reaction, the government in Budapest said that absent “meaningful EU measures,” it would follow suit at the end of June.1119 In reaction, a European Commis- sion spokesperson stated on April 16 that unilateral action on trade by European Union member states was “not acceptable.”1120 Still, Bratislava and Sofia followed suit in introducing a temporary ban on Ukraine grain imports on April 17 and 19, respectively.1121 On April 17, the Kremlin stated that

prospects for a renewal of the Black Sea grain initiative were “not so bright.”1122 The following April 18, Polish Agriculture Minister Robert Telus said Poland had reached an agreement on restarting transit of Ukrainian grains through its territory as of April 21.1123 On April 19, the European Commission said it was preparing €100m in compensation for EU farmers affected by the recent influx of Ukrainian grain as well as restrictions on selling wheat and maize in affected countries.1124


Also on April 15, Ukrainian finance minister Serhiy Marchenko stated that a new international eco- nomic support package of $115 billion would give Ukraine more confidence that it could prevail in bat- tling Russia's invasion, amid growing recognition that the war could continue for longer than expected. He detailed that G7 ministers had assured him during International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings in Washington that they would support Ukraine for as long as needed.1125


In other international reactions to the war in Ukraine, on April 14, Brazilian president Lula da Silva met in Beijing with China’s leader Xi Jingping, after which the two leaders declared that negotiation was “the only viable way out of the crisis in Ukraine,” – in a statement which avoided the words “invasion” or “war.”1126 Following the visit, on April 16, da Silva called for establishing a group of countries that were not involved in the Russia-Ukraine war in order to broker peace, citing China’s Xi and the president of the United Arab Emirates, bin Zayed al-Nahyan, both of whom he had met during the second week of

1125 “Ukraine minister: G7 support crucial for longer war with Russia,” Reuters, April 15, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/ukraines-marchenko-says-g7-support-crucial-longer-war-with-russia-2023-04-15/].


1126 Keith Bradsher, “Brazil’s Lula Meets Xi in China as They Seek Path to Peace in Ukraine,” New York Times, April 14, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/14/world/asia/brazil-china-russia-ukraine.html].

April. But Kyiv remained critical of Brasilia’s efforts. On April 18, Lula condemned the violation of

Ukraine’s territorial integrity by Russia, but again called for mediation to end the war.1127


In what seemed like a follow-up to Xi’s visit to Moscow in March, on April 16, China’s defense minister Li Shangfu concluded his three-day visit to Moscow, where he was welcomed by Putin and Shoigu. Fol- lowing the meeting, Putin stated that military cooperation played “an important role in the Russia-China relations.” The two countries were “working actively through the military departments, regularly ex- changing information that is useful to us, cooperating in the field of military-technical cooperation, con- ducting joint exercises, moreover, in different theaters: in the Far East region, and in Europe, and at sea, and on land and in the air,” Putin said. Li stated that the countries’ relations “outperform the military- political unions of the Cold War era. They rest on the principles of nonalignment, and are very stable,” while also underlining that he had chosen Russia for his first state visit to “show the world the high standard and uniqueness of China-Russia relations.”1128

On April 17, Russian opposition activist Kara-Murza was sentenced to jail for 25 years for his opposi- tion to the Russia’s war in Ukraine. Numerous Western countries protested. Russia replied these calls were attempts to interfere in its internal affairs.1129


Concerning further weapons supplies to Ukraine, the Slovak defense ministry stated on April 17 that Slovakia had handed over all 13 MiG-29 fighter jets it had pledged.1130 In addition, Ukraine received two types of air defense systems ahead of the Rammstein military group meeting on April 20. The Patriot air defense system delivery, one from the United States, the other jointly gifted by Germany and the Nether- lands, was confirmed by Ukrainian defense minister Reznikov on April 19. The second of four promised German Iris-T system were also delivered, according to German government officials. The same April 19, the White House announced a new US military aid package for Ukraine of about $325m in additional military aid, which would include more ammunition and artillery rounds.1131 On April 20, the Danish and Dutch defense ministers announced in a joint statement that they planned to provide Ukraine with at least another 14 refurbished Leopard 2 battle tanks by early 2024.1132


1127 Anthony Boadle, “Brazil's Lula condemns invasion of Ukraine, touts peace initiative,” Reuters, April 19, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/ukraine-invites-brazils-lula-visit-criticizes-his-peace-efforts-2023-04-18/].

1132 “Danes, Dutch to donate Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine,” AP, April 20, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/denmark-netherlands- ukraine-tanks-9f6a383f99c09eb25e47fd711b775651].

184.

De-escalatory

In an interview, US undersecretary of defense for policy Colin Kahl pushed back against criticisms that the Biden administration had slow-rolled aid to Ukraine. “We are all in,” he said on April 17, add- ing that “Russia has already lost, by every measure.” Regarding weapons deliveries to Ukraine, the

Administration had expressed its “concern about US-provided equipment and material being used to strike targets inside of Russia,” but “by and large” it had “not held things back because of a concern for escalation.” Kahl also stated that in exchanges with the US administration, Russian officials had “constantly made the point that Russia’s nuclear doctrine has not changed, that they would only use nuclear weapons in an event of an existential threat to the Russian state,” and the Administration did not think the war in Ukraine posed such a threat. But, Kahl stressed that “while we will do anything we can to support Ukraine, the United States does not have any interest in directly entering the con-

flict, and seeing the conflict escalate to World War Three either.”1133


185.

Warning

On April 18, G7 foreign ministers discussed moving closer to an outright ban on most exports to Russia in an attempt to increase economic pressure on Putin. “We remain committed to intensifying sanctions against Russia, coordinating and fully enforcing them,” the communiqué stated, and would support Ukraine “for as long as it takes.” It condemned “in the strongest possible terms Russia’s war of aggression against Ukraine,” calling on Russia to “withdraw all forces and equipment from Ukraine immediately and unconditionally.” In the nuclear realm, it once again noted that “Russia’s irresponsi-

ble nuclear rhetoric and its threat to deploy nuclear weapons in Belarus” were “unacceptable,” adding that any use of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons in Ukraine “would be met with severe conse-

quences.”1134


With more details about Russia-China relations arising from leaked US documents, on April 20, media reported that a leaked US intelligence report showed that China had refused a request from the Wagner mercenary group for weapons. Wagner’s request in early 2023 suggested “it had some confidence Bei- jing would be open to arming Moscow, going beyond other non-lethal forms of support for the military campaign provided by Chinese companies.”1135


Meanwhile, Stoltenberg paid a surprise visit to Kyiv on April 20 and reaffirmed on this occasion that Ukraine’s place was in NATO. On the following April 21, speaking ahead of the meeting of the Ukraine defense contact group at Ramstein airbase, he declared that “Ukraine’s rightful place is in NATO, as Al- lies have agreed.” This statement was later criticized by some allies, who noted that there was no such broad agreement on Ukraine joining NATO, including Hungary’s Orbán. Stoltenberg further pledged more military support for Ukraine, and said he and Zelenskyy had discussed a NATO support program for Ukraine, which would help Ukraine “transition from Soviet-era equipment and doctrines to NATO


1133 “Colin Kahl on America’s Defense Strategy,” FP, April 17, 2023, min 10:50 - 12:40 and 15:35 - 17:25 [https://foreignpol- icy.com/live/colin-kahl-on-americas-defense-strategy/?live_refresh; https://vimeo.com/818359939?embed- ded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=24338262].

1135 Mehul Srivastava, Max Seddon and Felicia Schwartz, “China snubbed Wagner arms request, says US intelligence leak,” Financial Times, April 21, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/755b7302-6f69-4790-a143-d75dd2ad8aef].

standards and ensure full interoperability with the alliance.” He added that once the war in Ukraine ended, Ukraine had to have “the deterrence to prevent new attacks.”1136


In response, on April 21, Peskov repeated that preventing Ukraine from joining NATO remained one of

the goals of Russia’s invasion, arguing that NATO continued its policy of “absorbing and drawing

Ukraine into the alliance” and Kyiv’s membership would pose “a serious, significant threat to our coun- try, to our country’s security,” as Russia was dealing with “an aggressive bloc” that viewed it as an “op- ponent.”1137


Also at the meeting at Ramstein airbase, on April 21, Austin said the support of the Ukraine defense contact group “for the forces of freedom in Ukraine holds strong and true,” and that the 11th meeting of the group would focus on three key areas: “air defense, ammunition and enablers.”1138 Austin further-

more announced that thirty-one Abrams tanks that Ukrainians will use for training would arrive in Ger- many by mid-to-late May. Yet Washington continued to refuse to supply Ukraine with F-16 fighter jets. After the Ramstein meeting, Milley said that Ukraine’s air-defense system had worked effectively for more than a year and kept Russian warplanes “cautious” for fear of being shot down. Sustaining

Ukraine’s air defenses, he said, was “the most critical thing right now.” Milley said the US would continue to work with its allies to that end, adding that “we need to do everything we can to ensure that Ukraine has adequate air defense — ground-based air-defense capability.”1139


In the context of the Ukraine defense contact group, more pledges for further military assistance were made. On April 21, Pistorius stated that Germany, Poland and Ukraine had signed an agreement for a hub to repair Leopard tanks used in Ukraine to fight Russian forces, a hub that could begin operations at the end of May 2023.1140 The same April 21, the Canadian defense minister Anita Anand announced C$39m in new military assistance for Ukraine, including sniper rifles, radio sets and a donation to a NATO fund to help Kyiv in its war against Russia.1141 On April 24, Borrell expressed confidence that the bloc would complete a plan within days to buy ammunition for Ukraine after Kyiv had expressed

frustration at wrangling among EU member states. “I am sure everybody will understand that we are in


1136 Lili Bayer, “Your place is in NATO, alliance chief tells Ukraine on first wartime visit,” Politico, April 20, 2023 [https://www.po- litico.eu/article/nato-jens-stoltenberg-visit-kyiv-ukraine-war-russia/amp/]; “Doorstepby by NATO Secretary General Jens Stol- tenberg at Ramstein Air Base prior to the Ukraine Defense Contact Group meeting,” NATO, April 21, 2023 [https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/opinions_214043.htm]; “National Security Daily,” Politico, April 21, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/04/21/what-a-year-mayorkas-week-has-been-00093246]; Lorne Cook and Samya Kullab, “NATO chief: Ukraine’s ‘rightful place’ is in the alliance,” AP, April 21, 2023 [https://ap- news.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-stoltenberg-dd2432f52abc743a5f3592cec210a69e].

1140 “Ukraine aktuell: Reparatur-Hub für Leopard-2-Panzer in Polen,” Deutsche Welle, April 21, 2023 [https://www.dw.com/de/ukraine-aktuell-reparatur-hub-für-leopard-2-panzer-in-polen/a-65391554].


1141 “Canada to send rifles, radios in new C$39 million Ukraine aid package,” Reuters, April 21, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/americas/canada-send-rifles-radios-new-c39-million-ukraine-aid-package-2023-04-21/].

a situation of extreme urgency,” Borrell stated as he arrived for a meeting of EU foreign ministers in Lux-

embourg.1142


In an attempt to push forward talks on Ukraine’s EU and NATO accession, on April 24, Estonian prime minister Kaja Kallas visited president Zelenskiy in Kyiv and said that Ukraine should be admitted to the EU and NATO. She stated that she supported Ukraine getting more ammunition, arms and training, which was why she proposed the EU to provide 1m shells to Ukraine.1143 The following day, on April 25, Kallas voiced hope that EU membership talks with Kyiv could begin in 2023, adding that it would be a “hard process” and that the requirements would “need to be fulfilled 100%.”1144


Also on April 24, in less optimistic news, media reported that Biden administration officials were qui- etly preparing for the possibility that if Ukraine’s spring counteroffensive fell short of expectations, crit- ics at home and allies abroad would argue that the United States had come up short, too. If Kyiv’s forces did not retake a large part of territory seized by Russia, hawks might say the US should have provided more weapons while doves might claim the time for peace talks was yesterday, officials feared. Still, in- side the Administration, officials stressed that they would be doing everything possible to make the spring offensive succeed.1145


186.

Warning

On April 24, Lavrov told the UN Security Council that the world may have reached a more dangerous

situation than ever during the Cold War. “As was the case in the Cold War, we have reached the dan- gerous, possibly even more dangerous, threshold.”1146


187.

Warning

The next day, April 25, Medvedev said that the world was “sick and quite probably on the verge of a new world war,” adding that such a new world war was not inevitable but the risks of a nuclear con-

frontation were growing and more serious than concerns about climate change.1147


188.

Warning

Also on April 25, the Russian foreign ministry’s head of nuclear non-proliferation Vladimir Yerma- kov stated that if the US continued “to follow its current course towards a standoff with Russia, while constantly raising the stakes on the verge of a direct military conflict, then the fate of the New START Treaty may become sealed.” He added that “in the worst-case scenario,” if Washington drove the situ-

ation “to a military clash between the strongest nuclear powers,” then it was “not the fate of the New


1142 “Foreign Affairs Council: Press remarks by High Representative Josep Borrell upon arrival,” European Union External Action, April 24, 2023 [https://www.eeas.europa.eu/eeas/foreign-affairs-council-press-remarks-high-representative-josep-borrell-upon- arrival-8_en].


1143 “Joint Declaration of the President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelenskyy and the Prime Minister of Estonia Kaja Kallas,” Republic of Estonia Government, April 24, 2023 [https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/joint-declaration-president-ukraine-volodymyr-zelen- skyy-and-prime-minister-estonia-kaja-kallas].


1144 “Ukraine EU entry negotiations should start this year, urges Estonian PM,” Euronews, April 25, 2023 [https://www.eu- ronews.com/2023/04/25/ukraine-eu-entry-negotiations-should-start-this-year-urges-estonian-pm].


1145 Jonathan Lemire and Alexander Ward, “Biden’s team fears the aftermath of a failed Ukrainian counteroffensive,” Politico, April 24, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/04/24/biden-ukraine-russia-counteroffensive-defense-00093384?bezug- grd=NWL&utm_source=sondermailing].


1146 “Ukraine war live: Summary,” Guardian, April 24, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/apr/24/russia- ukraine-war-live-drone-attack-on-crimea-repelled-russia-says-moscow-threatens-to-scrap-grain-deal].


1147 “Putin ally: We are probably on verge of a new world war,” Reuters, April 25, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/eu- rope/putin-ally-we-are-probably-verge-new-world-war-2023-04-25/].

START but the fate of the entire world” that would be a “concern.” These observations would “again confirm” that “the most pressing threat today” was “connected not with the dynamic of stimuli for the first massive strike, which is supposed to be curbed by agreements like the New START, but with a danger of nuclear escalation as a result of a direct military confrontation between nuclear powers,” adding that “to our deepest regrets, these risks keep growing.” He added that Washington was esca- lating the risks through its conduct with Moscow, demanding that to reverse the negative trend “the US must immediately take concrete steps on de-escalation and to abolish the hostile course towards

undermining Russia’s security in practice.”1148


On April 26, in a telephone conversation with president Zelenskiy, Xi reportedly stated that there was

“no winner in a nuclear war” and negotiation was the only viable way out of the conflict. All parties should “remain calm and restrained in dealing with the nuclear issue and truly look at the future and

destiny of themselves and all mankind and work together to manage the crisis,” Xi added, emphasizing that “we should seize the opportunity to accumulate favorable conditions for a political settlement of the crisis,” that he hoped all parties would “jointly seek long-term peace and stability in Europe through dia- logue,” and that he would send the special representative of the Chinese government for Eurasian affairs to visit Kyiv and other countries for “in-depth communication” on the political settlement of “the Ukraine crisis.”1149


189.

De-escalatory

Following the warnings by senior Russian officials that Western military support for Ukraine was in- creasing the risks of a nuclear conflict and the phone-call between Zelenskiy and Xi, on April 27 Mos- cow seemed bent to half-heartedly walk back Russian claims. Zakharova said that Russia would “do everything to prevent the development of events according to the worst scenario, but not at the cost of infringing on our vital interests,” adding that she would “not recommend that anybody doubt our determination and put it to the test in practice.” She also underlined that the United States would

“continue to deliberately infringe on our fundamental interests, deliberately generate risks and raise the stakes in the confrontation with Russia.”1150 On the same day, Peskov stated that the Kremlin was “ready to welcome anything that could hasten the end of the conflict in Ukraine and Russia achieving all the goals it has set itself,” which seemed to all but Russian ears a contradiction in and of itself. 1151


Zakharova and Peskov’s statements notwithstanding, Russia fired more than twenty cruise missiles at Kyiv and other parts of Ukraine, including Dnipro and Uman, in the early hours of April 28. A few hours later, Shoigu told the press that NATO’s real aim in Ukraine was to “strategically defeat” Russia, as “al- most all” members of the alliance had send military aid to Ukraine. The government in Kyiv noted its


1148 “Risks of direct military clash between Russia, US keep growing — Foreign Ministry,” TASS, April 25, 2023 [https://tass.com/russia/1609013].


1149 “China says it will send peace envoy to Ukraine,” AP, April 26, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/china-ukraine-russia- ac231aec87246cca207c8bb48fd49f34]; “习近平同乌克兰总统泽连斯基通电话,” CRI online, April 26, 2023 [https://news.cri.cn/2023-04-26/95029a60-8f18-ffc9-c51d-f5ba9889d1ee.html].

1150 “Russia says does not plan nuclear escalation, but others should not test its patience,” Reuters, April 27, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-says-does-not-plan-nuclear-escalation-others-should-not-test-its-patience- 2023-04-27/].


1151 Andrew Osborn, “Kremlin welcomes Xi-Zelenskiy call on Ukraine, but says Russia's aims remain the same,” Reuters, April 27, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/kremlin-welcomes-xi-zelenskiy-call-ukraine-says-its-aims-remain-same-2023-04-27/].

forces had downed 21 of 23 Russian missiles and two attack drones overnight. Zelenskiy condemned the attack and vowed a response to “Russian terror.”1152


Also on April 28, Peskov played down the idea that Russia was planning to test nuclear weapons. Tracy had told Russian media that Russia was the only country talking about potentially resuming nuclear testing. The US ambassador to Moscow was responding to Putin’s February 2023 statement that “if the United States conducts tests, then we will. No one should have dangerous illusions that global strategic parity can be destroyed,” Putin said. 1153


That same April 28, media reported that the US National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) was setting up an advanced network of radiation sensors in Ukraine to detect nuclear blasts and verify an attacker’s identity.1154


Against this background, support for Ukraine remained steady at the end of April. During a visit to the United States, South Korea’s president Yoon Suk-yeol said on April 29 that it was necessary to ensure Russia’s invasion of Ukraine was unsuccessful and that Seoul was considering options to provide lethal aid to Kyiv.1155


May 2023: Western debates on arming Ukraine – but few nuclear statements


Support for Ukraine remained strong, and Russia continued to resent it. On May 1, Republican US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy stressed his support for military aid to Ukraine, blistering Russia’s “killing of the children,” and distancing himself from others within the GOP who opposed major additional US aid to Ukraine.1156 On May 2, in a meeting with Russia’s top military officials, Shoigu said Russian forces were engaged in combat operations “along the entire line of contact” in Ukraine and were fighting not

only Ukraine but also “unprecedented military assistance from the West.” On the same day, Peskov stated German-supplied weapons were already being used in the Donbas region. Scholz had said on May 1 that Berlin had stressed towards Ukraine, like other NATO members, that the weapons it was supplying should not be used against Russian territory.1157


After a pair of explosions above the Kremlin early on May 3, Russia accused Ukraine of trying to assas- sinate Putin in a terrorist attack with a drone attack that had been disabled by Russian defenses. Kyiv denied any involvement and asserted that Russia had manufactured the incident to distract attention


1152 Joe Middleton, Jon Henley and Helen Sullivan, “Russia-Ukraine war live,” Guardian, April 28, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/apr/28/russia-ukraine-war-live-air-raid-sirens-sound-in-kyiv-and-across-ukraine?filterKe- yEvents=false].


1153 “Kremlin plays down idea that Russia is preparing a nuclear weapons test,” Reuters, April 28, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/kremlin-plays-down-idea-that-russia-is-preparing-nuclear-weapons-test-2023-04-28/].


1154 William J. Broad, “U.S. Wires Ukraine With Radiation Sensors to Detect Nuclear Blasts,” New York Times, April 28, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/28/science/ukraine-nuclear-radiation-sensors.html].


1155 David Brunnstrom and Eric Beech, “On lethal aid to Ukraine, South Korean leader says Seoul considering its options,” Reuters, April 29, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/lethal-aid-ukraine-south-korean-leader-says-seoul-considering-its-options- 2023-04-28/].


1156 “Ukraine war live: Evening summary,” Guardian, May 1, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/may/01/rus- sia-ukraine-war-live-air-raid-sirens-in-kyiv-and-across-ukraine-as-officials-warn-of-missile-threat].


1157 “Kremlin says German involvement in Ukraine conflict is growing due to arms supplies,” Reuters, May 2, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/kremlin-says-german-involvement-ukraine-conflict-is-growing-due-arms-supplies- 2023-05-02/].

from Ukraine’s expected imminent counteroffensive and possibly to justify an escalation of its own at- tacks. Moscow stressed that “the Russian side reserves to take retaliatory measures where and when it sees fit.”1158 In reaction, on May 4, Zelenskiy denied responsibility for the attack, stating “we don’t at- tack Putin, or Moscow, we fight on our territory and defend our towns and cities.” The same day, Podol- yak also denied Ukraine’s involvement in the attack, saying it was the result of “local resistance forces.” In reactions from Russia, Medvedev said that Zelenskiy should be “eliminated” in retaliation. In a simi- lar vein, the chair of the State Duma Vyacheslav Volodin stated the “Kyiv regime” should be labelled as terrorists and destroyed, adding “we will demand the use of weapons that can stop and destroy the Kyiv terrorist regime,” though it remained unclear whether he meant nuclear weapons or merely sufficient conventional deliveries.1159


However, some Russian officials were more explicit. On the same May 4, Rogozin said “an imminent

deadly air fight” was anticipated but that Russia could avoid a significant number of casualties by using tactical nuclear weapons against Kyiv preemptively. “According to our [nuclear] doctrine we have the right to use tactical nuclear weapons because that’s what they exist for,” he said, calling them a “great equalizer for the moments when there is a clear discrepancy in the enemy’s favor.”1160 In contrast, Prigozhin cautioned that “as a radically-minded person” he could say that “the use of nuclear weapons in response to a drone is, of course, out of question.” He added that instead Russia should improve its military capabilities to allow it to retaliate, while making disproportionate threats to the West made them “look like clowns.”1161


In reaction to the drone incident, also on 4 May, Blinken stated that the US could not confirm Russian reports that Ukraine had targeted Putin with a drone strike. White House press secretary Karine Jean- Pierre stated the US was “certainly not encouraging or enabling Ukraine to strike beyond its borders.” Senior administration officials were working to confirm whether the suspected strike was ordered by Kyiv, conducted by a rogue pro-Ukraine group, or a false flag operation by Russia, two US officials stated.1162


Later on 4 May, Peskov claimed the US was behind the drone incident, stating Russia knew “decisions about such actions, on such terrorist attacks, are not made in Kyiv, but in Washington” and that Kyiv was “doing what it is told to do.” He added that it was “very important” that “in Washington they understand that we know this, and understand how dangerous such direct participation in the conflict” was, adding that retaliatory steps would be “carefully considered and balanced” by the Russian leadership. In an ap- parent attempt to project an image of normality, Peskov also said the same day that Putin would not


1158 “Сообщение пресс-службы Президента,” President of Russia, May 3, 2023 [http://kremlin.ru/events/presi- dent/news/71091].

1162 Alexander Ward, Matt Berg and Ari Hawkins “The Kremlin drone attack, explained as best we can,” Politico, May 3, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/05/03/the-kremlin-drone-attack-explained-as-best-we- can-00095047]; Pjotr Sauer and Dan Sabbagh, “Kremlin drone incident: Zelenskiy denies Russian claim Ukraine attempted to kill Putin,” Guardian, May 4, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/may/03/russia-accuses-ukraine-of-trying-to-kill- vladimir-putin-with-kremlin-drone-strike]; “Putin Allies Split Over Using Tactical Nuclear Weapons in Ukraine,” Moscow Times, May 4, 2023 [https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2023/05/04/putin-allies-split-on-using-tactical-nuclear-weapons-in-ukraine- a81038].

give a special presidential address in connection with the attack and that a normal working situation was in place. In response, Kirby said “the US did not have any involvement with this incident,” and

Peskov was “just lying there, pure and simple.” Kirby further reiterated that Washington did not support or condone attacks by Ukraine outside its borders, stating “we’ve been clear with them publicly and we’ve been clear with them privately that we do not encourage nor do we enable them to strike outside Ukraine.” Similarly, US Defense Department spokesperson Garron Garn said the allegations were “com- pletely false” as “the US was in no way involved.”1163


Concerning possible nuclear weapons use, also on May 4, Director of US National Intelligence Avril Haines stated that Russia was “very unlikely, in our current assessment” to use its nuclear arsenal. She did not elaborate further on the US intelligence community assessment.1164


Meanwhile, on May 3, during Zelenskiy’s visit to Finland, a group of Finland, Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Iceland issued a joint statement in which they backed Ukraine to become a member of NATO and the EU. The statement added that the Nordic countries would “continue their political, financial, humani- tarian and military support for as long as it takes.”1165


Concerning military support for Ukraine, the same May 3, a senior US DoD official told media that a Patriot air defense system from the US Army, along with a group of 65 Ukrainian air defenders trained by the US military had arrived in Ukraine the previous week.1166 In Brussels, the European Commission signed off on an act in support of ammunition production, Breton stated. The act allocated more than

$550 million from the EU budget to boost weapons manufacturing, matched with another $550 million in co-financing from member countries, with the aim to produce 1 million rounds of ammunition within one year.1167


Meanwhile, discussions on supplying Ukraine with F-16 jets continued. Helsinki Commission Chair Joe Wilson and ranking member Steve Cohen visited Kyiv in the first week of May and stated that they plan to urge the Biden administration to facilitate the donation of materiel Kyiv has sought for months: F-16 jets and long-range munitions, such as the U.S.-made Army Tactical Missile System.1168


1163 Matt Berg, “Kremlin ‘lying’ about U.S. involvement in Moscow drone strikes, officials say,” [https://www.polit- ico.com/news/2023/05/04/moscow-drone-strikes-kremlin-kirby-00095266]; Pjotr Sauer and Julian Borger, “White House dis- misses ‘ludicrous’ Russian claims US planned Kremlin drone strikes,” [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/may/04/rus- sia-accuses-us-of-being-behind-drone-attack-on-kremlin-putin]; “Ukraine war live: Summary,” Guardian, May 4, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/may/04/russia-ukraine-war-live-air-raid-sirens-in-kyiv-and-eastern-regions- zelenskiy-denies-responsibility-for-kremlin-drone-attack].


1164 “Russia ‘very unlikely’ to use nuclear weapons, US intel chief,” Reuters, May 4, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/eu- rope/russia-very-unlikely-use-nuclear-weapons-us-intel-chief-2023-05-04/].


1165 “Joint statement of the Nordic-Ukrainian Summit in Helsinki,” Government Offices of Sweden, May 3, 2023 [https://www.gov- ernment.se/statements/2023/05/joint-statement-of-the-nordic-ukrainian-summit-in-helsinki/].


1166 Alexander Ward, Matt Berg and Ari Hawkins “The Kremlin drone attack, explained as best we can,” Politico, May 3, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/05/03/the-kremlin-drone-attack-explained-as-best-we- can-00095047].


1167 Alexander Ward, Matt Berg and Ari Hawkins “The Kremlin drone attack, explained as best we can,” Politico, May 3, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/05/03/the-kremlin-drone-attack-explained-as-best-we- can-00095047].


1168 “National Security Daily: On the Hill,” Politico, May 9, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security- daily/2023/05/09/no-atacms-to-ukraine-following-u-k-move-00095936].

US senator Tammy Duckworth stated on May 5 that if F-16s were what Ukraine needed and were ap- propriate, she would support that, but “frankly, what they need more of than anything right now” was artillery and ammunition, which was “something that we’re working hard on producing.”1169


Instead, on May 9, media reported that London was set to send missiles with a range of 300km to Ukraine.1170 On May 11, Wallace confirmed reports that the UK had donated multiple long-range Storm Shadow cruise missiles to Ukraine, stating that these weapons systems would give Ukraine “the best

chance to defend themselves against Russia’s continued brutality, especially the deliberate targeting of Ukrainian infrastructure, which is against international law.” According to Western officials, Britain had received assurances from the Ukrainian government that these missiles would be used only within Ukrainian sovereign territory and not against Russian territory.1171


In reaction to London’s step, the Biden Administration stated on May 9 that it had no plans to follow Britain’s lead in sending long-range missiles to Ukraine, with one US official stating that the US “policy on ATACMS had not changed.”1172 However, on May 9, the US Department of Defense still confirmed a “new security assistance package,” which included more artillery, ammunition, air defense missiles and drones to bolster Ukraine’s air defenses and artillery ammunition needs. Washington sought to spend money to help network the new US Patriot air defense systems with existing Ukrainian Soviet-era air defenses, as well as the French, German and Italian systems at work in Ukraine, the DOD announced.

This package totaled up to $1.2bn and is being provided under the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative (USAI).1173 Moreover, the same day, MEPs voted in Brussels to speed up consideration of a law to boost ammunition production in Europe to €500m to supply Ukraine. The decision should see the new legisla- tion, termed the Act in Support of Ammunition Production (Asap), in place by the end of the year, MEPs and European Commission officials said.1174


Concerning attacks on Russian territory, on May 6, Russian nationalist writer Zakhar Prilepin was wounded in a car bombing, an attack which the Russian foreign ministry blamed on Ukraine and the West, stating that “responsibility for this and other terrorist acts lies not only with Ukrainian authori- ties, but also their western patrons, the United States in the first instance.” Zakharova stated on Tele- gram that the attack was the “direct responsibility of the US and Britain,” and alleged that Washington and NATO had “fed another international terrorist cell – the Kyiv regime.”1175


1169 “National Security Daily: The complex,” Politico, May 5, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security- daily/2023/05/05/duckworth-dod-needs-to-think-ahead-in-the-indo-pacific-00095542].


1170 Karen DeYoung, “Britain prepares to send long-range missiles to Ukraine,” Washington Post, May 9, 2023 [https://www.wash- ingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/05/08/britain-ukraine-long-range-missile/].


1171 “Britain has delivered long-range ‘Storm Shadow’ cruise missiles to Ukraine ahead of expected counteroffensive, sources say,”

CNN, May 11, 2023 [https://edition.cnn.com/2023/05/11/politics/uk-storm-shadow-cruise-missiles-ukraine/index.html].

1172 “National Security Daily: No ATACMS to Ukraine following U.K. move,” Politico, May 9, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news- letters/national-security-daily/2023/05/09/no-atacms-to-ukraine-following-u-k-move-00095936].


1173 “Biden Administration Announces Additional Security Assistance for Ukraine,” US Department of Defense May 9, 2023 [https://www.defense.gov/News/Releases/Release/Article/3388890/biden-administration-announces-additional-security-assis- tance-for-ukraine/]; “National Security Daily: The complex,” Politico, May 9, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/na- tional-security-daily/2023/05/09/no-atacms-to-ukraine-following-u-k-move-00095936].


1174 “More ammunition production to support Ukraine: MEPs to fast-track proposal,” European Parliament, May 9, 2023 [https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20230509IPR86104/more-ammunition-production-to-support- ukraine-meps-to-fast-track-proposal]; “Ukraine war live: Summary,” Guardian, May 9, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/may/09/russia-ukraine-war-live-15-missiles-shot-down-over-kyiv-as-victory-day-begins-in-russia].


1175 “Pro-Kremlin writer Zakhar Prilepin injured in car explosion, says Russia,” Guardian, May 6, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/2023/may/06/pro-kremlin-writer-zakhar-prilepin-injured-in-car-explosion-says-russia].

Regarding air and missile defense efforts in Ukraine, the Ukrainian air force stated on May 6 that a US- made Patriot air-defense missile successfully intercepted a Russian hypersonic Kinzhal missile for the first time over Kyiv on May 4. This was confirmed by three senior US officials.1176 Ahead of Russian ‘Vic- tory Day’ celebrations, Russia attacked Kyiv with nearly three dozen drones overnight, Ukraine’s mili- tary stated on May 8, which amounted to one of the largest direct attacks of the Ukrainian capital as part of a broader aerial assault that also targeted Kharkiv, Kherson, Mykolaiv and Odesa with 16 missiles.

Ukraine’s military said that it shot down all 35 drones, including 30 over Kyiv.1177


On May 9, Putin said in a speech during celebrations marking Russia’s World War II victory on the Red Square that Western nations were waging a “real war” on Moscow and treated Ukraine as a “bargaining chip.” He added that Western elites would “talk about their exceptionalism, dividing people and provok- ing bloody conflicts, sowing hatred, Russophobia and aggressive nationalism, destroying traditional

family values.” The celebrations were scaled back, featuring a single Soviet-era tank, no aircraft and lasted less than an hour.1178 The same May 9, in reaction to Russia’s Victory Day parades, Scholz stated that the EU had to avoid being intimidated by Moscow’s showcasing of military power but continue to support Ukraine for as long as it took.1179


Meanwhile, on May 9, concerning the Black Sea Grain initiative, Blinken and UK foreign secretary James Cleverly urged Russia not to use global hunger as a tool of war in the conflict in Ukraine. Blinken called on Russia to extend and expand the grain initiative, calling Russia blocking ships from sailing to

Ukrainian ports to pick up grain a “cynical action,” adding that “the world shouldn’t need to remind Mos- cow every few weeks to stop using people’s hunger as a weapon in their war against Ukraine.” Similarly, Cleverly stated it was “completely wrong” that Russia used “the hunger of some of the poorest people in the world to pursue leverage in this conflict.”1180


In discussions on the possibility of ending the war, also on May 9, Guterres said there was currently no

prospect of peace between Russia and Ukraine because “both sides are convinced that they can win,” adding he was pessimistic about the EU and the UN’s ability to broker an end to the conflict sparked by Russia’s 2022 invasion.1181 The same May 9, speaking alongside her Chinese counterpart, Qin Gang, at a press conference in Berlin, Baerbock stated China could play a decisive role in ending the war in Ukraine, adding that as a permanent member of the UN security council, China had the power to be in- fluential in the conflict and bring it to an end.1182


1176 “Ukraine Claims It Shot Down Russia’s Most Sophisticated Missile for First Time,” New York Times, May 6, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/06/world/europe/ukraine-russia-war-patriot.html].


1177 “Russia launched a large wave of attack drones over Kyiv, Ukrainian officials say,” New York Times, May 8, 2023 [https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/08/world/europe/russia-drone-attack-kyiv.html].


1178 “Downbeat Putin slams West at low-key Victory Day parade in Russia,” Politico, May 9, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/arti- cle/russia-downbeat-vladimir-putin-slams-at-low-key-victory-day-parade-celebrations-moscow-kremlin-ukraine-war/].


1179 “Europe must not be intimated by Moscow's power plays - Scholz,” Reuters, May 9, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/eu- rope/europe-must-not-be-intimated-by-moscows-power-plays-scholz-2023-05-09/].


1180 “US and UK tell Russia to stop using hunger as leverage in Ukraine conflict,” Guardian, May 9, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/may/09/russia-ukraine-war-live-15-missiles-shot-down-over-kyiv-as-victory-day-begins-in-russia].


1181 David Latona, “UN chief says peace talks in Ukraine conflict not possible right now,” Swissinfo, May 9, 2023 [https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/un-chief-says-peace-talks-in-ukraine-conflict-not-possible-right-now/48497008].


1182 “Germany's Baerbock says China can help end Ukraine war,” Deutsche Welle, May 9, 2023 [https://www.dw.com/en/germa- nys-baerbock-says-china-can-help-end-ukraine-war/a-65566298].

Further dimming the prospects of arms control, according to a decree signed by Putin on May 10, Rus- sia may formally “denounce” the treaty on conventional armed forces in Europe that it pulled out of in 2015. The decree formally appointed Ryabkov to represent Putin during parliamentary proceedings on denouncing the treaty.1183


Also speaking on May 10 at a meeting of NATO’s military committee, Stoltenberg said the alliance needed to “redouble our efforts” in order to provide security to the 1 billion people in NATO countries, citing what he claimed was a range of rising threats.1184


Elsewhere, media reported that Trump had known of Putin’s intent to invade Ukraine. On May 10,

Trump said that he and Putin “used to talk about” Moscow’s intention to launch another invasion in

Ukraine, adding that Putin “would’ve never gone in if I was president. We used to talk about it, too.” Al- exander Vidman, an NSC director for Ukraine in the Trump Administration, confirmed on May 11 that conversations about Russia’s aggression had been “on the agenda consistently” during bilateral meet-

ings, adding that “it was in every set of talking points” he drafted for Trump, “all the background docu- ments” he prepared. Vidman added that warning Russia against escalating the war “was a regular topic.” The same day, a former Trump Administration official said Trump in at least one call told Putin that Russia couldn’t wade deeper into Ukraine because he had approved the transfer of anti-tank missiles to Kyiv. “It was in the context of you can’t do what you did with Obama,” the official said, referring to the annexation of Crimea and the “little green men” in the Donbas.1185


Regarding discussions on peace talks between Russia and Ukraine, on May 12, Putin told South African President Cyril Ramaphosa over the phone that Moscow had never refused the “diplomatic track” to resolving the conflict in Ukraine, adding that he supported the proposal to involve African leaders in talks regarding a peace process for Ukraine.1186 On May 16, Ramaphosa reiterated that six African lead- ers would plan to travel to Russia and Ukraine “as soon as is possible” to help find a resolution to the war, adding that Putin and Zelenskiy had “agreed to receive the mission and the African heads of state,

in both Moscow and Kyiv.”1187 In reaction, on May 18, Peskov said Moscow would be ready to listen to

“any proposals” that would help resolve the conflict.1188


Concerning Chinese efforts to help resolve the Ukraine war, also on May 12, media reported that Bor- rell had sent a paper to EU foreign ministers stating that a Russian defeat in Ukraine would not derail China’s rise, while relations between Beijing and the EU would be “critically affected” if Xi did not push


1183 “Russia moves to 'denounce' European armed forces treaty - decree,” Reuters, May 10, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/russia-moves-denounce-european-armed-forces-treaty-decree-2023-05-10/].


1184 “Opening remarks NATO Military Committee in Chiefs of Defence session,” North Atlantic Treaty Organization, May 10, 2023 [https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/opinions_214383.htm?selectedLocale=en].


1185 “National Security Daily: Trump ‘used to talk about’ Ukraine invasion with Putin,” Politico, May 11, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/05/11/trump-used-to-talk-about-ukraine-invasion-with-putin-00096394]; Aaron Rupar, “’He made a tremendous mistake’ - Trump on Putin,” Twitter, May 11, 2023 [https://twitter.com/atrupar/sta- tus/1656464045145223171?s=20].


1186 “Putin, S.Africa’s Ramaphosa discussed Ukraine in phone call-Kremlin,” Reuters, May 12, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/putin-safricas-ramaphosa-discussed-ukraine-phone-call-kremlin-2023-05-12/]; “Telephone conversation with President of South Africa Cyril Ramaphosa,” Kremlin, May 12, 2023 [http://en.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/71120].


1187 “President Cyril Ramaphosa: Media briefing on Official Visit by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of the Republic of Singapore,” South African Government, 16 May 2023 [https://www.gov.za/speeches/president-cyril-ramaphosa-media-briefing-official-visit- prime-minister-lee-hsien-loong].


1188 “Kremlin says African Ukraine peace delegation will visit Moscow,” Reuters, May 18, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/arti- cle/ukraine-crisis-kremlin-africa-idAFR4N377023].“Ukraine war live: Evening Summary,” Guardian, May 18, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/may/18/russia-ukraine-war-live-updates-kyiv-missile-strikes-attack].

Putin to withdraw his forces from Ukraine.1189 Meanwhile, on the same May 12, China’s foreign minis- try announced that its special representative for Eurasian affairs, Li Hui, would visit Ukraine, Poland, France, Germany and Russia in what it called “an effort to promote peace talks.”1190


Meanwhile, discussions flared up again about attacks on Russian territory. On May 13, media reported that leaked US intercepts would show that Zelensky had plotted attacks inside Russia. Namely,

Ukraine’s leader proposed occupying Russian villages to gain leverage over Moscow, bombing a pipeline that transfers Russian oil to Hungary, and privately pining for long-range missiles to hit targets inside Russia’s borders, according to classified US intelligence documents detailing his internal communica- tions with top aides and military leaders.1191


Elsewhere, Western states pledged more military support to Ukraine. On May 13, media reported that the German government would provide further military equipment worth €2.7bn to Ukraine in what would be the biggest Berlin had provided since Russia’s invasion. The package would include 20 Marder infantry fighting vehicles, 30 Leopard 1 tanks, 15 Gepard anti-aircraft tanks, 200 reconnaissance drones, four additional Iris-T anti-aircraft systems including ammunition, additional artillery ammunition and more than 200 armored combat and logistics vehicles.1192


On May 14, on his first state visit to Berlin since the beginning of the war, Zelenskiy thanked Germany for its support and what he called the largest military aid package since the beginning of the full-scale Russian invasion as he met with Steinmeier and Scholz in Berlin. Scholz pledged to support Ukraine as long as needed to repel Russia’s invasion, and outlined weapons deliveries including new IRIS-T air de- fense systems and Leopard 2 tanks.1193


The same May 14, Macron stated that Russia had “already lost geopolitically” its war in Ukraine and was transforming into a vassal state of China, adding that Russia had “de facto started a form of vasalli- zation with China” and had “lost its access to the Baltic, which was critical, because it prompted the deci- sion by Sweden and Finland to join NATO.”1194 Macron also promised Zelenskiy, who was vising Paris, to “train and equip” several Ukrainian battalions and provide them with “tens of armored vehicles and

light tanks.”1195


1189 “EU tells ministers they must ‘recalibrate’ China policy over support for Russia,” Guardian, May 12, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/may/12/eu-tells-ministers-they-must-recalibrate-china-policy-over-support-for- russia].


1190 Nicolas Camut, “China’s special envoy to visit Ukraine, Russia,” Politico, May 12, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/china- xi-jinping-li-hui-volodymyr-zelenskyy-vladimir-putin-special-envoy-to-visit-ukraine-russia/].


1191 “Zelensky, in private, plots bold attacks inside Russia, leak shows,” Washington Post, May 13, 2023 [https://www.washing- tonpost.com/world/2023/05/13/zelensky-ukraine-war-leaked-documents/].


1192 Matthias Gebauer und Marina Kormbaki, “Bundesregierung schnürt neues Waffenpaket für die Ukraine,” Spiegel, May 13, 2023 [https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/ukraine-bundesregierung-schnuert-neues-waffenpaket-hilfe-fuer-die-fruehjahrsof- fensive-a-220880d8-c19a-4785-a97b-8c2e94e68366?sara_ref=re-so-app-sh].


1193 Loveday Morris and Kate Brady, “Ukraine’s Zelensky visits Germany, turning a page on fragile ties,” Washington Post, May 14, 2023; [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/05/14/zelensky-ukraine-germany-visit-aid/]; “Ukraine war live: Sum- mary,” Guardian, May 14, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/may/14/russia-ukraine-war-live-zelenskiy- arrives-in-berlin-after-germany-announces-further-27bn-of-military-aid].


1194 “Russia denounces Macron over China comments,” Reuters, May 15, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/russia-de- nounces-macron-over-china-comments-2023-05-15/].


1195 “France to give Ukraine more tanks, Macron and Zelenskyy announce,” Politico, May 14, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/arti- cle/volodymyr-zelenskyy-emmanuel-macron-ukraine-war-france/].

After meeting Zelenskiy in Britain, Sunak said on May 15 that Britain would provide Ukraine with hun- dreds of air defense missiles and further unmanned aerial systems, including new long-range attack drones with a range of more than 200km, over the coming months. He added that Ukraine needed “the sustained support of the international community to defend against the barrage of unrelenting and in- discriminate attacks that have been their daily reality for over a year.”1196


Concerning Russian weapons supplies, also on May 15, Kirby stated that the US was seeing more indi- cations that Russia and Iran were expanding an unprecedented defense partnership that would help

Moscow prolong its war in Ukraine as well as pose a threat to Iran’s neighbors. Iran reportedly provided

Russia with one-way attack drones, including more than 400 since august, Kirby said.1197


On May 16, Ukraine’s military said it has neutralized the Kremlin’s most potent hypersonic weapon, shooting down six out of six Kinzhal missiles launched at Kyiv during a sweeping and “exceptionally in- tense” night-time attack. Ukraine’s commander-in-chief, Valerii Zaluzhnyi, moreover claimed Kyiv’s defenders shot down 18 out of 18 Russian rockets and drones. In response, Russia’s defense ministry stated that it had destroyed a US-built Patriot surface-to-air missile defense system overnight with a hy- personic Kinzhal missile attack on Ukraine.1198 Two US officials said later on May 16 that a Patriot sys-

tem had probably suffered damage but that it did not appear to have been destroyed.1199 The following day, Ukrainian air force spokesperson Yuriy Ihnat ruled out the possibility of a Russian Kinzhal missile having destroyed a Patriot system.1200


Meanwhile, discussions on conditions for peace talks and the possibility of the Ukraine war turning into a frozen conflict took off. On May 17, Kuleba reiterated towards China’s special representative for Eura- sian affairs Li Hui at talks in Kyiv that his government would not accept any proposals to end the war with Russia that involved it losing territory or freezing the conflict.1201 After China’s special envoy had met with Zelenskyy, his chief of staff Andriy Yermak, and with Kuleba, Wang stated on May 18 that there was “no remedy to resolve the crisis,” adding that “all parties should create favorable conditions and accumulate mutual trust for the political settlement.” Over two days, Hui and Kuleba had discussed “ways to stop Russian aggression,” the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry stated.”1202 In contrast, on May 17, Lavrov alleged the war in Ukraine may end due to the US abandoning its allies, as Washington had done


1196 “UK pledges attack drones, more missiles as Ukraine’s Zelenskyy meets prime minister on European tour,” AP, May 15, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-zelenskyy-uk-sunak-military-aid-fc6809548de37304fb311fc66ee7d0d0].


1197 “US sees more indication of Russia, Iran defense cooperation,” Reuters, May 16, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/us- sees-more-indications-russia-iran-defense-cooperation-white-house-2023-05-15/].

1199 “Patriot missile defense system in Ukraine kileky damaged, US officials say,” Reuters, May 17, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/patriot-missile-defense-system-ukraine-likely-damaged-us-sources-2023-05-16/].


1200 “Ukraine denies Russia destroyed Patriot missile defence system,” Reuters, May 17, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/busi- ness/aerospace-defense/ukraine-denies-russia-destroyed-patriot-missile-defence-system-2023-05-17/].


1201 “Ukraine tells Chinese envoy it won't accept ceding land to Russia,” Reuters, May 17, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/ukraine-tells-china-envoy-it-would-not-accept-proposals-ceding-territory-russia-2023-05-17/].


1202 “China says Ukraine envoy met with Zelenskyy during talks in Kyiv,” AP, May 18, 2023 [https://apnews.com/article/china- ukraine-zelenskyy-envoy-a9be43651b773735a99e1edef64bd6af].

before in Afghanistan.1203 Instead, on May 18, according to US officials, various US agencies and the White House were discussing the possibility that the Russia-Ukraine war might turn into a frozen con- flict that could last many years. Three current and a former Biden administration official confirmed that an extended freeze in fighting was one possibility for which the US government was preparing.1204


Regarding the Ukrainian bid for F-16s jets, Sunak and Rutte agreed on May 16 to build an “interna-

tional coalition” to help Ukraine procure such weapons. A UK spokesperson said the two governments “would work to build an international coalition to provide Ukraine with combat air capabilities, support- ing with everything from training to procuring F-16 jets.”1205 Senior US officials stated on May 18 that the Biden administration was still reluctant to send Ukraine its own F-16s, in part because the plane’s multimillion-dollar price tag would absorb too much of an already-dwindling war funding.1206 And Nor- way’s defense minister Bjørn Arild Gram said his government donating F-16 fighter jets to Ukraine was not on the agenda at the moment.1207


However, Biden told G7 leaders on May 19 that Washington would back a joint international effort to train Ukrainian pilots to fly F-16 and other modern fighter jets. According to a senior administration of- ficial, the plan would include training “on fourth-generation fighter aircraft, including F-16s.” The official added that the training would take place “over the coming months” and that the participating countries

would decide “when to actually provide jets, how many … and who” would provide them. 1208 In reaction,

Denmark’s ministry of defense stated the same May 19 that it would train Ukrainian F-16 pilots.1209 In response, Russia’s Deputy FM Alexander Grushko stated the following May 20 that Western coun- tries would be running “enormous risks” if they supplied Ukraine with F-16 fighter jets.1210

At the same time, on May 18, Wallace stated that the long-range Storm Shadow missiles Britain had provided had already been used in Ukraine.1211 And on May 19, the United States and Australia im- posed a new set of sanctions on Russia. Washington halted the exports of a number of consumer goods out of concern that they might be repurposed to support Russia’s war in Ukraine. Meanwhile, Australian PM Anthony Albanese and foreign minister Penny Wong announced sanctions that would target nu- merous entities.1212 In a similar vein, on May 20, Sunak announced a UK ban on imports of Russian dia- monds and Russian-origin copper, nickel and aluminum.1213


190.

Warning

Meeting in Hiroshima, the G7 nations condemned Russia’s “brutal” war on its neighbor Ukraine “in the strongest possible terms,” calling it a “serious violation of international law,” in its final commu- nique of their summit, released on May 20. As part of the statement, the G7 called for “just and lasting peace” and recommitted to providing Ukraine with military, financial and humanitarian support.1214 Their May 19 communique on nuclear policy had made clear that “Russia’s irresponsible nuclear

rhetoric” and “stated intent to deploy nuclear weapons in Belarus” were “dangerous and unaccepta- ble.” The G7 reiterated that “threats by Russia of nuclear weapon use, let alone any use of nuclear weapons by Russia, in the context of its aggression against Ukraine [were] inadmissible.”1215 In reac- tion, on May 21, Russia’s foreign ministry dismissed the G7 summit as a “politicized” event which it said had pumped out anti-Russian and anti-Chinese statements.1216


Meanwhile, as a response to the ICC issuing an arrest warrant for Putin, on May 20, the Russian gov- ernment placed the ICC prosecutor, Karim Khan, and ICC judge Rosario Albatore Aitala on a wanted list.1217 The Russian national investigative committee stated that both were charged with “preparing to attack a representative of a foreign country enjoying international protection in order to complicate in- ternational relations.”1218

1217 Andrew Roth, “Russia issues arrest order for British ICC prosecutor after Putin warrant,” Guardian, May 19, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/law/2023/may/19/russia-arrest-order-international-criminal-court-prosecutor-karim-khan]; “Russia puts war crimes prosecutor on ‘wanted list’,” Politico, May 19, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/russia-vladimir- putin-karim-khan-british-icc-prosecutor-karim-khan-on-a-wanted-list/].


1218 “Russia indicts ICC prosecutor, judge who issued war crimes warrant for Putin,” AP, May 21, 2023 [https://apnews.com/arti- cle/russia-indictment-icc-prosecutor-judge-putin-260100f9ba533e15ebee3084dba74ff4].

Regarding military aid to Ukraine, on May 21, the White House announced a new package of up to

$375m, including ammunition, artillery, armored vehicles and training. In addition, on May 22, defense ministers from twelve northern European countries met in Poland to discuss stepping up the deter- rence and security on NATO’s eastern flank and strengthening Ukraine’s defenses. The talks were de- scribed as “very good” by the Polish defense minister and focused on coordinating ways of providing se- curity to countries in the group.1219


In Washington, Biden defended his reluctance about sending F-16 fighter jets to Ukraine despite con- stant calls from Kyiv, but he added that his Administration’s recent authorization of training on the jets was intended to deter further Russian aggression down the line.1220


191.

Warning

In what appeared to be a warning in reaction to Biden’s announcement to support training of Ukrain-

ian pilots on F-16 fighter jets, as well as the US’ “unconditional approval of strikes on the Crimea us-

ing American and other Western weapons,” Antonov stated on May 22 that “such steps” would “once again clearly demonstrate” that the US had “never been interested in peace,” but only in “a strategic

defeat for Russia.” He added that he “would like to warn representatives of the administration against thoughtless judgments on Crimea, especially in terms of blessing the Kyiv regime for air attacks on the peninsula. Let me remind you that strikes on this territory are considered by us as an attack on any other region of the Russian Federation. It is important that the United States is fully aware of the Rus- sian response.”1221


Despite these strong statements of disapproval from Moscow, as of May 22, Belgium, the Netherlands and Denmark had signaled their willingness to train Ukrainian pilots to fly F-16 jets, although they did not comment on sending jets. A Norwegian military spokesperson stated that Oslo was still evaluating its options concerning training and supplying Ukraine with F-16s.1222 The training mission had “started in several countries,” Borrell said on May 23. The same day, Denmark’s acting Defense Minister Troels Lund Poulsen said that Ukrainian pilots could start training on F-16 jets in July, adding that it would then “probably … take up to six months before we have the facilities in place so that we can fly F-16

fighter jets from Ukraine.”1223 Also on May 23, Pistorius stated that Germany was also looking into op- tions to support a coalition of countries that planned to train Ukrainian pilots in flying F-16s, adding that any potential German contribution could be minor only, as Germany did not own any of the US-built jets.1224 The following May 24, Dutch defense minister Kajsa Ollongren stated in a letter to parliament
