1224 “Ukraine F-16 training has begun in Poland, Borrell announces,” Euractiv, May 23, 2023 [https://www.euractiv.com/sec- tion/global-europe/news/ukraine-f-16-training-has-begun-in-poland-borrell-announces/]; “Ukraine war live: Summary,” Guard- ian, May 23, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/may/23/russia-ukraine-war-live-updates-latest-news-belgo- rod-kremlin-russian-pm-china].

that the Netherlands wanted to offer Ukrainian pilots F-16 training as soon as possible. The training would be coordinated with Belgium, Denmark and the UK, and other countries could join, Ollongren added.1225 On May 26, Swedish Defense Minister Pal Jonson said that Stockholm was open to training Ukrainians on Gripen fighter jets, although “at this stage” Sweden would not deliver such jets to Ukraine.1226


Meanwhile, also on May 23, Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin arrived in China to meet with Xi Jinping and discuss a series of deals on infrastructure and trade.1227 The following day, Mishustin said that relations between Russia and China were at an “unprecedented high level.”1228

At the same time, the possible use of Western equipment against Russian territory sparked discussions. On May 22/23, a two-day incursion into Russia’s Belgorod region took place. Already on May 22, Podol- yak stated Ukraine had “no direct relationship” with the events, instead he casted the attack as a home- grown, internal Russian strife carried out by underground partisans comprising Russian citizens.1229

The same day, Ukrainian military intelligence spokesperson Andriy Yusov stated that the Russian Vol- unteer Corps (RVC) and the Freedom of Russia Legion had launched the operation. Both groups claimed responsibility the same day.1230 In reaction, on May 23, Russia’s military said it had routed militants who attacked its western Belgorod region with armored vehicles, killing more than 70 “Ukrainian na- tionalists” and pushing the remainder back into Ukraine.1231 RVC and Freedom of Russia Legion, how- ever, stated that only two of their soldiers died while 12 were wounded.1232


192.

Warning

In reaction to these attacks inside Russia, the Kremlin accused “pro-Ukrainian fighters” on May 24 to have conducted the raid and stated that the use of US-made military hardware was testament to the West’s growing involvement in the Ukraine conflict. Shoigu promised the same day that Moscow would respond to any more cross-border raids by Ukrainian militants swiftly and “extremely

harshly.” Peskov stated that it was “no secret” that “the direct and indirect involvement of Western

countries in this conflict” was “growing by the day,” adding that Russia was “drawing the appropriate


1225 “Netherlands wants to give Ukrainian pilots F-16 training as soon as possible,” Reuters, May 24, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/netherlands-wants-give-ukrainian-pilots-f-16-training-soon-possible-2023-05-24/].


1226 Catherine Nicholls, “Sweden will consider training Ukrainian pilots on Gripen fighter jets if asked, says defense minister,” CNN, May 26, 2023 [https://edition.cnn.com/europe/live-news/russia-ukraine-war-news-05-26- 23/h_d50ff45b244c1d5b013b8b82ef7d8348].


1227 “Ukraine war live: Summary,” Guardian, May 23, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/may/23/russia- ukraine-war-live-updates-latest-news-belgorod-kremlin-russian-pm-china].


1228“Russia, China seal economic pacts amid Western criticism,” Reuters, May 24, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/russia- china-set-ink-bilateral-pacts-despite-western-criticism-2023-05-24/].


1229 “В Офісі президента відреагували на звинувачення РФ щодо подій у Бєлгородській області,” Radio free Europe, May 22, 2023 [https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/newspodiyi-byelhorod-ukrayina-reaktsiya/32422673.html].

1231 “Ukraine war: Belgorod incursion may stretch Russia's defences,” Reuters, May 24, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/eu- rope/cross-border-incursions-ukraine-may-stretch-russian-defences-2023-05-24/]; “Anti-Putin Russians say they launched a cross-border attack from Ukraine. conclusions.”1233 In response, Kirby stated the same May 24 that Washington was looking into these reports, adding that the United States had been clear with Kyiv that it would not support any such use of US-made equipment.1234 The same May 24, the head of Russia’s foreign intelligence service Sergei Naryshkin accused Washington and London of thwarting efforts to reach a settlement over the con-

flict in Ukraine and of turning a blind eye to what he said was increasing “terrorism and violence” vis- ited on Russia’s civilians by Ukraine. Naryshkin expressed satisfaction that most countries in Asia, Af- rica and Latin America had not imposed sanctions on Russia over its actions in Ukraine, despite what

he called colossal pressure to do so from Washington.1235


Regarding discussions on granting NATO membership to Ukraine, also on May 24, Stoltenberg stated that Ukraine would not be able to join NATO as long as the war was ongoing, adding that the issue was “what happens when the war ends.”1236


193.

Escalatory

Meanwhile, the Russian plan to deploy nuclear weapons to Belarus progressed. On May 25, Shoigu and Lukashenko signed a corresponding agreement to store Moscow’s nuclear weapons in Belarus, with Lukashenko stating that the relocation of some tactical nuclear weapons from Russia to Belarus had begun. Control of the weapons was planned to remain with the Kremlin, and it was unclear how many nuclear weapons would be stored in Belarus. Russian and Belarusian officials said that the move was a direct result of Russia’s perception of increased Western aggression. “In the context of an extremely sharp escalation of threats on the western borders of Russia and Belarus, a decision was made to take countermeasures in the military-nuclear sphere,” Shoigu said. Belarusian Defense Min- ister Viktor Khrenin called the deal “an effective response to the aggressive policy of countries un-

friendly to us,” and also announced plans to “build up the combat potential of the regional grouping of Russia and Belarusian troops,” including the transfer to Minsk of the Iskander-M missile system, ca-

pable of carrying a nuclear charge, and the S-400 anti-aircraft missile system.1237


194.

Warning

In reaction to Russia’s stated intention to deploy nuclear weapons to Belarus, also on May 25, Miller

said the US government strongly condemned this arrangement, which he called “the latest example of irresponsible behavior,” repeating Washington’s warning that a use of chemical, biological or nuclear

1234 “US investigates claims American gear used in raids on Russia,” Politico, May 24, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/article/us- investigate-claims-american-gear-military-vehicle-used-raids-russia-ukraine/].

1236 “Ukraine joining NATO in midst of war 'not on agenda' -Stoltenberg,” Reuters, May 24, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/ukraine-joining-nato-midst-war-not-agenda-stoltenberg-2023-05-24/].


1237 Yuras Karmanau “Russia signs deal to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus,” AP, May 25, 2023 [https://apnews.com/ar- ticle/belarus-russia-nuclear-weapons-shoigu-285ff887e8b1c28d20ff68e1d775441e]; “Belarus' president says transfer of tactical nuclear weapons from Russia has already started,” Guardian, May 25, 2023 [https://www.theguard- ian.com/world/live/2023/may/25/russia-ukraine-war-live-updates-russian-rebels-belgorod-attack-raid-anti-putin-militia-lat- est-news?filterKeyEvents=false&page=with:block-646f7fea8f08e69f06831877#block-646f7fea8f08e69f06831877].

quences. He added that the US government had, however, not seen any reason to adjust its nuclear posture or any indications that Russia was preparing to use a nuclear weapon.1238


The same May 25, Russia’s foreign ministry stated that it had summoned the ambassadors of Germany, Sweden, and Denmark to protest the “complete lack of results” in an investigation to identify who had blown up the Nord Stream gas pipelines the previous year. The Russian government accused all three countries of trying to conceal who was behind the blasts, adding that it was unhappy about what it called the opaque nature of the investigation and its refusal to engage with Russia.1239


195.

Warning

Nuclear warnings once again returned to the forefront. Signaling skepticism of an approaching end to the Ukraine war, on May 26, Medvedev said the conflict in Ukraine would last “for a very long time,” and “probably” for “decades.” Negotiations with Ukraine were inevitable but impossible as long as Zelenskiy was in power. He said Russia could not trust any truce with the current rulers of Kyiv as the conflict would simply erupt again and so the very nature of the current government of Ukraine would have to be destroyed. Medvedev also warned that the West was seriously underestimating the risk of a nuclear war over Ukraine, cautioning that Russia would launch a pre-emptive strike if Ukraine got nuclear weapons. Allowing Ukraine nuclear weapons would mean “a missile with a nuclear charge

coming to them.” He added that “the Anglo-Saxons” would “not fully realize this and believe that it will not come to this. It will under certain conditions.”1240


The same May 26, echoing Russia’s reluctance to commit to peace talks, Lavrov told Hui that there were “serious obstacles” to resuming peace talks, blaming Ukraine and western countries.1241 Nonetheless, Putin, in a phone call with Lula da Silva, stated that Russia was open to dialogue over Ukraine.1242


Against this background, western support for Ukraine continued. On May 26, Canadian trade minister Mary Ng said Canada would welcome Ukraine’s application to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP).1243 Moreover, the previous day, Canada’s minister of

1242 “Brazil's Lula says spoke to Putin on war, declined economic forum invitation,” Reuters, May 26, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/brazils-lula-said-spoke-putin-war-declined-invitation-economic-forum-2023-05-26/].


1243 “Canada backs Ukraine's application to join trans-Pacific trade pact,” Reuters, May 27, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/canada-backs-ukraines-application-join-trans-pacific-trade-pact-2023-05-26].

defense Anita Anand said Canada would donate 43 AIM-9 missiles to Ukraine to help the country “se- cure its skies in the face of ongoing Russian attacks.”1244


Elsewhere, the same May 26, Japan’s chief cabinet secretary Hirokazu Matsuno stated that Japan would place additional sanctions on Russia after the Group of Seven (G7) summit the country hosted the previous week had agreed to step up measures to punish Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine.1245 In response, the following May 27, Russia accused Japan of “cynical, unscrupulous speculation” over Tokyo’s com- ments around the nuclear threat Moscow poses and promised to respond to Japan’s latest round of sanc- tions.1246


Also on May 27, Russia’s embassy in the US dismissed US criticism vis-à-vis nuclear deployment to Bela- rus, saying Washington had for decades deployed just such nuclear weapons in Europe.1247


On May 28, the EU’s spokesperson for foreign affairs and security policy, Nabila Massrali, said Russia

would be “held accountable” for attacks on civilian areas. 1248

Meanwhile, on May 29, Lukashenko said that if any other country wanted to join a Russia-Belarus un- ion there could be “nuclear weapons for everyone,” adding “we need to strategically understand that we have a unique chance to unite.” Kazahk President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev dismissed Lukashenko’s invi- tation to join the union as a “joke,” adding that Kazakhstan was already a member of the Russian-led Eurasian Economic Union, so no further integration was necessary. He also stated that Kazakhstan would not need nuclear weapons as it had joined the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and Comprehen- sive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty.1249


196.

Warning

Meanwhile, Russian warnings against Western weapons supplies to Ukraine were renewed. The same May 27, the Russian ambassador to the UK, Andrei Kelin stated that Russia had warned that West- ern supplies to Ukraine risked escalating the war to levels not seen so far, saying that it was “a big

idealistic mistake” to think that Ukraine would prevail since Russia had “enormous resources” and it was yet to “act very seriously.” He added that this depended on the escalation of the war that was tak-

ing place and "sooner or later, of course, this escalation may get a new dimension which we do not

need and we do not want. We can make peace tomorrow if the Ukrainian side will be prepared to ne-

On May 29, Podolyak detailed a possible peace plan, suggesting that any peace settlement acceptable to Ukraine would have to include not only a restoration of the country’s sovereign borders, but a demilita- rized zone extending between 100km and 120km into Russia. Podolyak tweeted: “The key topic of the postwar settlement should be the establishment of safeguards to prevent a recurrence of aggression in the future. To ensure real security for residents of Kharkiv, Chernihiv, Sumy, Zaporizhzhia, Luhansk and Donetsk regions and protect them from shelling, it will be necessary to introduce a demilitarization zone of 100km-120km on the territory of Belgorod, Bryansk, Kursk, and Rostov republics. Probably with a mandatory international control contingent at the first stage.”1251 Also contributing to the debate of how to end the war in Ukraine, in a speech in Moldova on May 31, Macron stated the West may at some stage have to negotiate with the existing Russian leadership even as it pursued international justice against the same individuals. He also reiterated that Ukraine needed security assurances.1252


At the end of May, the US and Denmark announced additional weapons supplies for Ukraine. On May 29, Danish prime minister Mette Frederiksen said that her government planned to increase spending on military aid to Ukraine by $2.6bn in 2023 and 2024.1253 On May 31, the US administration announced a

$300 million package for Ukraine featuring munitions for the Patriot missile defense system, artillery rounds and more than 30 million rounds of small arms ammo.1254


At the same time, on May 30, Moscow was targeted with a large-scale drone attack for the first time in its 15-month-old war in Ukraine. In reaction, Putin said that Ukraine had chosen the path of attempting “to intimidate Russia, Russian citizens [with] attacks on residential buildings” and added that the drone attacks were “clearly a sign of terrorist activity.”1255 Figures from Russia, including the head of Chech- nya, Ramzan Kadyrov, said Putin should declare martial law nationwide to “sweep away that terrorist gang.” Podolyak, stated that Ukraine was “pleased to watch and predict an increase in the number of attacks,” but had “nothing directly to do with this.”1256 In a sarcastic tweet, he added that “even artificial

ship.”1257 Also on May 30, the White House said that it was still gathering information about what hap- pened in Moscow, repeating its earlier statements that it did “not support attacks inside Russia.”1258 The following May 31, Peskov stated that Russia would not plan to declare martial law after the large-scale drone strike.1259


In a similarly de-escalating statement, Kirby said on the same May 31 that Washington was planning to continue to give Ukraine what it needed to defend itself and its territory, “but we don’t support attacks

on Russia”. He added that “we don't want to encourage or enable attacks inside Russia, because we don't want to see the war escalate beyond the violence has already visited upon the Ukrainian people.”1260


June 2023: Some Russian nuclear rhetoric returns with Ukraine’s offensive


In June, discussions on Ukraine’s NATO membership and security guarantees for the country continued. On May 31, Macron had reiterated that NATO needed to provide “strong and tangible” security guaran- tees or “an architecture of security” for Ukraine ahead of the alliance’s Vilnius summit in July if it wanted a sustainable peace and wanted to be credible toward Ukraine, adding that Kyiv needed a clear “path” to become a NATO member. The following June 1 at a NATO foreign ministers meeting, French foreign minister Catherine Colonna said that NATO needed to think about what kind of security guarantees it could offer Ukraine.1261 The same day, Lithuania’s foreign minister Gabrielius Landsbergis also noted that the time had come for NATO members to find a concrete answer to the question of how Ukraine could become a member, while Stoltenberg stated that the focus of NATO foreign ministers had been to “bring Ukraine closer to NATO, where it belongs” and that the alliance had to “have in place frameworks to provide guarantees for Ukrainian security after the end of the war.”1262 In contrast, on the same June 1, Scholz only said that “there must also be guarantees for a peace order after the war” and that Ger- many would “make a contribution to this.” Meanwhile, Kallas stated that the “only security guarantee” that “works” was NATO membership.1263 On June 2, Wallace said that the path was open to Ukraine, alt- hough political realities may slow the process as it was not possible to add members in the middle of a

1262 “Ukraine war live: Summary,” Guardian, June 1, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/jun/01/russia- ukraine-war-live-three-killed-in-kyiv-as-russia-launches-fresh-overnight-strikes].


1263 “National Security Daily: I want a guarantee,” Politico, June 2, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security- daily/2023/06/02/saudi-sportswashing-getting-messi-00099867].

war. In reaction to these discussions, also on June 2, Zelenskiy said he understood Ukraine would not join NATO while the war with Russia was ongoing.1264


Reacting to these statements, Peskov stated on the same June 2 that Ukraine’s membership in NATO was “one of the main irritants and would be a potential problem for many, many years,” an issue he said many EU countries were “well aware of” though the US ultimately called the tunes at the military alli- ance. He added that Kyiv’s NATO ambitions indicated “the unpreparedness, the unwillingness and the

incapacity of the Kyiv regime to resolve existing problems at the negotiating table.” Peskov underlined that Russia would “ensure its interests and its security,” which excluded the “expansion of NATO and its direct approach to our borders.”1265


Concerning the question of whether the US government had been holding back military equipment out of fear of Russia’s potential reaction, a senior US administration official stated on June 1 that this fear had “always been overstated compared to others, like what would actually help [Ukraine] in the fight.” A

US Department of Defense official added that Kyiv’s troops proved repeatedly that they would not use US-provided equipment to strike deep into Russian territory, making it less risky to deliver Ukraine ad- vanced weapons and technology.1266


Meanwhile, discussions on arms control questions continued. On June 1, the US State Department stated that Washington would stop providing Moscow some notifications required under New START, including updates on its missiles and launcher locations, to retaliate for Moscow’s “ongoing violations” of the accord.1267


In a much-awaited speech, Sullivan stated on June 2 that the Biden administration was willing to con- duct “unconditional” talks with Russia and China. Sullivan further noted that the Administration was not planning to deploy additional nuclear weapons to match Russia and China’s growing arsenals, but that it would rely on conventional options to retain military dominance and on enhanced relations with allies and partners around the world.1268


In reaction, on June 3, Ryabkov warned Washington that it should stop brandishing ultimatums over the collapse of arms control agreements, saying that Moscow would only return to a nuclear arms reduc- tion treaty if Washington abandoned its hostile stance. Ryabkov stated that the pillars of arms control were collapsing and were in “semi-lethal” condition due to what he cast as the hostile policies of the US. “Talking to the Russian Federation in the language of ultimatums just does not work,” he stated. Moscow would come back to full compliance with the New Start treaty if Washington abandoned its “hostile

1265 “Kremlin says Ukrainian NATO membership would cause problems for many years,” Reuters, June 2, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/kremlin-says-europe-knows-risks-ukraine-joining-nato-us-calls-tunes-2023-06-02/].


1266 “National Security Daily: Who’s afraid of Vladimir Putin,” Politico, June 1, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/na- tional-security-daily/2023/06/01/whos-afraid-of-vladimir-putin-00099623].


1267 “U.S. Countermeasures in Response to Russia’s Violations of the New START Treaty,” US Department of State, June 1, 2023 [https://www.state.gov/u-s-countermeasures-in-response-to-russias-violations-of-the-new-start-treaty/]; Jonathan Landay and Arshad Mohammed, “US to stop giving Russia some New START nuclear arms data,” Reuters, June 2, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/us-stop-giving-russia-some-new-start-nuclear-arms-data-2023-06-02/].


1268 “Remarks by National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan for the Arms Control Association (ACA) Annual Forum,” White Houset, June 2, 2023 [https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2023/06/02/remarks-by-national-security-advi- sor-jake-sullivan-for-the-arms-control-association-aca-annual-forum/].

stance” towards Moscow, he added.1269 On June 5, Peskov stated that it was “an important and positive statement,” but that he expected it to be supported with steps through diplomatic channels. He added that Russia remained “open to dialogue, and we believe it was of paramount importance,” but needed to “understand how this offer is formulated.”1270


Meanwhile, debates continued on how and under which conditions peace in Ukraine could be reached. The same June 2, Blinken said Washington was working with Kyiv and other allies to build consensus around the core elements of a “just and lasting peace” to end the war with Russia. Washington would also encourage initiatives by other countries to bring about an end to the conflict, as long as they upheld the UN charter and Ukraine’s sovereignty, territorial integrity and independence.1271 Blinken underlined that a “cease-fire that simply freezes current lines in place” would enable Putin “to consolidate control over the territory he has seized, and rest, rearm, and re-attack.” This was “not a just and lasting peace” but would instead “reward the aggressor.” He added that the US would support negotiations if and when Russia was “ready to work for true peace,” but rejected any calls for a “land for peace” deal, whereby Kyiv agreed to give up some of its sovereign territory to end the war.1272


China continued to boost its role in the conflict. Li stated the same June 2 that Beijing was considering “sending another delegation to relevant countries to engage in dialogue on resolving the Ukraine crisis.” He rejected a media report saying China promoted a ceasefire that would leave its ally Russia occupying parts of Ukraine and said Beijing would “do anything” to ease tensions. However, he acknowledged a

“big gap between both sides’ positions” and “getting all sides to negotiate now would still face a lot of

difficulties.” He stated that the “the risk of escalation of the Russia-Ukraine” was “still high,” adding that all sides must take concrete measures to “cool down the situation” and ensure safety of nuclear facili- ties.1273 He also underlined that the Chinese leadership believed “that weapon supply to the battlefield should cease if the war is to stop, lives are to be saved and peace is to be realized, otherwise the risk of spiraling tensions will only increase.”1274


In reaction to China’s efforts, the same June 2 a French official said that during his delegation’s visit in May, Li had not presented any peace plan but the meeting was rather “doing a roundtable of each of our positions,” adding that Paris did not expect China to be a mediator, but that it could “use its influence on Russia” and could “help make it understand.”1275


Other nations also attempted to mediate in the conflict. On June 3, Indonesia’s defense minister Prabowo Subianto called for a ceasefire and the establishment of a demilitarized zone by withdrawing 15 kilometers from each party’s forward position – to be monitored by a UN peacekeeping force. How- ever, the proposed plan was dismissed the same day by Ukrainian foreign ministry spokesperson Oleg

1270 “Kremlin welcomes U.S. readiness for dialogue with Russia on new nuclear arms control system - Peskov,” Interfax, June 5, 2023 [https://interfax.com/newsroom/top-stories/91166/].

1273 “China weighs next Ukraine peace mission after first yields little progress,” Reuters, June 2, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/neither-ukraine-nor-russia-have-shut-door-talks-china-envoy-2023-06-02/].


1274 Missy Ryan, “U.S. rebuffs cease-fire calls in its strategy for Ukraine resilience,” Washington Post, June 2, 2023 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/06/02/ukraine-russia-blinken-address-finland/].


1275 “China weighs next Ukraine peace mission after first yields little progress,” Reuters, June 2, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/neither-ukraine-nor-russia-have-shut-door-talks-china-envoy-2023-06-02/].

Nikolenko, who reiterated Kyiv’s position that Russia should withdraw its troops from Ukraine and that “no disputed territories” but only occupied territories existed.1276


The US government’s efforts to strengthen Ukrainian defenses also continued. The Pentagon said on June 2 that training for Ukrainian forces on advanced US Abrams tanks had started, but that those weapons would not be ready in time for Kyiv’s counteroffensive.1277 On the same day, allies attending a summit in Moldova on 1 June signaled that F-16 fighter jets could be made available to Ukraine within six months. Several countries, including the UK, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and Belgium, said they wanted to help procure F-16s for Ukraine. Zelenskiy said he had received “powerful support.”1278 On 4 June, the Peskov stated that any supply of missiles to Kyiv by France and Germany with a range of 500 km or more would lead to “another round of spiraling tension” in the Ukraine conflict. Peskov also reiterated that Russia would continue its operations in Ukraine until the “job is done,” stating that there was “no alternative.”1279


Concerning the attribution of several drone attacks on Russian territory in May, US officials told media on June 5 that they assessed that Ukraine had developed sabotage cells inside Russia made up of a mix of pro-Ukrainian sympathizers and operatives well-trained in this kind of warfare. Ukraine was believed to have provided these operatives with Ukrainian-made drones, and, according to two US officials, there was no evidence that any of the drone strikes had been conducted using US-provided weapons.1280


Meanwhile, on June 5, the US delegation to the US-Ukraine Cyber Dialogue reaffirmed its unwavering commitment to support Ukraine’s cyber defense in the face of Russia’s invasion. As part of this support, Washington was working to deliver an additional $37 million in cyber assistance to Ukraine, the State Department stated.1281


Media then focused on developments in the Russia-occupied south of Ukraine, where the Nova Kakhovaka dam was destroyed on 6 June, with 80 villages located in the immediate flooding zone. The dam supplied water to the Crimean peninsula and Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant. While western re- actions signaled that it remained unclear who was responsible, they condemned the destruction of the dam and suspected it was Russia. Accordingly, media reported on the same June 6 that the US govern- ment had intelligence leaning towards the Kremlin being responsible, according to two US officials and one Western official, while Russian officials stated Ukraine was responsible. 1282 Kirby stated the same June 6, that the US could “not say conclusively” who was responsible but was doing its best to assess,

1282 Yuliya Talmazan, Daniel Arkin, Sarah Kaufman and Daryna Mayer, “Ukraine accuses Russia of blowing up a major dam; Krem- lin blames Kyiv,” NBC News, June 6, 2023 [https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/kakhovka-dam-ukraine-russia-destroyed- rcna87852].

adding that “destruction of civilian infrastructure is not allowed by the laws of war.”1283 Also on June 6, Stoltenberg stated that this was “an outrageous act,” which demonstrated “once again the brutality of Russia’s war against Ukraine.”1284 Sunak said that if the bursting of the Kakhovka dam was proven to be intentional, it would represent a “new low” in Russian aggression, adding that the UK’s military and in- telligence agencies were looking into the blast and it was too soon to pre-empt the cause and make a de- finitive judgment.1285


The incident sparked escalatory rhetoric. The same day, Zelenskiy condemned the attack on the dam as “an environmental bomb of mass destruction,” calling it a “terrorist” act. “Such deliberate destruction by the Russian occupiers and other structures of the hydroelectric power station is an environmental bomb of mass destruction,” he said. 1286 Ukraine’s foreign ministry called for an urgent meeting of UN security council to discuss what it called a Russian “terrorist act against Ukrainian critical infrastructure.”1287 Danilov claimed that Russia’s 205th Motorized Rifle Brigade was directly responsible.1288 Also on June 6, Yermak said he did not understand how there could be any doubts that Russian forces blew up the

hydroelectric station and its dam at 2.50am, since both constructions were “located in the temporary Russian-occupied territories.” He added that “neither shelling nor any other external influence” would have been capable of destroying the structures as “the explosion came from within.”1289


Peskov, in contrast, stated on June 6 that Moscow could “state unequivocally” that the explosion was due to “deliberate sabotage by the Ukrainian side,” demanding that Kyiv to “bear full responsibility for

all the consequences.” He strongly rejected the Ukrainian allegations that Russia had destroyed the dam, adding that “here we are definitely talking about deliberate sabotage from the Ukrainian side,” which could potentially have very serious consequences for several tens of thousands of residents of the re- gion.”1290 On June 7, Putin accused Kyiv of destroying the Kakhovka dam at the suggestion of the West,

in what he called a “barbaric” war crime that escalated the conflict with Moscow.1291 The same June 7,

1291 “Ukraine war live: Closing summary,” Guardian, June 7, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/jun/07/rus- sia-ukraine-war-live-updates-nova-kakhovka-dam-collapse-kherson-oblast-floods-evacuations-flood-flooding-latest-news].

the Russian permanent mission to the UN stated the responsibility for the “unfolding tragedy” in Kher- son due to the destruction of the Kakhovka dam rested with “the Kiev regime and its Western masters who pump up Ukraine with weapons.”1292


Against the destruction of the dam, media reported on June 6, 2023 on new evidence related to the de- struction of the Nord Stream pipeline on September 26, 2022. Apparently, the CIA had received intelli- gence from a close US ally from Europe in June 2022 – three months before the Nord Stream pipelines were destroyed – that the Ukrainian military was planning a covert attack on the undersea network using a small team of divers who reported directly to the commander in chief of the Ukrainian armed forces, Valery Zaluzhny – who had been put in charge so that Zelensky would not know about the opera- tion, the intelligence report said. The intelligence summary reported on by the media stated that the

Ukrainian military operation had been “put on hold” for reasons that remained unclear. The Ukrainians had planned to attack the pipeline on the heels of the major allied naval exercise BALTOPS that ran June 5-17, 2022, according to the report. The source’s information could not immediately be corroborated, but the CIA had shared the report with Germany and other European countries in June, with highly spe- cific details including numbers of operatives and methods of attack, according to multiple officials famil- iar with the matter.1293 On June 13, 2023 media reported that the CIA had even warned Ukraine not to destroy the Nord Stream pipeline months before the attack.1294 In reaction, Zelenskyy denied again on June 7 that Ukraine had any involvement in destroying the pipelines. He insisted that he did “not know anything, 100 percent,” adding that if the Ukrainian military was “supposed to have done this, show us proof.”1295 On June 13, media reported that the CIA had even warned Ukraine not to destroy Nord Stream months before the attack.1296


Paris planned to send aid to Ukraine “to meet immediate needs” after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam, Macron said on June 7, calling the destruction an “atrocious act which is endangering popula- tions.”1297 On June 9, Kishida also told Zelenskyi that Japan would offer emergency humanitarian aid worth a few million dollars.1298 The same June 9, the Norwegian Seismic Array Norsar published seis- mic data suggesting that the Kakhovka dam had been blown up with a blast at the site. Signals from a regional station in Romania pointed to an explosion at 2.54am on June 6. Norsar did not draw conclu- sions on who was responsible.1299 The same day, Ukraine’s domestic security agency said it had inter- cepted a telephone call proving Russian forces blew up the Kakhovka station and dam in Kherson re- gion. It posted a 90-second audio clip of the alleged conversation on its Telegram channel in which one

person said “Our saboteur group is there. They wanted to cause fear with this dam. It did not go accord- ing to the plan. More than they planned.”1300 Further engaging in discussions on who had caused the Kakhovka dam explosion, Ukraine’s deputy defense minister Hanna Maliar stated on June 11 that Rus- sian forces had blown up the Khakhovka dam to prevent Ukrainian troops from launching an offensive and advancing in the southern Kherson region. She said the action had been intended to help Russia de- ploy reserves to the Zaporizhzhia and Bakhmut areas.1301 On June 12, Zelenskiy stated that an investi- gation by the international criminal court had started over the breach of the Kakhovka dam.1302


197.

Warning

Meanwhile, the discussion of sending fighter jets to Ukraine received a nuclear dimension. On June 6, Lavrov noted in a speech at a military base in Dushanbe in Tajikistan that the US-made F-16s could “accommodate” nuclear weapons and warned that supplying Ukraine with F-16s would escalate the conflict further. “If they do not understand this, then they are worthless as military strategists and planners,” the Russian foreign minister said about Western decision-makers.1303


198.

De-escalatory

In reaction, Kirby declined to discuss the nuclear capabilities of the F-16 jets, but noted that Presi- dent Biden had been consistent that he did not want to see the war escalate, certainly not into the nu- clear realm. Instead, the purpose of providing advanced fighter aircraft was “to help Ukraine defend

itself, defend its airspace and its territorial integrity,” Kirby said.1304


On June 7, media reported that in closed-door sessions at the Shangri-La Dialogue the Ukrainian dele- gation had brought up the idea of obtaining F-18s alongside the F-16 fighter. Dozens of old but servicea- ble F-18s might be available for export by the end of the decade, as Australia, Canada, Switzerland and Finland transition to F-35s, the argument went.1305


Concerning security guarantees to Ukraine, former NATO secretary general Anders Rasmussen said on

June 7 that a group of NATO countries may be willing to put troops on the ground in Ukraine if member

states did not manage to provide tangible security guarantees to Kyiv at the alliance’s summit in Vil-

nius.1306


On June 8, of nine US congresspeople renewed pressure on the White House to send Ukraine long- range munitions, urging Biden to greenlight the Army Tactical Missile System. The letter also called on the president to approve other advanced weaponry, including F-16 fighter jets and additional air de- fense capabilities such as another Patriot missile defense system.1307 The following June 9, a bipartisan sextet introduced a House bill that called on the Biden administration to send Army Tactical Missile Sys- tems to Ukraine.1308


Meanwhile, the discussion of providing security guarantees to Ukraine picked up again. According to five European diplomats, the Western alliance was still divided. One proposal was the so-called Kyiv Security Compact, a concept Zelenskyy’s office had developed with Rasmussen. That plan would see a

core group of allies make binding commitments to fortify Ukraine’s defenses for years to come with both military and non-military aid. Separately, a group of former senior Western defense officials and aca- demics have put forward an idea focused on long-term cooperation and helping Ukraine rapidly expand its own defense industry. In reaction to these discussions, on June 7, Stoltenberg stated that NATO se- curity guarantees were Article 5, and thus full membership, but that he was aware about ongoing “dis- cussions and consultations between Ukraine and some allies on bilateral arrangements.” On June 8,

Ukraine’s deputy prime minister Olha Stefanishyna urged that Ukraine needed “clear security guaran- tees following the example of Finland and Sweden,” that applied “for the transition period before

Ukraine’s actual accession to NATO.”1309 On June 9, US Ambassador to NATO Julianne Smith stated that Ukraine was unlikely to get a formal offer to join NATO while being “engaged in full-scale war,” but that NATO allies wanted to signal to Zelensky in at the alliance’s Vilnius summit that “we care deeply about having a longer-term relationship with Ukraine and looking for ways to acknowledge, you know, all they’ve accomplished and that our support isn’t going to fade away or that we’re not going to get dis- tracted.”1310


199.

Warning

Concerning the stationing of tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus, Putin told Lukashenko on June 9 that Russia would start deploying them after the facilities were ready on 7-8 July, adding that every- thing was “going according to plan.”1311


Also on June 9, the North Atlantic Council stated that Russia’s decision to withdraw from the Treaty on

Conventional armed forces in Europe (CFE) was “the latest in a series of actions that systematically un-

The same June 9, Hungarian Deputy Prime Minister Zsolt Semjen stated that Hungary had received a group of Ukrainian prisoners of war from Russia, a release that the Ukrainian foreign ministry wel- comed while emphasizing “the need to coordinate cooperation on such sensitive issues.” The Russian Orthodox Church’s Moscow Patriarchate confirmed the same day that “at the request of the Hungarian side, a group of Ukrainian prisoners of war of Transcarpathian origin who participated in the hostilities was transferred to Hungary.”1313


Regarding further support for Ukraine, the US administration announced a new $2.1 billion assistance package for Kyiv on June 9. The aid included more munitions for the Patriot air-defense system, HAWK air-defense systems and missiles and Puma unmanned aerial systems.1314 The following June 10, Tru- deau stated Canada would be part of a multinational effort to train Ukrainian fighter pilots, announcing additional military and humanitarian aid for Kyiv. Trudeau added that Russia was responsible and would be held accountable for the destruction of the Kakhovka dam.1315 In a similar vein, also on June 10, the UK foreign secretary James Cleverly announced that the UK would provide an extra £16m of humanitarian aid to Ukraine after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam.1316 In addition, on June 14, me- dia reported that the Biden administration was expected to send depleted-uranium rounds to Ukraine after internal debates about how to arm the Abrams tanks that will be delivered.1317 The news came the same day Blinken unveiled a $325 million package for Ukraine, one that included more munitions for High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems, anti-tank weapons, armored vehicles, artillery rounds and other equipment. 1318


Underlining slim prospects for peace talks, Peskov stated on June 11 that there was “practically no pre- condition for an agreement at the moment,” and that there was “no foundation, even flimsy, for any kind of dialogue.” He claimed Kiev was lacking openness to negotiations due to its alleged unwillingness and unpreparedness, but also not being allowed by its Western sponsors.1319

1317 Michael R. Gordon and Gordon Lubold, “U.S. Set to Approve Depleted-Uranium Tank Rounds for Ukraine,” The Wall Street Jour- nal, June 13, 2023 [https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-set-to-approve-depleted-uranium-tank-rounds-for-ukraine- f6d98dcf?mod=world_lead_pos1].


1318 Eli Stokols and Ari Hawkins, “Biden reaffirms support of NATO alliance, announces more military aid to Ukraine,” Politico, June 13, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/news/2023/06/13/blinken-previews-robust-package-for-ukraine-with-nato-secretary- general-00101734].


1319 “Russia Seeing No Foundation for Peace Talks With Ukraine,” Sputnik International, June 11, 2023 [https://sput- nikglobe.com/20230611/russia-seeing-no-foundation-for-peace-talks-with-ukraine-1111058959.html].

On June 12, a very large NATO military exercise took place over Germany, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic. About 10,000 soldiers from 25 countries were involved, making use of 250 military jets to prepare for an attack on one of NATO’s members. Although the exercise was planned long before Rus- sia’s February 2022 invasion of Ukraine, it was nevertheless seen as a signal towards the Kremlin.1320


Meanwhile, announcements of military support to Ukraine continued. On June 12, Netherland’s defense minister Kajsa Ollongren specified that the Netherlands would aim to begin training Ukrainian pilots on F-16 jets in summer 2023, adding that the aim was to have the training program fully operational within six months, with Denmark being a possible location to host the program. She further stated that a final decision had not yet been taken on a request from Kyiv to supply dozens of F-16s. The US-backed training program would include Belgium and Luxembourg, while France and Britain had also offered assistance, she stated. Two sources said the training would begin with two groups of 12 Ukrainian pi- lots, already experienced flying Soviet-era MiGs.1321 On June 16, Stoltenberg in a statement “strongly” welcomed the Danish and Dutch leadership in the initiative, “for demonstrating their will to really step up support for Ukraine,” adding that the fact that Allies were now “starting training” meant that NATO would then “have the possibility, on short notice, also to make decisions of delivering planes,” which would, however, depend on the time it took to train the pilots and the assessment of the needs.1322 Also on June 16, Ollongren stated that the Netherlands had a number of decommissioned F-16 fighter jets that could be made available for training Ukrainian pilots. However, the partners were still deciding whether those jets would be needed, she said.1323


On June 13, Colonna stated that France had prevented an attack on its foreign ministry website that was likely carried out by Russian or Russian-speaking individuals, adding that authorities had pre- vented an identity-hack attempt on that site, and that Paris believed there was a broader campaign of spreading disinformation in France from Russian parties. France's foreign ministry said it could not di- rectly attribute the attacks to Russian authorities, but Colonna said Russian embassies and Russian cul- tural institutes were involved in the campaign by spreading disinformation.1324


Continuing the debate on Western security guarantees for Ukraine, according to multiple American and European officials speaking on June 14, the United States, Britain, France and Germany were working together to provide those assurances to Kyiv. They would formalize their military and economic support for Ukraine for an indefinite period of time, and thus continue it even after the fighting has stopped. The US was “in talks” with Ukraine and its allies and partners “on how we can reassure Ukraine about their


1320 “Ukraine war live: Evening summary,” Guardian, June 10, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/jun/12/rus- sia-ukraine-war-live-counteroffensive-seeing-first-localised-results-says-kyiv-icc-probe-of-kakhovka-dam-disaster-has-begun].


1321 Anthony Deutsch, “Exclusive: Coalition aims to begin Ukrainian F-16 pilot training by summer, Dutch minister says,” Reuters, June 12, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/coalition-aims-begin-ukrainian-f-16-pilot-training-by-summer-dutch- minister-2023-06-12/].


1322 “Press conference by NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg following the meeting of NATO Ministers of Defence in Brus- sels,” NATO, June 16, 2023 [https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/opinions_215694.htm].


1323 “National Security Daily: The complex,” Politico, June 16, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security- daily/2023/06/15/more-oil-on-the-fire-serbia-kosovo-heats-up-again-00102114].


1324 “France says it uncovered mass Russian-linked misinformation campaign,” Reuters, June 13, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/french-foreign-minister-prevented-attack-website-likely-carried-out-by-russian-2023-06-13/]; Laura Kayali and Clea Caulcutt, “France exposes mega Russian disinformation campaign,” Politico, June 13, 2023 [https://www.polit- ico.eu/article/france-accuses-russia-of-wide-ranging-disinformation-campaign/].

long-term security to deter any future aggression for after this war ends,” a National Security Council spokesperson confirmed.1325


In a message that could be read as re-assuring towards the Russian population in reaction to Ukraine’s counter-offensive, Putin stated on June 13 that while Russia needed to fight enemy agents and improve its defenses against attacks deep inside its own territory, it would not make any sense to follow

Ukraine’s example and “introduce some kind of special regime or martial law in the country,” he said, adding there was “no such need today.”1326


200.

Warning

Lukashenko said on June 13 that Belarus had started receiving missiles and nuclear warheads from Russia, adding that these nuclear weapons were “three times more powerful than those [dropped on] Hiroshima and Nagasaki.” He warned that “there would be no hesitation” to use the Russia-provided nuclear weapons “in the event of an aggression against us,” adding that a response would be “immedi- ate.” He further said that Belarus needed the weapons “to make sure not a single foreign soldier sets their foot on the Belarusian land again.”1327


201.

Warning

On June 16, Putin confirmed at the St Petersburg International Economic Forum that the first nu- clear warheads had been delivered to Belarus, “but just the first ones, this is the first batch.” He said that the use of nuclear weapons was “undoubtedly theoretically possible for Russia,” and that it was “possible” if there was “a threat to our territorial integrity, independence and sovereignty, to the ex- istence of the Russian state.” He added that Russia had “more of these weapons than NATO countries do, they know that” and that there was a “serious danger” that the NATO military alliance could be pulled further into the Ukraine war. He further underlined that stationing these weapons in Belarus was “an element of deterrence, a signal to those who think about inflicting a strategic defeat on Rus-

sia.” Still, he stressed that while nuclear weapons had been “made to ensure our security in the broad- est sense of the word and the existence of the Russian state,” Moscow currently had “no such need” to use them.1328


In contrast, Peskov signaled that Russia was not opposed to further arms control talks but that pro- spects remained meagre. He stated on June 18 that overall, the situation in arms control and strategic security was “rather bad than good;” it required “immediate” bilateral Russian-American negotiations, as well as negotiations “in a wider format.” However, he added that “so far” relations with Washington


1325 Alexander Ward, Matt Berg and Ari Hawkins, “The ‘European Quad’ weighs security guarantees for Ukraine,” Politico, June 14, 2023 [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/national-security-daily/2023/06/14/the-european-quad-weighs-security-guaran- tees-for-ukraine-00101897]; “Western allies plan to provide long-term security assurances to Ukraine,” Financial Times, June 14, 2023 [https://www.ft.com/content/8f0528ba-45a4-42c0-b099-07a34e2ee9ff].


1326 “Putin sees no need to declare martial law on Russia’s entire territory,” TASS, June 13, 2023 [https://tass.com/poli- tics/1631713].

1328 “Putin warns NATO over being drawn into Ukraine war, says Russia has more nuclear weapons,” CNN, June 17, 2023 [https://edition.cnn.com/2023/06/17/europe/nato-danger-ukraine-war-putin-intl-hnk/index.html]; “Putin says Russia put nu- clear bombs in Belarus as warning to West,” Reuters, June 17, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/putin-says-russia- positions-nuclear-bombs-belarus-warning-west-2023-06-16/].

had been “so bad” and “at such a low point that any substantial dialogue [was] out of the question for now.”1329


In addition, an official announcement of the United States, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and

Denmark partnering to send “high priority defense equipment to Ukraine” including “hundreds of short and medium range air defense missiles and associated systems” came in a joint statement released by the British government on June 15. The statement further read that the delivery of equipment had al- ready begun and should be completed “within several weeks.”1330


Meanwhile, diplomatic tensions between the West and Russia remained high. On June 15, the Austral- ian government stated it would cancel Russia’s lease to build a new embassy in Canberra due to secu- rity concerns. In reaction, the Kremlin called the Australian decision a hostile move which reflected what it said was the authorities’ anti-Russian sentiment.1331 The same June 15, the Russian foreign min- istry summoned the Australian ambassador in Moscow Graeme Meehan. Peskov stated this was “Rus- sophobic hysteria.”1332 On June 21, the Russian foreign ministry stated that Russia had barred an addi- tional 48 Australians from entering the country in what it said was retaliation for Australia’s long- running sanctions regime against it. On June 23, the Russian embassy in Australia stated that it had “ap- pealed to the Supreme Court because of Canberra’s termination of the contract for the lease of a new piece of land.”1333


Keen to foster support for peace talks, a delegation of African leaders began a peace mission in Kyiv on June 16. After meeting the delegation, Zelenskiy reiterated his position that peace talks with Russia would be possible only after Moscow withdrew its troops from the “entire” territory of Ukraine.1334 In Moscow on June 17, Putin welcomed the African leaders’ “balanced approach” and stated that he was “open to a constructive dialogue” with those who would consider the “legitimate interests of the par- ties,” but was also reported to have dismissed most proposal as unrealistic.1335 Peskov told journalists on June 20 that Putin’s discussions with the African delegations had been “very productive,” but that Kyiv’s position meant that one could “hardly talk about stable grounds” for peace negotiations.1336


1329 “Situation in arms control bad, no potential for negotiations — Kremlin Spokesman,” TASS, 18 June, 2023 [https://tass.com/politics/1634531].


1330 “Joint statement by Denmark, the Netherlands, the UK, and the USA,” UK Ministry of Defence, June 15, 2023 [https://www.gov.uk/government/news/joint-statement-by-denmark-the-netherlands-the-uk-and-the-usa].

1334 “Ukraine tells African leaders no peace talks with Russia,” Reuters, June 16, 2023 [https://www.reuters.com/world/south- african-president-arrives-ukraine-peace-mission-2023-06-16/].


1335 “Russia-Ukraine war live,” Guardian, June 17, 2023 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/jun/17/russia-ukraine- war-live-counteroffensive-records-tactical-successes-as-troops-advance-south?CMP=share_btn_tw&page].


1336 “Kremlin says it sees scant grounds for Ukraine peace talks after African mission,” Reuters, June 20, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/article/ukraine-crisis-russia-africa-kremlin-idAFS8N3850EO].

Also on June 16, regarding Ukraine’s NATO membership prospects, Biden talked to Stoltenberg about a proposal the latter had circulated among NATO members suggesting to waive the requirement for Ukraine to meet certain standards under a Membership Action Plan. According to a senior US official, Biden was “open” to this plan, if allies supported it. Biden further stated that he saw “no point” in hold-

ing the Vilnius summit without offering a clear “signal” that Ukraine would eventually become a NATO member.1337 Officials within European NATO governments told reporters the next day, June 17, that Stoltenberg’s plan was likely to succeed. Germany’s Pistorius agreed. “I would be open for this,” he said.1338 Nonetheless, the US position was less clear than it seemed on first sight. Also on June 17, Biden noted that Kyiv had to “meet the same standards” for joining NATO. The alliance system needed to be secure. Ukraine had to be “non-corrupt” and “meet all the standards.” He was not “going to make it

easy.” Could Ukraine fulfill these conditions? “I think it will. I think it can. But it is not automatic.” In the same interview, Biden also reiterated that it was “totally irresponsible” for Russia to deploy nuclear weapons to Belarus.1339


A number of other developments captured media attention. In Moscow, Peskov said on June 17 that the grain deal had “no chance” to be extended – but it was “hardly possible to predict any final decision.”1340 However, Russia wanted to keep in force its agreement with the UN to facilitate its exports of grain and fertilizer, deputy foreign minister Alexander Grushko told journalists on June 19.1341


In Paris, Thierry Breton, the EU commissioner for the internal market, told journalists on June 18 that the EU was “going to step up” its “efforts to deliver arms and ammunition – this is a war of high intensity in which they play a crucial role,” Breton said. “We are preparing for the war to last several more months, or even longer,” he added.1342


Meanwhile, hostilities continued. In London, British officials briefing the press on June 18 noted that both sides were taking high casualties as Ukraine was fighting to dislodge Russian forces from occupied areas.1343 On June 19, Ukrainian forces appeared to attack Russia’s Belgorod region, particularly the Valuisk municipal district, according to Russian sources.1344 On the same June 19, Ukrainian defense officials claimed their forces had shot down four Kalibr cruise missiles and a number of Shahed drones.1345 During the night of June 20, Russia launched attacks across Ukraine – Kyiv’s spokespeople

said about two-dozen Iranian drones had been destroyed.1346 Overall, it seemed difficult for the Ukrain- ians to pierce Russia’s well-prepared lines of defense, analysts concluded.1347


Debates on whether Ukraine would be invited to join NATO at Vilnius also continued. Stoltenberg told the press in Berlin on June 19 that no formal invitation for Ukraine to join NATO would be extended at Vilnius. Instead, leaders would talk about how to move Ukraine closer to NATO. Yet he also warned against accepting a frozen conflict. “We all want this war to end, but a just peace cannot mean freezing the conflict and accepting a deal dictated by Russia,” he said. At the same press conference, Scholtz said that Germany was prepared for the possibility that the war in Ukraine could last longer.1348


Some other statements attracted media attention. In Beijing, Blinken said on June 19 that China had renewed its promises not to send arms to Russia.1349 In California, Biden reiterated on the same June 19 in a side comment that the threat of Putin using nuclear weapons was “real.”1350 One day later, on June 20, after meeting Chinese Premier Li Qiang in Berlin, Scholz said he “appealed again” to China to “exert its influence even more strongly on Russia in this war.” It was important that China continued “not to deliver weapons to the aggressor, Russia,” the German chancellor said.1351


202.

Warning

Russian threats returned on June 20. In Moscow, Shoigu told military officials that Ukraine was plan- ning to strike Crimea with Western weapons. An attack on the “territory of the Russian Federation, including Crimea” with Himars and Storm Shadow missiles would constitute an attack “outside the

zone of the special military operation” and would mean “the full involvement of the United States and Great Britain in the conflict.” Russia would respond with “immediate strikes on decision-making cen- tres on the territory of Ukraine,” he said.1352


Concerning Ukraine’s NATO membership bids, on June 20, Ukraine’s ambassador to NATO, Natalia Galibarenko, said her government wanted at the Vilnius summit “some kind of invitation – or at least commitment […] to look at the timeframe and modalities of our [NATO] membership.” But she under- stood that for many within the Alliance this was a “red line” because they believed “that it creates a bur- den for them.” Hence, if Ukraine did not get an invitation, this would be a “bad message,” but not the

1352 “Russia warns Ukraine against striking Crimea with U.S., British missiles,” Reuters, June 20, 2023 [https://www.reu- ters.com/world/europe/russia-warns-ukraine-against-striking-crimea-with-us-british-missiles-2023-06-20/].

“end of the world.”1353 The following June 21, Cleverly stated that the UK would be “very supportive” of a fast-tracked accession to NATO for Ukraine, adding that he thought “all NATO allies” would “recognize” that the offer to both Sweden and Finland did not require a MAP, and Ukrainians had demonstrated their commitment to reform the military for the requirements of NATO membership.1354 Also, Wallace said on June 29 that NATO should “absolutely look at skipping” the MAP, but allies had to “all move to- gether” and there were 31 members in NATO.1355


Regarding further financial support for Ukraine, also on June 20, von der Leyen unveiled an aid pack- age for 2023-27worth €50bn, stating that the aim was to “provide predictable finance to Ukraine on its EU path, together with global partners and the private sector.” Of the aid pledge, 17 billion were meant as grants and the rest as low-interest loans.1356


With view to sanctions, on June 21, EU governments agreed to an 11th package of sanctions against Russia, aimed at stopping other countries and companies from circumventing existing measures. It for- bade transit via Russia of an expanded list of goods and technologies which might aid Russia’s military or security sector. The biggest novelty, diplomats said, was enabling restrictions on the sale of sensitive dual-use goods and technology to third countries that might sell it on to Russia.1357


The same June 21, adding to nuclear warnings, Putin announced that new Sarmat nuclear-capable in- tercontinental ballistic missiles would soon enter service. He stressed that “the most important task” was “the development of the nuclear triad,” which was “a key guarantee of Russia’s military security and global stability,” also stating that already about half of the units and formations of the Strategic Missile Forces were equipped with the latest Yars systems, and the troops were being re-equipped with modern missile systems with the Avangard hypersonic warhead.1358


Regarding the training of Ukrainian pilots on F-16s, the same June 21, a US Defense Department offi- cial stated that a coalition of Western countries thought Romania could be a good place to train Ukrain- ian pilots to fly F-16 fighter jets. The group was working to negotiate a contract to conduct the aircraft training at a site in Romania, Pentagon officials said.1359


1353 Lili Bayer, “Ukraine wants commitment on NATO membership bid,” Politico, June 20, 2023 [https://www.politico.eu/arti- cle/ukraine-seeks-political-decision-but-realistic-on-nato-membership-war-russia/].
